Not very long since,—having a HouseThus in printed source, for “horse.” in these days, and your old lodging having thus become accessible to me again, I pulled at the bell of the old House-door (House and Street recognizable to me by eyesight, title of them entirely forgotten),12 Spring St., Sussex Gdns., where she lived from Dec. 1854 to end Aug. 1856, when she moved to Stratford-upon-Avon. pulled there for several
minutes, again and again: but nobody would answer;—I considered withal that probably nobody might in the least know.

But now we again hear from yourself; that you are still well; nay more, that you have achieved a manifest success in what has long been the grand Problem of your life. Well done! This must be a greater joy to you than health itself, or any other blessing; and I must say that by your steadfastness you have deserved it!— You could not have a better Publisher than Parker; I am really thankful, along with you, that your word is at last to go forth.She had heard, 29 Oct., that her manuscript, ascribing the authorship of Shakespeare’s plays to Francis Bacon, had been accepted for publication by J. W. Parker through the efforts of Nathaniel Hawthorne (1804–64), novelist and U.S. consul in Liverpool 1853–57). It was pbd. with a pref. by Hawthorne as The Philosophy of the Plays of Shakespere Unfolded (1857). For TC’s unsuccessful attempt to persuade Parker to publish her work, see 28:320TC to JWP, 21 Nov. 1853, and 337TC to DB, 10 Dec. 1853.

My incredulity of your Thesis I have never hidden from you:For TC’s skepticism, see 28:166TC to DB, 8 June 1853. but I willingly vote, and have voted, you should be heard on it to full length; and this, whatever farther come of it, will be a profit to the world, and to yourself—I need not say what profit it will be!

When you return to London let us, so soon as possible, see you again.Bacon did not return to London, continuing to live in Stratford-upon-Avon until Dec. 1857, when she was moved to a small private asylum for the insane at Henley-in-Arden, 8 mi. from Stratford. TC never saw her again. We are in our old way, except that my Wife is rather poorlier than in common Winters (which are always unkind to her), and that I myself am sunk deeper than ever towards the very centre of Chaos,—in fact overwhelmed with such a mud-ocean of confusions and inexecutable businesses, late and early, as are like to drown me altogether, I sometimes think. But they won’t either!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-ED [EDW], 15 Dec. MS: Houghton 52M-179. Addr: Charles H. Mills Esq / For Miss Dwight / Boston / United States. PM: Boston, 2 Jan. Quot: Ashton 385; Fielding and Sorensen 196–97.
div3.head: JWC TO ELISABETH DWIGHT

docBody.p: You dear best girl in all America! I embrace you with all my heart, (as you left it),She had sailed, 4 Oct. and all my strength (considerably impaired); and thank you warmly for having given me a surprise, and a pleasure, and a consolation all in one!

Had your sister consulted the Stars for the favourablest moment to present that chair she could have done no better.2 Ellen Twisleton described to Elisabeth the visit when she had presented the chair, 11 Nov.: “She was delighted with the chair, which did really look lovely, & said she should write to you— ‘the little darling,’ she said ‘& to think I have not got her here to kiss her!’ Miss Wynne, the lady who refused a Duke was there whom she has often spoken to me of, & who looked a strong, good woman—& the everlasting Jewsbury. I did not present the chair until they had gone, however, don’t suspect me. Mrs C. is miserably, & does not get any better, & will not see any physician.” She wrote, 11 Dec.: “I have been doing the sociable this week. … Mrs Carlyle I took out for a drive yesterday, early, being fair and sunny: she is very pale, & has also had an attack. I saw your chair in its place, & it is a beauty, the colors & pattern are perfect for that room; she apologised for not writing, but I told her you would not care, as her head is in that dreadful state that mine was, last winter, And it almost kills her to write” (Houghton 45M-98). The moment she hit upon was one, when my soul (if I could any longer be said to have a soul) was crying alouldThus in MS. to Mr Carlyle’s friends “The Destinies,"For TC on destiny, cf. 5:13TC to HI, 31 March 1829. “The Immortal Gods,” “The Superior Powers” to bid something happen; and, if possible something pleasant! My very physical life was feeling to depend on something “out of the Blue” (as your Miss Sedgwick quoted us—Possibly Catherine Maria Sedgwick (1789–1867), novelist, whose mother was also a Dwight, or her niece Susan Ridley Sedgwick (1838?–72) later to marry Charles Eliot Norton (see 27:400–40127:biographical note). God forgive her!) coming to quicken my languid circulation, and interrupt the circular course of my ideas! For, my Dear, I was in a crisis of disordered nerves complicated with “the contradictions of sinners,"See Heb. 12:3. and for the rest, was it not “the gloomy month of November in which,” as the Frenchman began his novel, “the People of England hang and drown themselves"? Into this state of things your sister introduced the chair! and I doubt if a whole course of tonics “thrown into the system” could have done me half the good; tho’ Geraldine Jewsbury told me that very morning she “knew I was lying dying there, all for want of tonics?!”Jewsbury had called, 10 Dec., before visiting the Hargreaves, Silwood Park, Sunninghill, Berkshire. She wrote, 11 Dec.: “Though I shall be home to-morrow unless something a great deal more particular than I expect happens to prevent it yet I want to write this line to you to say how do you do & how did you sleep? … They are in the great house now … it looks very beautiful—but not at all fine. … Upon my honour I am disillusioned about the pleasure of furnishing a fine house & the bother of it stands pre-eminent.” She wrote of her friend’s son: “he is now so weak that sometimes … going from one room to another is too much for him … his mother is dreadfully anxious & if he belonged to me so shd I be.—but then you say I always want to kill people off.” I assure you for a measurable space of time I stood amazed before it (the chair) “as in presence of The Infinite"!Coterie speech; one of JWC’s phrases, source possibly a sermon; cf. Carlyle, Reminiscences 12. Then as my thoughts separated themselves into
a certain distinctness, and I realized that all these lovely leaves had been worked for me! that you had worked them for me! and that you were away to “the other side,” so that I could not get at you to kiss you! my mercury rose from freezing to Summer Heat; and I did not know whether to laugh or cry, and so did both, I am afraid, which looked rather foolish!—Meanwhile your sister sat on a low chair beside my sofa: cheering me like “the Singing Tree, the Talking Bird and the Golden Water” all in one!All in “The Two Sisters Jealous of Their Younger Sister,” Arabian Nights’ Entertainments, trans. Rev. Edward Forster (1844) 471–89. And when she went away leaving me alone with my chair I found myself saved—for that time! Upon my honour I dont quite believe that woman is a woman at all! I mean I have my own suspicion that Mrs Edward Twisleton is the Fairy Paribanou Rediviva!“Prince Ahmed and the Fairy Pari-Banou,” Arabian Nights’ Entertainments 447–70. Did you ever notice how the room, which she comes into, grows all sunshiny; even tho’ it be a “gloomy-November” day and fog pressing up to the windows? Then see how wonderfully she adapts her speech to your state! I have never seen her during this long illness without being reminded of a magic casket I have read of in Fairy Literature (my favourite Literature I blush to say!) in which you had only to dive and draw forth whatever thing you practically needed at the moment; were it a sword to cut off a giants head or diamond slippers to dance in at a ball!—Untraced. Oh I do love her dearly! and always the more the longer! I should tell you for your comfort that she never looked so well since I knew her as she is doing just now. Such a difference since last winter at the Grange! My only regret for her is that she has not a sister always with her; she loves her family so much! and naturally there are so few women here that she can sympathize with!Ellen reported that JWC “was full of Lady Sandwich’s saying that it made her crawl all over to have Mrs Brookfield sit down and talk to her, & that she was sure she was doing ‘Harriet’ a great deal of harm. … Of course this was nuts to Mrs Carlyle. Mr Brookfield departed for Nice last week, having infuriated Mrs Carlyle by coming to Chelsea, ‘to take the very latest news of Mr & Mrs Carlyle’ ” (Houghton 45M–98).

Do you know I think you must be an adorable family; If it weren’t that a sea voyage would be certain death to me; I would set about trying to persuade Mr Carlyle to get up a course of “Georges"Thackeray’s most recent tour of the U.S. (winter 1855–56) included lectures on “The Four Georges” (George I to George IV of Britain). or somethings to make money of in America and accompany him; on purpose to see all Mrs Twisleton’s sisters!Elisabeth Dwight, Anna Mills (b. Dwight), and Mary Parkman (b. Dwight). I “did intend” to write a long letter, and to tell you about everybody and everything; but I am already tired— being still about as effective as an eel trying to stand on its tail! However I get out now most days for a drive, and expect before long to be able to do a little walking anyhow when Paribanou
returns from Bowood“Paribanou“: Ellen Twisleton. Bowood Park, nr. Calne, Wiltshire, the home of Lord Lansdowne. I seriously mean to go to lunch with her. Will you remember me to the kind sisterMary Parkman or Anna Mills. who made me the pretty camisole, the pattern of which has been asked for both in Scotland and England
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

ps.p: It was quite a mistake about Mr Carlyle “talking quite rationally“—never any such thing I assure you!
The last news of him is that he has got a horse and a secretary (German) and the German secretary is going to prove invaluable to me, I rather think as a Lightning Conductor. Blitz Ableiter.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 19 Dec. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas / Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. MS: NLS 552.132. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: I am very glad you have decided on taking up that Business: it is clear to me you will find that a more productive line of industry, and far more satisfactory, than any that could have been had out of “Literature” in any form of it. You have been called into the thing by an evident emergency of new demand; it is not your own forethought or voluntary scheme at all;—and yet it bids very fair to form a real improvement in your way of life.Now responsible for his sister and her two young children after Adolph Frankau’s death, Neuberg had failed in an attempt at employment in the Public Records Office; see TC-JNTC to JN, 24 Nov. His new “Business” is not known.

I ride daily, an excellt swift strong and most good-natured well-bred horse: but I have got a swollen-cheek (bless the mark!)1 Henry IV 1.3. a continual headache; and hitherto do not prosper in improving of health. I understand these phenomena to mean the “transition” penalties of change from foot to horseback; and so mean to persevere.

Thanks for the Duchess;Probably Wolfgang Menzel, Briefe der Princessin Elisabeth Charlotte von Orleans an die Raugräfin Louise, 1676;–1722 (Stuttgart, 1843), from the London Lib.; see 30:84TC to JN, 20 Oct. 1855. I will try the Book tonight.— Decker’s £30 is probably all Martin can give.Decker, the Berlin publishing firm, currently operating under the directorship of Rudolf Ludwig Decker (1804–77); see 21:37527:375TC to RLDAKD, 27 Dec. 1852. Presumably Frederick Martin wanted books from Decker. The volumes are to be the size of the Cromwell ones 3d Editn,—3 of them make four voll. such as those of the French
Revolution.Frederick was planned in four but pbd. in six vols.; see 31:81TC to JCA, 5 May 1856.— I make dreadfully poor way in late weeks. My Schreiber [secretary] is one of the willingest of men; but makes dreadful interpretations of me! Likewise the thing has been, as heretofore, inexpressibly confusing and disgusting. God sent me thro’ it, for I never was in the like!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-VL, 19 Dec. Addr: Doctors Commons. MS: NLS 23107.98. Pbd: Fielding, “Vernon Lushington” 11 inc.
div3.head: TC TO VERNON LUSHINGTON

docBody.p: I have gone over the First Volume, under your guidance; and fancy it now ready for the Printer,—if once I had seen a glimpse of you again.

The Report (program included) is confirmable in every particular: a clear reasonable method, and set forth with perfect clearness. It shall be altogether as you say; and you shall do the “editing” &c, according to your own beneficent proposal;—and I hope very soon to wash my hands of the affair in that manner.

Only come Tomorrow (Saturday) Evg, at the old hour, if you can;—and bring along with you the Fourth volume of my Copy:Of Cromwell (1850), 3d edn., 4 vols. in 3, acc. to Yale catalog of Beinecke collection. An unidentified and undated bookseller’s offering of three vols. of this edn. for sale states that this was “Carlyle’s copy, used by him in preparing a new edition, with numerous alterations and additions in his hand. This is also the copy used by the printer in setting up the type for the new edition, as it bears many printer’s notes throughout.” TC noted on the subtitle of vol. 1 for Lushington: “Notes added in this 4th. Editn. call them uniformly (Note of 1857) / Mark in the Index (as you go on) where there is any new matter worth ‘indicating,’ as at p. 69; item a new letter there will be (in appendix) to one of Oliver’s Aunts (Elizth, I think) &c [to his sister Elizabeth; see Works 9:267]. / There is to be no breaking up of the text: the new Pieces (not above a couple of sheets I shd. guess) go all into Appx. you know where the divisions of the vols are to be, and that they are 3 again? Probably you will get the copy in whole before ending this first vol. / Text perfect in here, I believe: guide it well! / T. C. (28 Decr 1856) / N.b. Keep your copy carefully for the sake of Index” (Yale). There are marginal notes and inserted slips of comments and corrections throughout the three vols. I do not know always what the “Appendix” treats of by the resources I have.— Unfortunately I have hardly cut out any of the references yet, tho’ sensible of their tendency to distract the reader’s attention from what is chiefly worthy of attending to.

I have also cut out pientissimo altogether; doubtless the young gentn and you are right about its Ciceronian qualities;J. E. B. Mayor criticized TC’s “ancient” as opposed to his own “modern scholarship,” in a note to his introduction to Nicholas Ferrar, citing Cromwell, 3d edn.: ” ‘Pientissimo, which might as well be piantissimo if conjugation and declension were observed, is accredited barbarous-latin for most pious, but means properly most expiative; by which title the zealous individual of later date indicates his martyred Majesty [Charles I]: a most “expiative” Majesty indeed.’ Cromwell’s Letters, &c. i. 58.” Mayor continues: “When did Mr. Carlyle see a superlative formed from an active participle not used as an adjective? … It is hardly needful to say, that those who remember Cicero’s ridicule of Antony’s piissimus, and know the superlative of munificus, will readily divine the origin of pientissimus” (xxii). and most likely the old Diction—
aries are right too about its derivation from piantisso:—but I reflect that the whole question lies wide of my affairs; so we fling over the hedge and let the dogs worry over it that have a call thither.
Saturday at 7½ p.m.—and the Fourth volume with you.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A [LOA], 20 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Ashton 386.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Your Letter last night was of the nature of a godsend; bringing you all once more into my actual sphere of vision, after so long an interval: for which beneficent clear glimpse I give thanks; right glad to have it,—tho’ the news are not what I expected. By all accounts that could be gathered here, by direct tidings to Lady Sandwich, and rumours of a reflex nature that came, I understood in general that “all well” was the state of matters; and had no suspicion or imagination that My Lady especially was on the invalid list. But it has been otherwise. I suppose I need not say how glad I shall be to hear your favourable report on that evil matter confirm itself into the certainty you now seem to anticipate! It was of you always that one was in dread; and now it appears you go scot-free, and a thinner-skinned party pays the penalty. Let us hope that that too is on the way to “all well.” I fall at her Ladyship’s feet (as the George-Second Ambassadors do to little George),George William Frederick (1738–1820), the future George III. He became Prince of Wales and heir apparent to George II (1683–1760) when his father, Frederick Louis (1707–51), died; incident untraced. and make many prayers and promises!—

My existence ever since you left us has been sunk a long way under the common low depth: I can hardly remember to have been in such a boundless bottomless vortex as I had had to swim in for the last three months. Making hardly any perceptible way; yet swimming, not to sink altogether! My country “improvement of health” vanished altogether with my arrival here,—or seemed to vanish, for probably I did get essential good;—but the express-train, the town diet, the town life, seemed to have abolished it altogether and
even made it a negative quantity. Then there was Fredk, like to drive me delirious in the state it lay in; then a New Editn of my bits of Books, long clamoured for and now to go on: work witht limit, and no strength to do it with. I had to get a Horse, by way of trying for some strength of body at least:—I am confident you bought Kinloch Luichart Estate with about the tithe of the haggling, trying, corresponding &c I had on that small matter. However, here he is, an excellt little Nag at last (cannot remember to have ridden a nicer, except at The Grange now and then);—only no “health” has yet come; coming, we will fancy; as permanent headache, and a general shaking up of bile have evidently come. Furthermore I picked up a desolate little German with a good hand of writing; made of him a “spiritual galloway,” so to speak; who has cost me endless trouble;—a weak helpless creature, tho’ a nibling.Thus in MS; possibly related to “nibble,” stroke of luck, bargain. His last Clerk function was with Heyne the Blackguard Paris Jew:Heinrich Heine (1797–1856), German poet, humorist, and journalist. He was Jewish and enraged both radicals and conservatives when he strategically converted to Christianity in order to practice law in Berlin. After moving to Paris in 1831 to join the Saint Simonians (see 7:192JWC to TC, 26 May 1834) and escape Prussian persecution, he worked as a journalist writing articles on France for Allgemeine Zeitung. In articles pbd. in the Revue des Deux Mondes, later collected in D’Allemagne (1835), Heine had attacked Frederick the Great’s authoritarian influence on German culture. After the 1848 revolution, radicals’ suspicions that Heine was in the pay of Louis Philippe’s govt. were strengthened when it was revealed that he had been receiving a pension, probably granted by Thiers V1840 (Jeffrey L. Sammons, Heinrich Heine: A Modern Biography [Princeton,1979] 223–24). Richard Monckton Milnes wrote a sympathetic account of his life, Edinburgh Review 104 (July 1856): 192–209. I often wonder what the poor creature thinks of being Wagner to such a pair of Fausts! We have ridden thro’ endless square miles of dim dreary “Wash” (like that of Lincolnshire),A wide shallow arm of the North Sea from the coast of Lincolnshire, nr. Boston, to the coast of Norfolk. shallow continents of muddy sea; both shores now invisible, nothing but a hope here and there of getting to some sandbank or mudbank, where the water is not above girth-high, & so looking round us a little. In short I have been, and am, nearly lost in the mud element;—and hugely to be pitied by you and her Ladyship. All goings-out, in fact all society with fellow-creatures (except my two horses, ‘spiritual’ and physical, of whom the latter is the more interesting) have ceased, or as good as ceased. “Christmas Dinner” this time will consist of mutton-chop, eaten with the maximum of quietude, within these poor walls. For, by way of consummation to everything, my poor Wife has fallen Prisoner, to cold &c; did not get out at all for about two months; and is still very feeble, tho’ evidently recovering for some weeks past.— Lady Sandwich too, as you doubtless know, has been unwell; the last time I saw her Ladyship was with the French Duchess,Possibly Marie Amélie de Bourbon (1782–1866; see 30:127TC to LOA, 29 Nov. 1855), who lived in Claremont, Shropshire, though as the widow of Louis Philippe (1778–1850) of France she might not have been called “Duchess”; or her da.-in-law Maria Caroline Augusta, b. de Bourbon, duchess d’Aumale (1822–69), m., 1844, to Henri Eugène Philippe Louis d’Orléans, duke d’Aumale (1822–97), who also lived in England. who, it
seems, did all the mischief: day before yesterday, and two other previous times, I found her “gone out driving,” clearly in a tolerably improved state. She left a card lately, but would not quit her carriage here.— — On the whole, I cannot think somehow, you have lost much by Nice tel quel [such as it is]. We have hardly seen the sun physical once a fortnight; sun moral I, for my own poor share, have not seen or heard of at all. Tickets-of-leaveProposals to change “licences to be at large” (popularly known as “tickets of leave,” granted to convicts to give them freedom on condition of good behavior) in the next session of Parliament were much discussed in the Dec. Times; R. M. Milnes wrote at length, asking the Times to use its influence “to appease the terror as well as advise the remedy; and that the remedy be something more than reprisal of brute force and the gratification of social vengeance” (16 Dec..) The new law, which abolished the term “transportation” and introduced remission of part of a sentence for good behavior, was introduced, 26 June 1857. and Doctors CommonsName given to College of Advocates and Doctors of Law, a self-governing teaching body specializing in canon and civil law. The society was dissolved, 1858, and its headquarters, Paternoster Row, nr. St. Paul’s Cathedral, demolished, 1867. are to be abolished. Palmerston resembles, to me, old M. de Maurepas:Count Jean Frédéric Phélypeaux de Maurepas (1701–81), French minister and prime minister; see French Revolution, Works 2:31, 40–42. better be far from him. I intend writing to My Lady.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GLC, 20 Dec. Addr: Queens College / Belfast / Ireland. PM: 20 Dec. 1856. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO GEORGE LILLIE CRAIK

docBody.p:
Dear, kind Man! Nature would have had me answer your letter by return of Post;1. Craik wrote from Holywood, Belfast, 13 Dec.: “Tell Carlyle that his cordial, kindhearted expressions were meat and drink to my soul. His quick eye too, has perfectly caught my design. The volume really was intended merely as a school-book, an educational manual, for the editors of Shakespeare. … I know no set of people that need something of the kind so much. … I have had several other gratifying letters about the Book, but there can be no other that I shall value as I do this of Carlyle’s.” Craik presumably sent TC a prepublication copy of The English of Shakespeare illustrated in a Philological Commentary on Julius Caesar (1857). The 2d rev. and improved edn. (1859) is in Carlyle’s House, Chelsea. to tell you I was mortal glad of it, and very pleased that you still liked me! or rather I should say very pleased to hear it. For I knew you too well ever to fancy it could be “out of sight out of mind” with you; or that any new
people, never to say Irish people, could displace one you had taken into your heart. Besides did not i still like you?Craik wrote: “Of you and Carlyle … I think as often since I have been here as I did when I lived beside you. You are seldom many hours out of my head. What do I not owe to both of you! Words cannot express, thought cannot measure it.” and (as I told a man. a Mr RossAlexander Ross, Kate Sterling’s husband. at Brighton, who thought fit to tell me he had “received a most disagreeable impression of me at first sight”) you know these things are always mutual! you could do no otherwise!

This much—not about Mr Ross but the rest of it—I felt a need to say at once. The reason which prevented me till now was a rather whimsical one. A letter of thanks due to an american girl,Elisabeth Dwight. (the Sister of Mrs Edward Twisleton) who had sent me an elaborate piece of needlework made into a lovely chair had lain on my conscience for weeks! and just the day before receiving your letter I had gone and “registered a vow in Heaven.” that I would not write to Man Woman or child till I had done “what the United States expected of me"! But a letter of thanks, that has “lain on one’s conscience for weeks” is the Devil and all to write, I can tell you! It is written now however and this is the very next.

Did that dear little Mary confide to you the fact of my new bonnet?See 31:126JWC to MC, 19 July.—a fine, etherial, altogether irrelevant bonnet which she stood by and let me purchase, nay encouraged me in purchasing to keep up my dignity in Scotland? Well! God forgive her share in the transaction! and now you may tell her; it was no go! literally!— That bonnet did not go with me to Scotland, after all! On considering the box “all to itself” it would require, and the rains it would be exposed to, and, above all, the moral shock it might give to individuals remembering when I was born; I just wrapt it in silk-paper, and locked it away, and haven’t seen it since! But myself went to Scotland, all right; and was there ten weeks. A wonderful ten weeks! spent chiefly in being kissed and cried over, by the oldest Inhabitants, wherever I staid! I never could decide all the while, nor can I decide yet, whether I was exquisitely happy or exquisitely miserable! I know only that the state, was exquisite after one sort or other; and that I shed more tears in those ten weeks than I had done in ten years! and that I often doubted if I were dreaming or awake? A living woman or a ghost? And that I travelled back to London with a birdcage containing two Haddington Canaries and two flower-pots containing each—a weed!! And that I found on my return I had had more emotion than was good for me; and fell seriously ill; and was confined to my room seven weeks and that it is only during the last fortnight I have been able to go out, for a drive!—and there you have a complete outline of my history since little Mary and I
parted.He wrote: “[L]et me bless you for that kind note you wrote to my good little Mary [see 31:125–26JWC to MC, 19 July]. It was the crowning triumph of her London visit, and will be a precious possession to her. … She really deserves too, let me say it, your good opinion of her honest, simple, unselfish nature. As I read what you wrote I seemed to hear you speaking the words. / I do not find that distance and separation and even suspension of all positive intercourse with my friends of other days at all weaken my attachment to them.” If you were sitting here beside me, and I wish you were; or if there were any brief dagueratype process by which I could transfer the details of that journey thro’ old homes, the chief pleasure of which was being cried over, and the chief objects graves! I would not let you off with an outline.

For the rest; Mr C has made two great acquisitions lately—a horse and a secretary (german). The horse is a Beauty, and Mr C. says “a remarkable combination of courage and sensibility"; the Secretary is decidedly ugly, and Mr C always speaks of him as “that fellow up stairs.” Plattnauer “hopes—he (the famulus) is going to prove of great use to me—as a Lightening-Conductor”; I hope so too— Certainly I have noticed that on the days when one hears what my servant calls “the sound of Mr Marten catching it”; a certain mildness is remarked down stairs.

Dear Mr Craik I well understand all you say to me about your Wife.Jeanette, b. Dempster, who d. earlier in the year. Craik wrote: “I will not talk to you now of my poor wife. But I may when we meet. The blank that her loss has made to me is very great. For thirty years she had been with me through it all—a constant companion, a constant care. And … in losing her I seem to have lost a main purpose for which I lived. Nor do I find … that the sense of deprivation lightens with the lapse of time.” It was just so, I fancied you would be feeling her loss. Your sorrow is the price you pay for being unselfish, loyal, tender. I like to think of your having such kind, sensible, dear girls for daughters:Mary and Georgina; a third da., mentioned in the ODNB is untraced. I am sure they will do their very best to close over the blank in your home.

But you must come away as soon as you are at liberty, must come and see us all, and get your thoughts shaken out of the circular train which they naturally fall into when every thing present to the senses suggests a recent grief. Many will be delighted to see you here—besides me— And I will introduce you to my canaries with whom and dear little Nero I mostly live at present. Imagine me falling back on two vermin of birds! laying out the private capital which should have been invested in a new winter-gown, on a superb structure of brass wire and polished mahogany for these yellow atoms to reside in! anticipating all their wants and even their “little fancies” (“we allow the Prisoners their little fancies here"! the Pentonville official once said to me.In 1851; see 26:8JWC to JWE, 7 Jan. 1851.)—talking to them about Haddington and “all that,” in the Canary Tongue which I have studied on purpose— And then taking Nero in my lap, to talk seriously to him on the folly of his open jealousy of these birds and the
dangers of indulging it. And then when I have brought him to penitent whimpering, stroking his poor little head, and kissing his little black nose, and fondly assuring his little warm heart, that no biped or quadruped or centiped could ever come between me and him, my kind little dog of many years—thrice stolen—thrice bought back!Jewsbury wrote from Manchester, 29 Dec.: “I told Stauros the other night … a history of Nero—& the very next night when I had forgotten all about it he came to me & said ‘Please Aunt Geraldine tell me about the little curly dog you have in London’— So Nero is become a regular nursery hero.”— All this sounds very—“what shall I say?"Coterie speech; see 17:36JWC to TC, 11 Aug. 1843.—innocent! does it not?

When will you be here? and the girls—will they come with you? Suppose we went to Scotland together next summer, I feel to love Scotland since this last visit more than I ever did before— Every body was so adorably kind to me— Love to my “little Mary and Georgina too— Yours affectionately always Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-HF [HFE], [24 Dec.]. Pbd: Hansons, NE 456–57 inc. The ellipses are in the printed source.
div3.head: JWC TO HELENA FERME

docBody.p:
I often think of that visit to Aberleddy;Aberlady; see 31:174JWC to TC, 13 Aug. 1856. and those children stark naked, and dripping wet; the drops on them sparkling in the sunshine like diamond beads as they held up their little mouths to be kissed; and such a beautiful sea for a background! There never was a prettier sight before or since! At least, not since Venus issued from the sea and was kissed by The Seasons!!At her birth from the waves of the sea, Venus is said to have been greeted by the goddesses of the seasons, who clothed her and accompanied her to Paphos in Cyprus and Mount Olympus. … The canaries have gained all hearts in this house (but one!). Even Mr Carlyle takes to them; tho’ truth to say, I rather expected he would wring their necks! … I have not been well enough to go down to breakfast for upwards of eight weeks but the other morning, the doors being all open, I was thunderstruck to hear my young friends chirruping at the very top of their lungs! When Mr C came into my room soon after, I apologized for the disturbance, and spoke of removing the cage. ‘Oh let them alone there!’ said he ‘the little wretches have been all this time as merry as maltsters! But their incessant distracted chirling rather amuses me!’ The one heart they have failed to gain is my Dog’s! He is in fact madly jealous of them, and has been so all along! If I so much as approach the cage in his presence, Nero runs to me, tears at my
skirt, whimpers, gur-r-rs, and rises in the end to a loud, spiteful single bark! The creature has been so exclusively devoted to me for years and years, that I am indulgent even for his egotism, and so I refrain from making of the birds, speaking endearingly (!) to them and all that, before his face but I do it all the more in his absence.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-KSR [KS], 27 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO KATE STERLING ROSS

docBody.p:
My darling Kate! Jewel of the world! I am so glad you have written to me! and to this purport!Kate Ross had apparently not seen JWC since her marriage on 17 May; see 30:248JWC’s Journal, 27 April. They were living in Lady Byron’s house, 6 Pavilion Bldgs., Brighton (Adelaide Ross, Memoir of Alexander J. Ross [1888] 52).— Just so, I should think, must the good catholic feel:—thus lightened and “all right,” when his Priest has given him absolution! I was afraid you could never be made to understand how that adorable letter you wrote to me in Scotland should have remained unanswered, not at all thro negligence, nor any shadow of change in my feelings for you; but simply thro—“What shall I say?—shyness!— Like Miss Wynn,Charlotte Williams Wynn. “I am very shy, tho’ I dont look it!”—first thro shyness, and then thro’ shame of myself. And so, I never tried to make you understand it!— This want of faith, and of go-o-o-dheadness in me, so different, I flatter myself, from anything seen or known of me before, we will, if you please, impute to physical disorder! It is the easiest and most comfortable way of dealing with it—I have just been putting myself thro’ a course of Mental PhysiologyProbably Sir Benjamin Brodie, Psychological Inquiries; see JWC to MR, [28 Nov.].—and there is no folly or stupidity or mortal sin even that I could not explain and justify on the hypothesis of a disordered state of the sympathetic nerve and its ganglia!!— My Dear, years and years ago, there was a horrid dirty old sow at my grandfathers;Probably Walter Welsh (1752–1832), her maternal grandfather, latterly of Templand; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 127; or John Welsh (1757–1823), her paternal grandfather, of Penfillan; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 112. and it struck me I should deserve well of the Republic,See 30:191JWC’s "Simple Story of My Own First Love". could I get that sow cleaned!— so I went and made a sweet little face to two of the men-servants, and bribed them with sixpence a-piece, to scrub that sow with soap and brushes! You may imagine how she yelled, laid on her back, and
sconered!Meaning unclear; generally pigs “scunnered” others, i.e., disgusted, repelled, rather than themselves; perhaps in the sense of “complained.” The noise brought my grandfather to the scene who stood amazed a space, as “in presence of the Infinite!"Coterie speech. Then addressed me with uplifted hands “God’s curse! Miss! You fall on strange plans for diverting yourself!” That is true now as it was then it would seem! diverting myself with Physiology in this last long illness! and in a former one you may remember I went far in “Insanity—”Perhaps in Nov. 1855; see 30:223JWC’s Journal, 24 Nov. 1855. Heigh ho! one is put to it, when shut up in the house ten weeks!— I am thankful however to be not at the Grange this winter—and to not have had the Xmas toys to buy!Unlike in 1853 and 1855; see 28:316–17JWC to LA, 19 Nov. 1853 and 30:231JWC’s Journal, 11 Dec. 1855. In all afflictions there are consolations!Cf. “deux afflictions,” 8:147TC to JAC, 15 June 1835, and 14:33TC to SELB, 31 Jan. 1842. (you may read that striking new sentiment to your “Hub” it “does credit to my head and heart!)—No closing quotations. Coterie speech, usually “hort”; see 12:310JWC to FJW, 1 Nov. 1840, and JWC to TC, [23 July 1857]. The Ashburtons are at Nice and that is how I come to be “well let alone"!Coterie speech; William Graham’s phrase about the fire; see 18:231JWC to HW, 7 Oct. 1844.

Mr C has aThus in MS. got a lovely horse that reminds him, he says of XarifaHeroine of “The Bridal of Andalla”; see 12:185TC to RWE, 2 July 1840.—also he describes it as “a most remarkable combination of Courage and Sensibility!!” Also he has got a little German Famulus, of an ugliness—! who (Plattnauer “hopes) is going to prove of great use to me as—lightening Conductor!"—I hope so too!—certainly on the days when one hears sounds of what Ann calls “Mr Marten catching it” from up stairs; it is observed that Mr C is unusually mild and “affable” when he comes down!

My Dear! George CookJohn George Cooke (b. 1820?); see 30:252JWC’s Journal, 18 May. comes to call for me almost every Sunday!— I should mention,—“not to put too fine a point on it,“—that he comes on his road from Geraldines! Geraldine and he seem to have “sworn everlasting Friendship“— with proviso, on his part, that there should positively be nothing more tender! Geraldine is now off to Manchester for a month or moreJewsbury began her visit to her brother Frank and his family in Manchester, 23 Dec.; she wrote, 24 Dec.: “[T]hey were very glad to see me & certainly Emily had exerted herself to get every thing as she thought I wd. like to see it—& evidently wishes me to be happy & comfortable the children are grown out of tiresome crying babies into a nephew & niece of whom any aunt might feel proud & they are in tolerable good training too—the house looks much nicer than it used to do when you knew it formerly. … So I am very glad to see Frank so well off—& I know it is much better for him to be as he is than to have gone on living with me—of course you won’t care to hear all this except as it concerns me.”—
We shall see if he come after me at all! I like him and we talk about you— Of course I never see a sign of the ColonelAnthony Sterling.—I hear of him sometimes, in the frivolous sense, from Annie Farrer—from no-one else— The “Crimean Heroes” no longer occupy the public mind; “Thanks God!"Coterie speech; Mazzini’s expression; see 30:209JWC’s Journal, 1 Nov. 1855.

Tell Mr Ross I passed thro’ his native place, when I was in Scotland. And have here, still alive, a nettle brought from the little lonely church yard at Crawfurd, which he must know well. My Mother is buried there.Crawford, SE Lanarkshire, on the banks of the Clyde; for the burial ground, see 14:146TC to JWC, 14 April 1842. Ross was born in Crawford manse, where his father, Rev. John Ross, was the Church of Scotland minister, 1807–28. More than this; I found that a second cousin of mine knew him. Her name was Hunter—Miss Hunter of Glenshaw—now Mrs PringleSee 31:27JWC to MR, 8 Feb. 1856. with ever so many thousands a year, the finest drawingroom in Nithsdale, and three red haired obstreperous children,

My child! it is the pen that is making this bad writing, not want of “a liberal education“— You shall see another time I will write as good a hand as other well brought up females— My Dear there is a little fascinating Mr Lushington, with dove’s eyes and without two fingers, who comes here now to tea very often—and he talks of you with interest

My kind love and a kiss to that dearest of Julias! I am so obliged to her for your letter as well as her ownJulia Sterling had written from Brighton, 25 Dec.; for her opinions of Kate’s husband in this letter, see 31:96JWC to KS, 14 May. I will contradict the statement about the will as often as I hear it— It is much to be wished some man of sense and solidity would marry up that well meaning, rather distracted young lady! Or she is likely to get into worse scrapes than Mrs WilliamsJulia wrote: “I lose no time in telling you that I hear from Miss Irby that she has not made a will in Mrs Williams’ favour! The poor girl seems to have made so many mistakes in her dealings with this wretched woman, that I am very anxious she should not have the credit of any more than she deserves. I am most thankful for many reasons that we are able to contradict this report.” Miss Irby and Mrs. Williams are not further identified.— God bless you my darling Kate— Your own ever

p.name: Jane W Carlyle
p.note: Julia had apparently visited JWC fairly recently, as she wrote: “I am not sorry either to have this excuse for writing you a few words from here as a kind of postscript to my last visit which was somewhat cut short by Mr. Plattner’s appearance! … It was a great comfort to me to find you really looking & seeming better; & I trust that as you have made a beginning in going out, though only in the omnibus (!) you will soon come to walking and getting about as usual”; for JWC’s omnibus excursions, see JWC to IC, [ca. 10 Dec.].

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 28 Dec. MS: NLS 516.39. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Tho’ in very great haste (as usual!), I will write you a word just now, lest there be no time at all farther on.

We are in the old way; Jane still mostly a prisoner, tho’ very considerably better, and getting on, in-doors in a contracted kind of existence, tolerably, considering. I, thanks to the Horse, feel as if I were, in some faint perceptible degree better: the riding is but uncomfortable, in such weather; mostly in the dusk too, otherwise I cannot get a days work done at all: my swift galloping &c withal has “stirred up” endless “bile,“—swollen face, gum-ache, continuance of headache (quite unusual things): but I consider, and even partly feel, all this is on the right road, and will lead to real improvement. Human speech cannot describe the inhuman state of body I have been in, more and more, for years past.— — The worst at present is, We have frost, slippery roads; and my riding is out for the last 3 days! Dangerous, these glass roads, crowded with vehicles; and nobody roughens here, seemingly (frost so “uncertain”); but waits for thaw.

For the last week I have been drawing up a “Chronological Summary” (with a Blessing on it!) for the French Rn, last vol. Happily I have now done with it,—forever and a day! Cromwell too is about ready for the Printer I have torn out a Print of his here, whh is tolerably good and of no use whither it was going. Perhaps you have some little Frame for it; or somebody you want to favour has?—

Poor Samuel Brown never wrote me anything that was worth printing.Dr. Samuel Brown had d. 20 Sept.; see 31:190JWC to TC, 23 Aug. 1856. His Lectures on the Atomic Theory, and Essays Scientific and Literary, 2 vols., were collected and pbd. posthumously (Edinburgh, 1858). Presumably Jean had sent a request from Thomas Aird, ed. of the Dumfries Herald, who had been a friend of Brown’s; see 28:14TC to JCA, 19 Jan. 1853. I believe there may be one or two old Notes of his, stowed by in some dusty corner; but really they never were or could be of any significance; nor could I find them (if they exist at all): Let the answer therefore be, “Alas, nothing!”— Poor Browne; he had something very fine in him, fine and high-aiming, and his fated course was tragical. They tried to help him by “praise” too, and favour; and did him only ill by it. Nobody can help a man!—

What a tragedy too is that of Hugh Miller! A solid stonemason soul, with a great deal of fresh manful quality and health in it; becomes “literary"; catches up “Free-Kirk,” and is caught by it; “geology” &c, and a crowd of Gomerals
huzzaing around:—till the issue is, this!Hugh Miller shot himself, 24 Dec. There was speculation that his suicide was the result of his inability to “reconcile Geology with the Bible” (Wilson, Carlyle 5:280–81), though there was no evidence to support this view. The Times, 29 Dec., reported that a post mortem had revealed a disease of the brain and that after experiencing several seizures in previous months, Miller was afraid that he was losing his mind. His obituary described him as a man of “amiable disposition,” “generous spirit,” and “humble piety,” looking like “a shepherd from the Ross-shire hills rather than an author or a man of science.” It concluded: “Literature and science have lost in him one of their brightest ornaments, and Scotland one of its greatest men.” For TC’s contact with Miller, see 29:44TC to HMI, 9 March 1854.— — I will write soon again. With kind love to all,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Jane wants worsted (dark-grey almost black) for darning my old stockings. “Too much twined, too hard” &c, all that she can yet find here;—she thinks there will be none right in Dumfries either? Tell us; or “send 1 oz."

div3.sourceNote: TC-RF, 1 Jan. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO ROBERT FARIE

docBody.p: May the worst of our years be past!Coterie speech; Irving’s toast; see 29:232TC to JAC, 6 Jan. 1855, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 157. That is in place of “Happy New-Year."

I perceive you do not send for the little NagFritz, the horse Farie helped TC buy. at all, tho’ there is far more riding in him (as I assured you) than I care for just now. In the frost, tho’ I took him out one day very successfully in spite of the slippery ways, he had got uncommonly fond of going; and anybody rather [than]Word omitted. myself to indulge his taste wd have been a welcome sight to me.

The little fellow shall stand for you on Saturday, ready to be saddled whenever you come for him to Till’s.Pearson Till, livery stables, 41 Manor St., Chelsea. I say Saturday, to give time; otherwise it may be tomorrow if you like to come soon enough:—or it may quite as well be Sunday; or indeed what day and days you like, till you get a horse of your own;—I pray you let that be understood, and stand as a thing known.
On Saturday if I hear nothing, the message to the groom at Till’s will be (that is my last word to him, of Friday Evg): “Mr Farie will ride this horse, and not I."

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: Aurelio Saffi wrote to JWC from Oxford, [31 Dec. 1856], apologizing for his “long and culpable silence. … I have been wrong very wrong. That’s all. / Still this external fact does not bear in the least on my inner feeling, does not represent it all. My heart is not changed.” JWC had been for five years “the most true and generous friend … a peculiar blessing bestowed on me by the hand of Providence.” He had broken his arm but was now better and intended to visit the 2d week of Jan.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MA [MCA], 2 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Pbd: Froude, LM 2:308–10.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY AUSTIN

docBody.p: The Box came yesterday all safe—not so much as one egg cracked! and just in time to have one of the fowls boiled for Mr C’s dinner. Mr C dines all by himself at present; I merely looking on! (as he doesnt participate in my dislike to eating in presence of one’s fellow creatures not similarly occupied.) Since my illness, that is to say pretty nearly ever since I returned from Scotland4 Oct. 1856. I have used my privilege of Invalid (and no doubt about it) to dine at the hour when nature and reason prompt me to dine, viz: 2 oclock; instead of at Mr C’s fashionable hour of six. So my go at the fowl comes off today. They look famous ones; and as for the goose!—Heaven and Earth! what a goose!— Even Ann, who is so difficult to warm up to bare satisfaction point with anything of an eatable sort, stood amazed before that goose—“as in presence of The Infinite"! And when she had found her tongue broke forth with—“Lord! Ain’t it fat Mam?“— Thank you very much dear Mary. Your Box reminds me of the time when you came to me at some dreadful Inn at Annan;Meeting untraced and inn unidentified. where I happened to be, I dont remember why; and was doing I dont remember what; except that I was horridly sick and uncomfortable—and you came tripping in with a reticule basket and gave me little cakes and sweeties out of it!—and that comforted my mind, if not exactly good for my stomach!

Dear Mary how kind you used to be in these old times when we were thrown so much on one anothers company. That is the only feature of my existence at Craig o’ puttaCraigenputtoch, where the Carlyles lived, May 1828 to Feb. 1834. For Ellen Twisleton’s account of JWC’s unhappiness there, see 30:267–74Ellen Twisleton’s Account of Life at Craigenputtoch. See also JWC to MS, 11 Jan. which I recall with pleasure—the rest of it was most dreary and uncongenial—

The meal is welcome—for I brought but little from Scotsbrig, not thinking to need more— When I dine in the middle of the day however, I can take my old supper of porridge; provided I feel up to the bother of making it myself. So I have my porridge while Mr C takes his more unsubstantial breadberryBread soaked in hot milk or water and sweetened. (I call it; Ann calls it, “Master’s pap!”)

We have beautiful weather again and I get out for a drive—in an omnibus— The Scotsbrig gig would be nicer; but anything is better than walking, when one feels like an eel in the matter of back-boneCoterie speech; see 8:211TC to JAC, 23 Sept. 1835.— I go in an omnibus from the bottom of our street to the end of its line, and just come back again; thus realizing some—fourteen miles of shaking at the modest cost of one shilling. Mr C’s horse gives him the highest satisfaction—he says it is “a quite remarkable combination of courage and sensibility"

The Secretary too would do well enough if he could only give over “sniffing thro his nose“— The Canaries are the happiest creatures in the house. The dog next! kind regards to your Husband and MargaretJames and their da.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-VL, 5 Jan. Addr: Doctors Commons. MS: NLS 23167.101. Pbd: Fielding, “Vernon Lushington” 10.
div3.head: TC TO VERNON LUSHINGTON

docBody.p: My wife wishes much, in case you have nothing better to do, that you wd come to us Tomorrow (Tuesday) Evg, to meet some 3 (or perhaps only 2) agreeable persons whom she expects. As to the agreeable persons I can say nothing; but will add on my own score that the sight of you will, as always, be pleasant to me again. Come therefore, if you can manage it.

There is no Official duty this time; Cromwell vol I is in the hands of the Printer (a good way in reserve, as I suppose), and all going well there.Lushington had been helping TC to prepare Cromwell for the cheap edn. of TC’s Works. Chapman & Hall advtd., Athenaeum, 13 and 27 Dec., that the first work pbd. of the “Cheap and Uniform Edition” would be French Revolution in two vols., vol. 1 to appear, price 6 shillings, 1 Jan. Vol. 1 of Cromwell was advtd., 7 and 13 Feb., as to be pbd., 28 Feb. From Jan., Chapman & Hall dropped the “Uniform” and referred to the edition as the “CHEAP EDITION” or the “Cheap Re-issue”; see appendix 1Athanaeum Advertisements.

ps.p: (in haste, and with the most scandalous of pens).Ellen Twisleton wrote to her sister, 5 Jan.: “Last night we tea’d with the Carlyles, all aloney poney, we by ourselves we;—& first Mrs C. sat in the chair [see JWC to EDEDW, 15 Dec. 1856] & then I did, or the other way rather; she told me to tell you that the other day Carlyle came in tired from riding, & flung himself into the armchair & put up his feet over your chair—‘I started up, & said, oh! any chair but that, & took it away, & he got up, very grumpy, & went away, & wouldn’t make himself comfortable again with any other; so I told Ann to put that chair back against the wall, so that it shouldn’t happen again & Ann said,—‘I’m sure it’s very strange of the Master to think he could put up his feet on that chair, because anybody could see it wasn’t ever meant to be used, only to look at!’ You & I shouldn’t approve at all of her taking it away from him,—but Ann’s speech I tho’t delicious. They and the Lyells are coming on Saturday” (MS: Houghton 45M-98). Sir Charles (1797–1875; ODNB) and Mary Lyell (d. 1873); see 30:203JWC’s Journal, 24 Oct. 1855.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MS, 11 Jan. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 2:29–30 inc.; The Autobiography of Mary Smith, Schoolmistress and Nonconformist (1892) 308–12; Bliss, JWC 256–58; Fielding and Sorensen 221–23 inc. Text: Smith. Mary Smith (1822–89), schoolteacher, poet, and misc. writer; see JWC to MS, 16 Jan. 1854.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY SMITH

docBody.p:
This time you come to me as an old acquaintance, whom I am glad to shake hands with again. The mere fact of your being still in the same position after so long an interval, and with such passionate inward protest as that first letter indicated,For JWC’s first letter to Smith, when she advised against a literary life, see 29:20–21JWC to MS, 16 Jan. 1854. Smith wrote: “Poetry indeed was through all the hard periods of my life, my joy and strength, the uplifter of my soul in trouble. Now it was that the very prospect of a literary career—always the cherished ideal of my soul—seemed forever blocked out of my prospects and hopes. I, who would cheerfully have gone ragged and barefoot to have had the meanest place in the temple of lofty learning, was now, by my very success as a teacher, and with my own hand, bolting the door of my own higher hopes on my soul. … [T]he prosperity of my school rather depressed than gladdened me. Urged on by these feelings … I conceived the bold idea of writing to Mrs Carlyle … telling her the state of my mind and asking her advice” (Autobiography 242). is a more authentic testimony to your worth, than if you had sent me a certificate of character signed by all the clergy and householders of Carlisle!Smith ran a boarding school, 11 West Tower St., Carlisle, from 1852: “I was seven years at 11 West Tower-street. It was a busy and somewhat eventful time. I have given a brief glimpse into my inner life, showing myself up most likely as an incomprehensible being. My object has been to show the inner cravings of my soul after literary pursuits, which, being a woman, I failed to attain, despite of all my self-denial and persistent endeavours. … I had higher visions than matrimony; literature, poetry, and religion gleamed fair before me. Had I been a young man, how gladly should I have gone into the Nonconformist ministry, and should probably have been accepted. But as a woman I had to struggle with all sorts of difficulties, hardships and insults; being in the world, but not of it, nor aspiring after any of its flimsy gewgaws. … My school increased more and more, for if I lost my best scholars, I had still new ones brought. So I worked on, little disconcerted by my difficulties, nor was my life unhappy. I had no debts. My work was my comfort” (Autobiography 192, 197, 201). So many talents are wasted, so many enthusiasms turned to smoke, so many lives blighted, for want of a little patience and endurance! for want of understanding and laying to heart that which you have so well expressed in these verses—the meaning of the Present!“The Present,” one of the poems Smith pbd. in Poems. By M. S. (1860) (printed in Preston, not pbd., as at 29:20JWC to MS, 16 Jan. 1854), which was dedicated “To Mrs. Carlyle, / Wife of Thomas Carlyle, esq., / of Chelsea, / This volume is respectfully inscribed / in / remembrance of her goodness, / and as / a tribute of esteem, / by the author.” Smith later dedicated Progress, and other Poems (1873) to TC: “[O]ne of the greatest writers, / profoundest thinkers, purest moralists / that this or any age has produced, / this volume, / with his full permission, / is inscribed, / in grateful recognition of the light and guidance derived from the pure and faithful teachings of his many / noble works, / by his faithful servant, / the author.”—for want of recognising, that it is
not the greatness or littleness of “the duty nearest hand,"See “Wilhelm Meister’s Apprenticeship,” Works 24:2, and Tarr, Sartor 145. but the spirit in which one does it, that makes one’s doing noble or mean!

I can’t think how people, who have any natural ambition, and any sense of power in them, escape going mad in a world like this, without the recognition of that! I know I was very near mad when I found it out for myself (as one has to find out for one-self everything that is to be of any real practical use to one). Shall I tell you how it came into my head? Perhaps it may be of comfort to you in similar moments of fatigue and disgust.

I had gone with my husband to live on a little estate of peat bog, that had descended to me, all the way down from John Welsh, the Covenanter, who married a daughter of John Knox.JWC’s ancestor was Elizabeth Knox’s brother-in-law David Welsh of Colliston (near Craigenputtoch); see 3:420TC to JBW, 28 Nov. 1825. TC implied that JWC’s father’s family did not inherit Craigenputtoch from John and Elizabeth Welsh when he wrote that “a better probability perhaps is the topographical one that Craigenputtock … did apparently form part of Collieston, fertile little farm still extant,” but he apparently accepted the claim that they were descended from John rather than David Welsh (Carlyle, Reminiscences 108–9). That didn’t, I am ashamed to say, make me feel Craigenputtock a whit less of a peat bog, and most dreary, untoward place to live at! In fact, it was sixteen miles distant on every side from all the conveniences of life—shops and even post office!

Further, we were very poor; and further and worst, being an only child, and brought up to “great prospects,” I was sublimely ignorant of every branch of useful knowledge, though a capital Latin scholar and a very fair mathematician!! It behoved me in these astonishing circumstances to learn—to sew! Husbands, I was shocked to find, wore their stockings into holes! and were always losing buttons! and I was expected to “look to all that!” Also, it behoved me to learn to cook! No capable servant choosing to live at “such an out of the way place,” and my husband having “bad digestion,” which complicated my difficulties dreadfully. The bread, above all, brought from Dumfries, “soured on his stomach,” (Oh, Heavens!) and it was plainly my duty as a christian wife to bake at home!

So I sent for Cobbett’s “Cottage Economy,"William Cobbett, Cottage Economy (1824); chaps. 3 and 4 are on bread making, 3 arguing that bread is a better staple food than potatoes and 4 giving step-by-step directions for bread making. and fell to work at a loaf of bread. But knowing nothing about the process of fermentation or the heat of
ovens, it came to pass that my loaf got put into the oven at the time myself ought to have put into bed, and I remained the only person not asleep, in a house in the middle of a desert! One o’clock struck, and then two, and then three; and still I was sitting there in an intense solitude, my whole body aching with weariness, my heart aching with a sense of forlornness and degradation. “That I who had been so petted at home, whose comfort had been studied by everybody in the house, who had never been required to do anything but cultivate my mind, should have to pass all those hours of the night in watching a loaf of bread! which mightn’t turn out bread after all!"

Such thoughts maddened me, till I laid down my head on the table, and sobbed aloud. It was then that somehow the idea of Benvenuto Cellini, sitting up all night watching his Pericles [Perseus]Smith prints “Pericles”; Froude, who says Smith sent him the letter, has “Perseus.” Bliss notes that it was “undoubtedly a copyist’s error; Mrs. Carlyle would never have written anything but Perseus” (257). Benvenuto Cellini (1500–1571) described casting the statue of Perseus in his Autobiography; see also 30:266GEJ to JAF, 22 Nov. 1876, and 271Ellen Twisleton’s Account of Life at Craigenputtoch. in the oven, came into my head; and suddenly I asked myself, “After all; in the sight of the upper powers, what is the mighty difference between a statue of Pericles [Perseus] and a loaf of bread, so that each be the thing one’s hand hath found to do? The man’s determined will, his energy, his patience, his resource, were the really admirable things, of which the statue of Pericles [Perseus] was the mere chance expression. If he had been a woman, living at Craigenputtock, with a dyspeptic husband, sixteen miles from a baker, and he a bad one—all these same qualities would have come out most fitly in a good loaf of bread!"

I cannot express what consolation this germ of an idea spread over my uncongenial life, during five years we lived at that savage place; where my two immediate predecessors had gone mad, and the third had taken to drink!The 3d was Mrs. William Blacklock, JWC’s immediate predecessor; see 4:226TC to AC, 3 June 1827, and 30:267Ellen Tiwsleton’s Account of Life at Craoigenputtoch.

But here am I beginning on a third little sheet and you are waiting for my opinion of the verses!Smith had apparently sent JWC several poems in addition to “The Present.” If you knew how completely I have lost all taste for poetry (so called), you would not have appealed to my judgment of all peoples! Indeed, I should need to have been a poet born, to have continued writing or reading anything in verse, in the valley of the shadow of Mr. Carlyle’s denunciations of verse! I suppose, too, as one gets old, one naturally falls back on plain prose. But since you have asked my opinion, it would be discourteous to refuse it, even on the plea of incompetence.

I have read these verses very carefully several times over, and what I feel about them is that they are full of thought and sense, and deficient in music. They give me the impression of thought put into verse by force of will, rather than from a natural taste for singing itself.

My husband once asked Monkton MilnesRichard Monckton Milnes. why he put what he had to say into rhymes, “instead of just saying it.” The answer was—“Why you see, a very little thought goes so much further in verse!” Now, it seems to me, that you do not lie under that general exigence of modern poets, driving them on expedients to make a little thought go further than its natural length. There is more thought in the verses you have sent me, than might be elaborated into a long prose essay—more thought than in several volumes of poems, lying about on drawing room tables. But it is hurt rather than shown to advantage by the versification, which is hard and stiff—in a word, unmusical.

I should hardly have trusted my own judgment in such a matter, if Mr. Carlyle had not confirmed it. I read the verses to him, having first given him my notions about them, and he said—“Well, they are just what you said. The young lady has something in her to write, but she should resolve on sticking to prose.” That from him was rather high praise, I assure you.
docBody.name: JANE W. CARLYLE.

div3.sourceNote: TC-VL, 13 Jan. Addr: Doctors Commons. MS: NLS 23167.104. Pbd: Fielding, “Vernon Lushington” 12 inc.
div3.head: TC TO VERNON LUSHINGTON

docBody.p: I got the two Cromwell volumes all right: “many thanks!” I may well say, and feel. You have saved me a great deal of time and labour; and done the business as well or better than if I had myself been in it.
I have not gone into the removal of the markers yet: but probably shall this evening; I guess it may be an hour’s work or little more.

You wish me to say “sand hills,” then, instead of “chalk hills”? That surely will be worth doing in the circumstances.— As to die meaning properly “live” (or something like it),—I still cannot make sense of the passage unless in that way: “If yr Daughter bring a son to Dick and you, you pay, at sight of that phenomenon, £2,000; at any rate in six months after the marriage, you pay £1,000, and if Dorothy have no child (or only daughters, which seems the same), you will not be asked for the other £1,000.”See Cromwell, Works 6:309, 7:2–3 and 18–19.

But all this is superfluous at present. What I had to do was to ask you to come to us (at the old hour, in the old way) on Thursday Evg,15 Jan. when there is to be a Welsh-English friend of ours making a call, who wants to know you, and whose acquaintance I think will not be disagreeable to you. He is
from Oxford originally; one Foxton;Frederic Joseph Foxton (1807?–70); see 26:29426:biographical note, and 28:162TC to JCH, 6 June 1853.—who did an extremely heterodox thing, threw away his clerical surplice and living (on account of not believing in them), but is otherwise a very social, cheery and by no means dangerous character.
We expect you, if you answer nothing.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LA], 14 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Ashton 386.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Among my own muddy tribulations I always flattered myself you were well and in a sunny element; but this also, it appears, is not so. “Discouraged,” “languor,” “gone out to ride the first time“—what am I to think of all that? Among the many fine things I have loved in you, the bright frank courage of your mind, the healthy promptitude with which you shook away annoyances, and walked on as if incompatible with “mud” (in which I may be said to dwell) was always one. Be not “discouraged”; no! There are better times coming round again; the brave true heart can (full surely) make for itself better times. If we have gone astray, on miry thorny paths,—we must return again. There is still a sky overhead, and green Earth underfoot; and this is “the Place of Hope,”Cf. 5:171TC to MAC, 10 Oct. 1830 and Tarr, Sartor 121. while we continue here!— —“New-Year’s wishes”; my poor wishes, hopes and homages, these cannot fail, while years run for me new or old.—Lady Sandwich had reported to Lady Ashburton, 27 Dec., that TC “desired all things to you” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388).

For the rest you may judge if I have been “happy,” by the one fact that this is the first time you hear from me. Ever since you went away, it is as if the windows of Heaven (or of some other place) had been opened, and nothing but deluges of shot-rubbish had been poured upon me in the dark winter weather! I will not recapitulate what his Lordship will have already told you. The truth is I am wrestling fiercely to do a piece of work set to me for which, on the given terms, I am not equal. I rather despise it too, as I go along,—“could do infinitely better work than that“:—but this I cannot do, it wd seem; and yet must do it, under nameless penalties, and will. That is the short story; capable of spreading wide enough when run into practical details!—

One of the best things in my lot is the excellent little Horse I have; on which I go daily splashing thro’ the mud,—forgetting, more or less for a
couple of hours, the spiritual welter I otherwise live in.Lord Ashburton had reported to Lady Ashburton: “Carlyle came in also upon his charger, low about himself and his work, but not looking ill” (n.d.; MS: NLS Acc. 11388). From the Norwood heights I see Addiscombe;The Ashburtons’ estate, nr. Croydon, 10 mi. S of London. Norwood Ridge is a hilly area, 1½ mi. N of Addiscombe. think how easy it were to gallop out thither, were there anything now there for me. Patience; perhaps there will again!— — My German Famulus proves but a weak animal; willing but ineffectual; the good to be got of him questionable altogether.Lady Sandwich wrote, 27 Dec.: “Mr Carlyle is half demented … by a half wild German amanuensis who worries his life out & snorts in a way which drives him wild” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388).

Of my other fellow-creatures, except as indefinite shadows in the London fog-element, I know next to nothing: pleasant they are not; and being painful, one can edge away. LoweRobert Lowe, leader writer to the Times. I have never seen, tho’ he was here once, and wanted us to Christmas, good man. I avoid sight of the Times, sound of the vile babble of the loquacious stupidities—Ach Gott.The Times’s support for the government might have irritated TC. Palmerston thanked John Delane, the ed., in Feb. for “the handsome and powerful support” from the Times (Dasent, Delane 1:249). Kingsley came in one night; and did nothing but spoil poor Froude, who is good for something to me: a blustery questionable bag of things that Kingsley, blow[n]Letter omitted. Charles Kingsley (1819–75; ODNB; see 26:29626:biographical note) and J. A. Froude were close friends. Kingsley had introduced Froude to his sister-in-law Charlotte Maria Grenfell whom Froude m., 1849. too big, for the present. The Twisletons, Petite and all, are coming tomorrow evg. Pray for me, I beg of you; and still more, get well; and come home again! God bless you, Friend of Friends.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-VL, 17 Jan. Addr: 8 College Sq. Doctors Commons. MS: NLS 23167.107. Pbd: Fielding, “Vernon Lushington” 12–13 inc.
div3.head: TC TO VERNON LUSHINGTON

docBody.p: Here is the Fethard Letter;See Cromwell, Works 9:257–58. Fethard is in Ireland, Co. Tipperary, NE of Cork. my poor German went to the Library for it,—and made what a job you may see; bringing the Postscript, and leaving the Body! However, I had bidden him bring the BookGentleman’s Magazine n.s. 19 (1843): 266; see Works 9:258. itself; so it was easily righted.
This Letter wd have better than perhaps any other merited to go into the Text, had we not forsworn that method.It was put in an appendix. Whh is a determination we will not revoke.

I think, by intense looking (at a Map of Ireland among other things) it wd be found to refer to some surprisal of a Town, no, p. 293, ’4 probably Mallow,” ‘Mayallo’ in orig.” (TC’s note, see Works 9:257).—“Mallow pasest”“By another hand there is also written on the outside ‘Mallo posest,’ meaning … Mallow possessed” (TC’s note, Works 9:258). Mallow is 22 mi. N of Cork. pointing clearly that way. I have given you all the indications I had; and (enjoining only brevity) will leave it to your beneficence.

One thing more. I think you had better hang the thing (the Footnote for it, that is) upon the Story of Fethard itself (pp. 295 vol II),—perhaps to the words “force them*”The note was attached to “Fethard,” in a letter of 15 Feb. 1649; see Works 7:137. (p. 296, l. 4) (with* ‘See Appx No—Letter of—to Col Phayr Govr of Cork,Robert Phayre or Phaire (1619?–82), regicide; gov. of Cork, 1651–54. abt sending men to help in these operations,’—or the like) But all that I leave to your own good head,—and must not spend another word on the subject. Volume to Robson,Charles Robson. please, so soon as you are satisfied with it: I wish no more acquaintance in that quarter.
A Fh Revn is waiting for you, if I had time to look after it. Do not buy at least, in the interim!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 19 Jan. MS: NLS 516.40. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Having literally “five minutes” with paper and pens about me, I will devote it to you, as better than nothing.

My dismals are a little abated again; I am getting the wheels to move again (they seemed fast,I.e., stuck fast. up to the axles in tough clabber, not long since);—I am also, I do believe, in a private way, slowly getting better in health. Nothing can exceed my regularity in riding; and I never in my life had such a little jewel of a Horse! You wd be amused to see how we make the glar go, of an afternoon; passing with ease all things and persons; pushing outwards for a glimpse of real sky and field, if possible. I get a kind of company even out of this
respectable Nag; he knows London better than I do (never saw such a creature for roads); has real sense and virtue in him,—respects his Master, as if it were the Grand Turk or a Demigod come to ride him. In short I get real benefit from the creature; and shall still more, I am persuaded.

Jane was very proud of her stockings, tho’ they were not the kind that suit,—more is my blame! She cannot do except with fine knit stockings (not woven ones):—with my advice she therefore changed yours into the right sort, at a Scotch shop here,Unidentified. and now she is stockinged by you to her mind, all the same. With thanks! My five minutes are out. Adieu, dear Sister—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Monday (in greater haste than ever: horse just here!): All well still. Jack writes me nothing. Say if there are any of anyThus in MS. Books wanting in your stock? The new ones are small print (too small for other than unfailed eyes), but otherwise good and correct volumes.

docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-ET, 21 Jan. Pbd: Hallam Tennyson, Alfred Lord Tennyson, A Memoir (1897) 1:417–18; quot: Ashton 386.
div3.head: JWC TO EMILY TENNYSON

docBody.p: You are a darling woman to have gone and written to me on the “voluntary principle” such a kind little note! You to have been at the trouble to know that I was ill! You to express regret at my illness. I feel both surprised and gratified, as if I were an obsolete word that some great Poet (Alfred Tennyson for example) had taken a notion to look up in the Dictionary.

In London, when one is sick, especially when one continues sick for three months, one falls so out of thought! it is much if even your female friend in the next street, do not weary of you and then forget you! I say female advisedly for, to give the Devil his due, I find that men hold out longer than women against the loss of one’s “powers of pleasing.”Cf. JWC’s similar view in 1845, 19:23JWC to JW, 6 Feb. 1845.

Now however I begin to be about: and have no longer the pretext of illness for straining what Mr Carlyle calls “the inestimable privilege of being as ugly and stupid and disagreeable as ever one likes!”Coterie speech; see 13:196JWC to JF, 24 July 1841. and my friends drop in more frequently and sit much longer!
The heartiest thanks for your invitation to Freshwater.Farringford House, Freshwater, Isle of Wight.

Wouldn’t I like to go and visit you if that man would leave his eternal Frederick and come along! nay wouldn’t I like to go on my own small basis,Coterie speech; cf. 8:41TC to RWE, 3 Feb. 1835, and 24:170JWC’s MAAN, 2 Aug. 1849. if only I had the nerve for it, which I have not yet! He goes nowhere, sees nobody, only for two hours a day he rides, like the wild German Hunter,Possibly a reference to Grane, Siegfried’s horse in the Niebelungenlied legend. on a horse he has bought, and which seems to like the sort of thing! Such a horse! he (not the horse) never wearies, in the intervals of Frederick, of celebrating the creature’s “good sense, courage and sensibility!” “Not once,” he says, “has the creature shown the slightest disagreement from him in any question of Intellect” (more than can be said of most living Bipeds)! I wrote to a relation in Scotland, “If this horse of Mr C.’s dies, he will certainly write its biography,” and that very day he said to me, “My dear, I wish I could find out about the genealogy of that horse of mine! and some particulars of its life! I am beginning to feel sure it is a Cockney.”
Poor Lady Ashburton has made nothing by leaving the GrangeThe Ashburtons’ home, Alresford, Hampshire, nr. Winchester. deserted this winter, she has been quite ill ever since she went to Nice.

closer.salute: May I offer my affectionate regards to your husband? And may I give yourself a kiss?

docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-VL, 22 Jan. MS: NLS 23167.110. Pbd: Fielding, “Vernon Lushington” 13 inc.
div3.head: TC TO VERNON LUSHINGTON

docBody.p:
Many thanks again to you. There cannot be a doubt but Scheme IV is the preferable one: Vol I to go as far as the end of Part IV and have the Squire Papers;William Squire’s forgeries of Cromwell letters and papers that TC still accepted as genuine; see vols. 21, 22, and 24, and Works 7:339–76. vol II to &c &c—in fact it is the same division as in the 3d Edition (whh is of 3 volumes), with the Squire added to Vol I, and something more of Appendix to vol IV.Vol. 1 of Cromwell (1857) ends with the warrant for Charles I’s execution, Jan. 1649 and the appendix of Squire papers; vol. 2 ends with part 7 on “The Little Parliament, 1651–53” and an appendix of the List of the Long Parliament and Lists of the Eastern-Association Committees; vol. 3 ends with a chap. on the “Death of the Protector” (1658), and 34 appendices containing some new letters, speeches, miscellaneous information, fragments, and the index. Vol II is too small; but we can by no plan help such
inequality somewhere; and here it falls in the middle of the file, which is better (as soldiers also know) than at either end. Not to say that every vol. ends in this way with a kind of epoch: Death of Charles I; Protectorate; Death of Oliver. In short I vote clearly that we stand by Scheme IV.

If you be within wind at all any evening, I am seldom or never so busy that I should not like to see you for a little;—failing such a bit of luck, I must make some special movement that way before long.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 25 Jan. MS: NLS 525.23. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I got your Aurora Leigh,For TC’s comments written on a copy of Barrett Browning’s poem, see TC to JCA, 12 March , and appendix 2 TC’s Comments on AL
. and more lately your little Brown-Biography,Possibly John Brown, “Dr Samuel Brown,” North British Review 26 (Feb. 1857):376–406, but more probably Some Account of Itinerating Libraries and Their Founder (Edinburgh, 1856), a short biographical account by Dr. Samuel Brown of his father, also Samuel (1779–1839); first pbd. in the United Secession Magazine (Dec. 1839), then pbd. in pamphlet form (Edinburgh, 1839). The second edn., pbd. Aug. 1856, with notes and emendations, is dedicated to Dr. Brown’s mother, Elizabeth. In the preface Dr. Brown writes: “If the more discerning reader detect … the signs of a much enfeebled mind … he is requested to understand that it has been written in the sick-room, during the intervals of a life of some suffering”; he had d. 20 Sept. 1856. all safe; a Note also whh nearly accompanied the Aurora Parcel. Jane has read that so-called “Poem,” too; but does not make very much of it:—indeed I apprehend it is doubtful whether there is any hit even of the purblind public fancy made; Aurora Leigh was a critical and popular success; the 1st edn., pbd. by Chapman & Hall, 15 Nov. 1856, was sold out within two weeks; a 2d edn. without corrections was printed in Jan. and reprinted in March. hit of the real mark to be aimed at there is clearly none, nor the dream of any. This Lady “hath a good utterance of speech”;Cf. Thomas Wilson, The Art of Rhetoric (1553) preface and folio 116:2. but as to the thing said with it, one asks, Is it a thing at all?— A sad pack of people these rhymesters of our time! For instance I have this moment received from Boston a new—Translation of Faust;Probably Faust; a Tragedy translated from the German, with notes, by Charles T. Brooks (Boston, 1856). probably the 21st I have handled in my time. I mean to send it off to Dumfries at once (the rather as it seems prettily

figure.p: Reproduced from Lawrence Shadwell, The Life of Colin Campbell, Lord Clyde (1881)
