docBody.p: printed), without reading one word of it;—no time even for the smallest answer to the ingenuous youth who sends me such a Gift.

We have pernicious weather: I never saw viler frost-mud (for such it is),—drizzles of despicable sleet, despicable but continual,—a wrestle always between ice and water above head, which makes under foot a thing you know! The Horse is under physic (precautionary, they allege!), and I have been off two days; today proving too intemperate, it was thought. Perhaps I am obscurely improving a little in health? No man can be more industrious in riding; or generally better carried in such weather. The progress of my work is so so; very far indeed from brilliant—ah me!—but I persist; if I live I shall get thro’ it.

I want you now to send me immediately the Addresses of James Cle and James AnCarlyle and Aitken. our Nephews at Glasgow; I am going to send each of them a Book. Also one to Alick’s Tom.Alexander Carlyle’s eldest son. There is a Copy lying for you also; tho’ it is too small print for eyes like ours.— I get a very considerable quantity of bother from that thing too, as it goes on. DarwinErasmus. is very poorly, not once out this long while. I yesternight saw Sterling & Genl Campbell, for a little,—
busy ‘reforming the Army’ all they can.Anthony Sterling had served under Colin Campbell in the Crimea; see 29:43 TC to JAC, 6 March 1854
. In July 1856, Campbell had agreed to accept an appointment as inspector general of the infantry (Lawrence Shadwell, The Life of Colin Campbell, Lord Clyde [1881] 1:401). Sterling accompanied him on several of his inspections. In Dec. 1856, at the request of the queen, Campbell (accompanied by Sterling) delivered the ensigns of the Order of the Bath to the prince of Prussia (Sterling to TC, 13 Jan.; Shadwell 1:402). Sterling wrote on his return from Berlin, 13 Jan.: “[O]ne day at dinner I sat next to Baron d’Usedom & in course of conversation your promised history of the great Frederic was referred to— Baron d’Usedom begged I would send you the name of a book bearing on the subject which he thought you might not have seen—and he wrote it on the back of the card herewith enclos[ed.]” The card is missing. TC wrote on the envelope: “jany 1857, Sterling, of v. Usedom.” Baron Guido von Usedom (1805–84), Prussian diplomat; see 29:230 TC to LA, 3 Jan. 1855
. On 29 Jan., Sterling sent TC a handwritten copy of a German poem, “Fredericus Rex. General Schweren. Gedichtet v. Dr. E. W. H. Haering, aus dem Balladen von Wilibald Alexis,” at the end of which TC wrote, “(From Col Sterling, 29 jany 1857).” On the back TC noted “ ‘Fredericus Rex’ (a Grenadr-Song; rather good;—by whom? when, where?) (from A. Sterling, jany 1857)” (MS: Yale). “Fredericus Rex” and “General Schwerin,” ballads by Georg Willhelm Heinrich Häring (1798–1871), pseud., Willibald Alexis, historical novelist. “Fredericus Rex” was first pbd. in his novel Cabanis (Berlin, 1832), where it is sung by Prussian grenadiers, thereby arousing the attention of Frederick the Great; presumably pbd. again in his Balladen, 1836. “Fredericus Rex” and “General Schwerin” were set to music, 1837, by Karl Loewe (1796–1869). Send the Addresses straightway, if you can!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-EC, 26 Jan. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD CHAPMAN

docBody.p: When the second volume of the Fr Revn comes out, will you please send both it and the first vol,—following that, monthly, byThus in MS. the other volumes as they come out,—to the following persons:
1o. Vernon Lushington Esq, 8. College Square / Doctors Commons
2o. John Chorley Esq, 76. Chester Square
3o. J. Neuberg Esq, 25. Oakley Villas / Adelaide Road, Haverstock Hill
4o. John Welsh Esq, (has first vol.) 19. St John’s Grove, Richmond
5o. Revd Walter Welsh, Auchtertool Fife (to go in your Edinburgh Parcel)
6. The Lady Ashburton, Bath House, Piccadilly

row.cell: 7o. The Dowager Lady Sandwich 64. Grosvenor Square.
8o. A Gilchrist Esq. 6. Cheyne Row, Chelsea.

docBody.p: 9o. Three Copies of Vol II to be sent hither this time: How many in the subsequent months, we will settle.
Besides these, I shall want 3 Copies (two of them to go to Glasgow), but I have not yet got the Addresses complete.
This I think is about 15 Copies for the present. I fear I may want several more,—but mean to keep within limits too: 10 or 12 for each 1000 of the Edition.
docBody.name: [no signature]

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 30 Jan. MS: Huntington Lib. Pbd: Larkin, BQR 34–35.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Your work, I can well perceive, is faithful, solid and judicious; in substance just what was wanted. I have not yet had time to go into it in practical detail; but so much I can see, and certify to you. Surely I owe you many thanks—for what you have done, and for what you are still doing and willing to go on doing.Larkin had volunteered to help TC with preparations for publication of his collected works; see TC to HL, 14 Dec. 1856. “While preparing the index, &c., I noted two or three little points which seemed dubious, and called attention to them by slips of paper between the leaves, on which I wrote only what was necessary, thinking it would thus be very little trouble for him to glance at the page, and then do anything or nothing as he saw fit. There was nothing of any great importance. … It was not long before I received the following very encouraging acknowledgment” (Larkin, BQR 34).

Both Summary and verbal Index will be wanted (that is now my plan) for this volume, and for the Collected Works in general. I mean that there shall be such a Summary as you have drawn up for SterlingLarkin began with Life of John Sterling (1851). (only briefer perhaps) to each volume; and then that there shall be, printed in the last volume a “General Index,“—which of course is only to be got by doing a verbal Index for each volume; so that the Printer (altering the page-nos to the new form of the volumes) may at length melt all the Indexes into one.

In this point of view I will beg you to proceed; and you shall have plenty more of work, if you like it,—no fear of that! For except the Fh Revolution (whh is to be sent you in a day or two)French Revolution was pbd. in Jan. and Cromwell whh will come next,Pbd. late Feb. to April; see appendix 1Athenaeum Advertisements. none of the volumes hitherto have either Index or Summary. Nor can my poor Clerk, whom I have tried at both businesses, do either of them in a tolerable way.

It appears clear to me the only fault of this Sterling Summary, and Sterling Index perhaps still more, will be their over-minuteness; whh surely, as you
remark, is a fault on the right side, and easy to mend. However, I shallpractically (I hope, when once some present hurries are over), and judge for myself. Meanwhile please go on with the Schiller,Life of Friedrich Schiller (1825). witht abatement of vigilance, but keeping that (probable) fault in your eye. The Summary to each volume ought not, I think, to exceed 7 or 8 pages at the outside;—how much of your Ms. that amounts to you will see when the Fh Rn comes; and you can try to conform in some measure to that condition. By the Index to the Frh Rn, you will also form some judgement about the degree of detail requisite in a Genl Index.In vol. 2 of Wilhelm Meister, vol. 16 of the cheap edn., pbd. Sept. 1858. Nothing important to be omitted, nor anything insignificant let in: that is the clear Theory;—but as to Practice, in that, as in all things, we require (as the Hindoo Algebraist says of Quadratic Equations in complex cases) “a clear judgt and the blessings of God”!The Hindu mathematician and astronomer Aryabhata (476–550?); quotation untraced, but possibly from his Aryabhatiya, in verse and a summary of mathematics as known in his time.—

So soon as you have done Schiller, do not fail to bring it, I mean yourself along with it, that we may have another meeting;—the sooner the better; and in fact so soon as you have got the Fh Rn Index examined, more especially if I have got your Sterling well looked into withal, it might be good that we met.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-EC, 31 Jan. MS: British Lib. Dexter 316. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD CHAPMAN

docBody.p: Will you, in addition to those I mentioned the other day, send a Copy of voll. 1, 2 (Fh Revn) and of the other volumes that follow, to
Henry Larkin Esq
2. St. John’s Villas
Islington
The other “three Addresses” (two of them to Glasgow) have not yet been realised: the 3 therefore must wait till your next opportunity that way; I will send the Addresses when they come.

closer.salute: In great haste / Yours always truly

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: Colin Campbell wrote, 31 Jan.: “Anthony and Myself concluded our Work at Colchester this morning— The place is famous for its oysters. I have brought you a little barrel, of which I beg your acceptance. With my Kind regards to Mrs. Carlyle.” Colchester, on the river Colne, Essex, had large military barracks. For Campbell’s inspections of the infantry, accompanied by Sterling, see TC to JAC, 25 Jan.

ps.p: E. Chapman Esq.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 2 Feb. MS: NLS 552.133. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: We are in utter despair here: “Book I”Of Frederick. is lost (undiscoverable unless you happen to have it):—in the name of all the Saints, help us to find it again! Lost utterly it cannot at all be, without miracle; but it was laid by in a certain drawer here,—then given out to you, and I think brot back by you:—and neither high nor low is there now sight to be got of it. An awful tempest in a teapot!For the loss of the MS of the first vol. of French Revolution, see 8:66–74TC to JFR, 7 March 1835. If you know or can advise in any measure, do it by Note immediately.

For the rest, I want you to come on Wedy Evening (Wednesday, day after tommorrow) at 5½ p.m., and eat a mutton chop with LewesG. H. Lewes. and me,—Lewes having volunteered. It is to be hoped the Ms. of Book I will have turned up in the interim!The MS must have been found very quickly, as there is no further mention of its loss.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 4 Feb. MS: Huntington Lib. Pbd: Larkin, BQR 35–36.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: There is not to be any “Summary” to Cromwell: alone of all the volumes those three are thought not to require one; the Story being so straight, with so good an Index, whh goes along with it. No doubt a good Summary wd be advantageous too; but it wd take trouble, and the third vol. then is already too large.Larkin had offered “to prepare a summary of Cromwell to be added to the existing index, and to be in time for the third volume. … Perhaps I was even a little urgent, for I well recollect feeling how glad I should have been to give the whole story of Cromwell such a thorough study, as the faithful preparation of a summary would necessarily involve. … I received in reply the following significant manifesto from the throne” (35).— Please, therefore, continue the Schiller with your best skill:—briefer, your one improvement. That vol. is to follow the Cromwell.Publication of Cromwell’s 3 vols. was completed late April; Lives of Friedrich Schiller and John Sterling was pbd. early June; see appendix 1Athenaeum Advertisements.

I looked over Sterling last night. There appear to be no “errors of the press,” then? I take your careful survey as guarantee of that. These are the chief things to be looked after as you read. Breaking in upon the Text,—of course it must be done if there is an absolute mistake; but otherwise I always avoid it, with a kind of shudder!Larkin wrote that he had “never allowed any bias … to prevent my summaries and indexes from giving a perfectly frank indication of the contents of the books to which they referred. Upon this point Carlyle very soon became entirely satisfied. But these were early days with us; and I suppose, for many reasons, he deemed it necessary to give me a timely caution against any tampering with the royal prerogative. … I confess I felt somewhat disconcerted at being thus sharply pulled-up. … There was really nothing in my very trivial memoranda, that could with any reason be called ‘breaking in upon the text’; but he evidently had a very real horror of anything of the kind, and he resolved to nip all that sort of irrelevancy in the bud.” Larkin assured TC that his one wish was to help him, “not to meddle or hinder in any way.” After this, he and TC understood each other better (35–36). The thing has congealed itself so; cold and hard now, burning hot as it once was: so let it lie in God’s name!— I will alter “long-clothes,” for that seems to be a real error;Larkin recalled that TC “had spoken of Sterling in his first few years as being still in ‘long clothes’; and I pointed out that this was a form of expression usually applied by mothers to the bird-of-paradise apparel, in which they adorn their infants before there is any possibility of the little feet alighting on the ground, and was hardly applicable to a boy trotting by his father’s side. I also called attention to an extract which had evidently been tucked-in after the rest was written, and which wanted some slight grammatical dovetailing. Besides this, there were two or three instances of what seemed to be imperfect punctuation” (34). In the 1st edn. of Sterling TC had written: “young John, still in long clothes” (12); it was changed to “young John still in petticoats” in later edns.; see Works 11:8. and I am glad to know it, there and for the future.

Of the Summary and Index I ought to try to shape a little bit according to my own notions of the space allowable; and I will, if time at all permit. But on the whole you would oblige me much if (after looking into the Fh Rn) you could undertake that too yourself, and compress as needful. For the Genl Index I can give no better model than the partial one attached to Cromwell.

I am very sorry I misread your “Highbury.” That must be the reason you have yet got no Copy of the Fh Rn: Chapman the Publisher was sent upon “Islington” too, and cd not shift like the Postman. This minute I write to him the right Address. If in a couple of days you hear nothing, pray call at 193. Piccadilly and speak. But that, I believe, will not now be necessary.

I am here for you any evg whatever, for an hour or so, Tea at half past 7;—you will come, at any rate, when the Schiller is done, or when you want the Sterling back, or care in any way to come. “Next week,” so far as I remember, all evenings are alike.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-head clerk, C & H [HCCH], 4 Feb. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. The head clerk was probably Mr. Warren; see TC to MRW, 22 Oct. 1852, and TC to EC, 14 Jan. 1853.
div3.head: TC TO HEAD CLERK, CHAPMAN & HALL

docBody.p: Henry Larkin Esq
2 St John’s Villas

(“Islington” it was, but it should be)
Highbury (instead of “Islington”).
Please let him have his 2 voll (and the others that follow) according to this correction.
Dr Carlyle was to call today, and give you the proper Addresses for the “Three Copies” I repeatedly mentioned.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: (Chelsea, 4 feby 1857[)]

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A [LOA], 12 Feb. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
We are infinitely obliged by your Note: it shook away a considerable mass of darkness out of us; and is the most intelligible definite word we have yet heard on that sad subject.Lady Ashburton’s illness. I got an ugly whiff of fright out of Venables’sGeorge Venables had accompanied Lady Ashburton to France in Oct.; see JWC to MR, [24 Oct. 1856]. He was present when “a famous physician [Locock], who came from London to see her, declared that her case was hopeless”; she had received the news with “cheerful courage” and had none of TC’s doubts about the accuracy of the diagnosis. Venables later visited TC and confirmed the information he had already sent; he was “surprised and interested by his refusal to believe the warnings. He burst out in a violent invective against the ill-boding physician, whom he declared to be the most incapable member of his profession.” TC took “the trouble to confirm his unfavourable judgment by a large collection of illustrative but doubtful facts. … It was touching to observe Carlyle’s determination to prove to himself rather than to me a foregone conclusion which he must have known to be unsound.” He sent Lady Ashburton a report of the conversation, “in just confidence that she would understand Carlyle’s pathetic perversity.” Lord Ashburton replied: “she was delighted with Carlyle’s new proof of affection, and that she had laughed with all her former heartiness at the form which his feelings had assumed” (George Venables, “Carlyle in Society and at Home,” Fortnightly Review n.s. 33 [1884]: 636). Letter and the other accounts, which, I know, was not without its basis and reasons alledgeable: nevertheless I have, after all the survey I can make, obstinately decided for confident hope,—with or even against Locock“Alledgeable“: thus in MS. For TC’s opinion of Charles Locock, see 23:119–20TC to JAC, 25 Sept. 1848. Ellen Twisleton wrote, 5 Feb.: “Just imagine that Lady Ashburton has sent for Locock from London to Nice, & that he went to stay 24 hours there,—for a fee of a thousand pounds! It does seem to me so simply absurd—of course all London is gossiping about it, and of course Mrs Carlyle says it is all owing to Mrs Brookfield, who, as she is going to be confined, wishes to see Dr Locock! He started on Monday. Lady Ashburton has arrived at the age which brings its disagreeables & dangers to all her ‘sect’ but why proclaim it to all London? Dr Rowse writes Lady Sandwich that Lady A. is suffering from ‘distention of the womb, accompanied by Hysteria’—do forgive me—it makes me so sick with disgust, that I charitably wish to give you the same emotions!—” (Houghton 45M-98). Dr. James Rouse. (if that
were it); for I have next to no faith in Medicine of any kind, as practised at present; and trust only to what dim intimations common sense may give one of the matter.

For one thing, I wish much my Lady and you were safe home again, with such health as there is: that clearly, so soon as the weather can permit, will be a great advantage to us all! We have Spring clearly prophecying itself now: frost and its muddy thaw all off; last monday I dated as the birthday of Spring, the skies and all earth and its winds indicating that glad fact. I was on the heights of Norwood, doing my sombre ride out there; and the universe seemed to rebuke such a mood: “Fool, art thou not still in the Place of Hope? See whether all that has not in it something of Divine!”Cf. Heroes, Works 5:54. And sure enough the Croydon Heaths, and Addiscom[b]eLetter omitted. regions generally, had a beauty, a look of kind prophecy upon them. We are to have some wild blasts of weather yet: but a few weeks, a few weeks—!—

My wife had caught new cold (as many have done);Ellen Twisleton had visited JWC, 3 Feb.; she “has caught another shocking cold to my sorrow” (5 Feb.). is still weak as water; yet visibly recovering. I have breakfasted by myself for the last four months.— Lady Sandwich too had become invisible, the last two times I called,—both last week: “a fit of cold,” Miss FarrarAnnie Farrer. reports, who is assiduous, and gains admission; “nothing more,” whh we hope will now abate in the better weather.

My writing operations are almost tragical here! No progress that is satisfact;Thus in MS. incessant slaving night and day,—for an object, in which I have now one interest, that of getting honestly done with it! Inch by inch,—if one stand doggedly to it,—the thing must diminish, must ultimateThus in MS. disappear; and go, I know not and care not whither!

Streets have grown suddenly loud and crowded; Parlt, “Collective Folly of the Nation”See “Chartism,” Works 29:122. Parliament had opened, 3 Feb. (so in sad truth it pretty much seems to me) having got together again. My rides are now like to be less solitary: other interest in the National
PalaverAnother of TC’s names for parliament. I as yet have none. Yesterday little Lord GoderichG. F. S. Robinson, Viscount Goderich. went galloping with me far and wide: a really ingenuous young man, I do hope; who has good honest sense of his own, and is almost the only serious young person of his rank that comes athwart me at all. Lord GreyHenry George Grey, 3d earl. I met twice in Rotten Row;A bridle path on the S side of Hyde Park. extremely eager for news about my Lady, and sharing with me what he had of his own.— Genl Campbell and Sterling whom I have seen just once appear to be stirring up the Military Cesspool at a diligent rate. No such “Army” ever heard of before,—except perhaps in Portugal, in Pombal’s time!Sebastião de Carvalho (1699–1782), marquis of Pombal, prime minister of Portugal, who reorganized the country’s finances and defenses. I will write to my Lady in a very short time.—Ever yours,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 13 Feb. MS: NLS 516.41. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Next time you write, be so good as send me James of Glasgow’s Address; I have got a little Book, which will go for twopence, and may be of some slight use to him,—a German kind of piece.Unidentified.

I am sorry I can do nothing for Dr Adam.Dr. Andrew Mercer Adam (22 Buccleugh St., Dumfries), Edinburgh M.D., who attended the birth of Jean Aitken’s son, Sept. 1855 (see 30:73TC to JAC, 26 Sept. 1855). He wanted to publish a piece by TC; see TC to JCA, 17 Feb. No paper that I can recollect, disjoined or disjoinable at once; and every minute is so taken up, I have neither time nor heart to go in search.

Jane has got more cold, poor soul; she is again very weak, but perhaps again in the way of recovery,Larkin described JWC during a visit he made this week: “I was especially surprised and delighted at the change in Mrs Carlyle. She had been very kind before; but with a patiently hopeless look, like a mourner standing by an unclosed grave. But all this had now passed away. All the blinds were drawn up in her house of mourning; her face was illuminated with the brightest of welcomes. I never knew any one who could deal out the flatteries so pleasantly and judiciously. I have seen it administered by the spoonful, like brimstone and treacle; and even laid on copiously, as if with a plasterer’s trowel. But she knew better. She knew the sensitive points exactly; and, if she choose, could touch them so delicately, that it almost seemed like a happy inadvertence; and she could also prick them with the deftest of needles, if she saw fit. She expressed a good deal of bantering astonishment at, what she called ‘my accurate knowledge of baby-linen’ [see TC to HL, 4 Feb.]; and was altogether cheerful and congratulatory” (Larkin, BQR 36–37).—“sleeps a little” again, which is better than not at all;
&c &c! She has had a sore imprisoned winter of it; but bears everything with much simplicity and quietness; and, I really think, has not been the unhappier for her sufferings, perhaps even otherwise.— I myself seem to feel a little better, since the Sun got visible again; there is a Spring-aspect traceable in fields and sky, which it does me good to see. My little Horse, still more, seems delighted with the dry roads and improved outlooks; willing to canter mile on mile if I would permit:—really a great help to me, this poor honest quadruped.

My “spiritual galloway,”Frederick Martin; cf. TC to JCA, 7 Dec. 1856. “weak as a teewheet,” and given to whistling thro’ his nose, as he breathes, in the cold weather,—him I have banished to the Museum, to his own House, anywhither: I could not do with him here. He is useful, too, or will be, in his kind;—and I could not well do witht some kind of servant in the prest state of matters.

Jack went away Saturday last; was to visit his Mr Hostage in Cheshire;Thomas J. B. Hostage (d. 1861), who lived in Northwich, Cheshire; see 31:131TC to IC, 21 July 1856. and ought to be arriving at Scotsbrig about now. He got handsomely rid altogether of the “Ship Phoebe” and all shipping matters whatsoever:Tom (see TC to AC, 3 Oct. 1856) and Henry Watt, two of John Carlyle’s four stepsons, were at sea. The “Ship Phoebe” is probably a reference to their mother, Phoebe Watt, rather than the name of a ship on which one of them sailed. which I heartily agreed with him in reckoning a very lucky thing. He was often here; after the first brunt of business got done: seemed well; more good to be got of him than usual.

closer.salute: Adieu, dear Sister.— My kind regards to James & every one.

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-VL, 16 Feb. Addr: 8 College Sq. Doctors Commons. MS: NLS 23167.112. Pbd: Fielding, “Vernon Lushington” 13–14 inc.
div3.head: TC TO VERNON LUSHINGTON

docBody.p:
Here has a new Cromwell Letter just fallen in: there is no end to them,—and to us they are now good for less than nothing! If you can anywhere stick it in without trouble, alter the spelling, and do so;—if it will derange your plans at all, fling it aside. There is such a thing as having enough of old Marine-Stores,I.e., a mass of unimportant papers. sent in upon one by all the blockheads of the Universe, be the pretext what it may! That History of Cromwell, as set forth in the First Edition, has got hardly any perceptible improvement by the endless cloud of bother that
has prosecuted me and it ever since. “Discloses a curious particular” &c &cApparently quoting someone who had sent TC a Cromwell letter.—and it is not curious particulars, but a correct picture of the man whh we are in quest of at all.Cf. TC’s preface to the 3d edn.: “Exposed … to the influx of new Cromwell matter from all the world, one finds it worth observing how little of the smallest real importance has come in” and “all these Appendices and Adjuncts are insignificant … the Life of Cromwell lies in the text” (Works 6:vii, viii).

I was sorry to have missed you yesterday; come some evg: I am seldom to be caught in the middle portion of the day, except by a man mounted; and then if he is a right eques [horseman], we do very well.
I know not how Robson is off. Did he get the second volume from us? I forget. He says nothing,—which is the very best utterance he cd make of himself as things go.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 17 Feb. MS: NLS 3112.257. Hitherto unpbd. Some missing letters in the text are caused by folds in the MS.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Here has your Note with the Address just come. I have packed the little book for going tomorrow; so that little matter is settled.

The good people are welcome to what they mean to print. I think it must be a piece, pretending to be by a Yankee Dr, whh I furnished to some poor lady (a Niece of [L]ady Blessington’s)Marguerite A. Power (1815?–67; ODNB), ed. of The Keepsake, 1851–57, was the niece of Marguerite, b. Power (1789–1849; ODNB; see 8:339TC to JSM, 2 May 1836), countess of Blessington, author and society hostess who lived with the Carlyles’ friend Count d’Orsay. to go into an “Annual“: I did no[t] hear of its ever being in a Newspaper;TC’s “The Opera,” supposedly by “Professor Ezechiel Peasemeal, a distinguished American friend of mine,” had been sent to Marguerite A. Power sometime in 1850, but had been kept over for publication in The Keepsake for Christmas 1851 (dated 1852) 86–92; see 25:121–22TC to BWP, 19 July 1850 and Works 29:397–403. But part of it, from “Of the Haymarket Opera” to “dwelling place of everlasting despair” (i.e., about half) was first pbd. in The Musical World 29 (29 Nov. 1851):753–54, under the heading “Carlyle at Her Majesty’s Theatre”; this extract was followed by the comment: “What will the readers of the ‘Keepsake,’ and the old improper-females (of quality), say to it?—Keepsake for 1852.” The complete “The Opera” was rptd. in The Dumfries Album, ed. A. Mercer Adam, M.D. (Dumfries and Maxwelltown Mechanics’ Inst., 1857): 134–40 (see Tarr 406). The Dumfries Courier pbd. a notice of it, 2 June: “Carlyle’s ‘The Opera’ is characteristic in style and thought: the world must be somewhat better than it appears to this cynical philosopher, otherwise it would soon cease to spin: the opera is, it appears, a prostitution of the glorious art of music, and yet those who attend are blamed for not paying attention to either the opera or the ballet. We have understood that the opera was one of the chief charms of London social life, when English stiffness was somewhat thawed, the distinction of position modified, while at the same time all the finest passages of music were appreciated and enjoyed. But, according to Carlyle, whatever is is wrong: we wonder what he would have thought of the Bazaar of the Dumfries and Maxwelltown Mechanics Institute had he looked in at the George Street Assembly Rooms for an hour—would he have deemed it a ‘pious adventure’?”—in the Annual I believe it was correctly printed:
if your people have nothing but the Newspaper to go upon, it will nearly to a certainty be incorrect. They should make an exertion to get the Annual;—I quite forget its name, but of course the Newspaper will tell.— If they absolutely cannot get the Annual, their next-best plan will be to send me a Proofsheet; which they shall get back with the smallest possible interval.— Enough as to that also.

Jane is slightly if at all better; has a heavy frequent (but not deep or dangerous-sounding) cough; can[n]otLetter omitted by TC. attain to any moderate capability of sleeping;—in short is very weak and feckless, tho’ not feverish or so miserable as you might fancy. I constantly hope she will rally soon now that the weather is changed for the better.

This ha[s] been a sad day with me,—work altogether spilt and gone to nothing: a day as if it had not been! I was in very bad fettle at starting; got into deeper and deeper confusion;—finally took to horse, and rode away from it all, (by poor Jane’s advice) into the mild spring Day taking the shortest & quietest road into Country region. After dinner and return, being very weary, I fell asleep; tea once done, I set out again, on foot, a considerable round of walking;—and here I am, innocent of work for one day, and mournfully hoping tomorrow may be a little more propitious.

closer.salute: Good night dear Sister; I seal this up tonight, and it goes off with the Glasgow Book tomorrow

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-VL, [20 Feb.]. Addr: 8 College Sq. Doctors Commons. PM: 21 Feb. 1857. MS:NLS 23167.115. Pbd: Fielding, “Vernon Lushington” 14 inc.
div3.head: TC TO VERNON LUSHINGTON

docBody.p: Come tomorrow evening, I shall be here.

The “Mall” cannot be Wharton’s Mary:“Mall” is Mary Cromwell (1636–1712), Oliver’s da.; see Works 7:324–25. Philip Wharton (1613–96), 4th Baron Wharton; see Works 6:359–60, 7:106–7. my man has brought evidence that
she is only 3 years old at that date!— Bring the Letter itself with you,For the new Cromwell letter, see TC to VL, 16 Feb. and let us have a guess.

I have just ended your Third volume; which I find done in the old excellently faithful and intelligent manner: I have made something of almost all your suggestions,—studying withal to be brief, and to keep down the number of Notes.
The volume goes to Robson tomorrow morning. Many thanks, many thanks.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LA], 23 Feb. NLS: MS Acc. 11388. Quot: Ashton 387.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Dear Lady,—My heart is dark about you and very sad. I cannot with the least certainty know how you are,—who can? I keep asserting to myself that there is not the least evidence conclusive to me of real danger: but it is too clear that you are in great suffering; oppressed probably with languors and sad dark thoughts and disquietudes: the beautiful bit of sunshine whither I always looked, this too is now sorrowfully gone into eclipse for the time. Alas, if prayers could avail, there are who would be diligent that way. But prayers cannot: what can we do? Silently continually go on with them, all the same.

My own private notion is, you probably got a great deal of mischief by your immense railway journeying. My own share of it, I know, hung palpably about me for weeks after; and it was but a poor tithe of yours. A great comfort to me always, too, is Rous.James Rouse. Rous does not want for head; and he must know the phenomenon, however he interpret it, at least 1000 times as well as Locock issuing from his express-train for one moment! I perceive, also, all Rous’s interests are very peremptory in their admonition to him, Not to err on that side, of all sides. Rous’s persistence is a strong fact to me. On the whole I do not allow myself the least wavering of Hope. I think all would be much better, moreover, if you were here, under the fit power of sun; if we saw you with our eyes again!— Lord A., for whose two Notes, the last of them this morning, I am very thankful,—never gives the least hint on this point. From whh I infer that there is nothing yet in the least speakably decided about it.

We have got Spring back here; a better february at last than is usual. The sight of the young skies, of the dry fields, ‘country people digging their gardens,’ with the poor birds singing round (I have heard thrushes in the
Regent’s ParkThe largest London park, about 2½ mi. N of Chelsea, designed by John Nash (1752–1835). even),—gives me a strange sombre joy. The eternal Opulence there is in this Universe, the silent prophecy written on Earth and Sky again, That this is “the Place of Hope,” touches my hard and stony heart, not to tears (these I think I shall never shed again) but to moods that are much better than my usual grim ones. The Spring is beautiful again; but the eyes that once saw it with me, where are they? One’s own eyes get old, even they are not the same!— Yesterday (it was a bright sunday afternoon, and I had been working to the edge of disgust in my Historical Quagmires) I rode out all round by Finchley, Hampstead &c,Both in N London. thro’ half a million of sundry fellow-creatures:—and was really thankful to my poor Horse, and the old Antediluvian Gentn that had conquered him for me out of the wild woods. If I had a Cow to feed me, as I have a Horse to carry, I should at least say, “Here are two friends!” The Cow, so far as my experience goes, is definable emphatically as the Friend of Man; and the French Cook as his Enemy. About the Horse and its qualities there can be no dissentience.

An old Scotchman whom I found here writing, “up from Edinburgh,“—the Head School-Inspector there,John Gordon (1797–1882; see 12:129TC to TA, 1 May 1840, and 16:176TC to JADO, 20 May 1843), inspector of schools; TC’s old friend. told me “It had been expected that Lord Ashburton was to be the new President of Council: and now Who was Lord Cowper?”Gordon apparently confused Francis Thomas de Grey Cowper (1834–1905; ODNB), 7th Earl Cowper, 1856, and grandson of Lady Palmerston, with William Francis Cowper (1811–88; ODNB), vice president of the newly created Committee of Council on Education, Feb. 1857–58.— Alas, alas!
We are in a very weak way here. My poor Wife is still prisoner,—getting slowly better, I persuade myself:—she has been a model of patience all winter; that is one alleviation of the case.

Four or five days ago, Lady Sandwich when I called had bid them admit me. There sat the good “Mamma” (Lady Sh the YoungerMary Montagu, b. Paget (1812–59), countess of Sandwich, m., 1838, John William Montagu (1811–84), 7th earl of Sandwich, Lady Ashburton’s brother. along with her, who soon went): I staid a while talking; there is nothing the matter but what you understand: good weather, and the sight of you especially, wd put all to rights. You do well to write often,— constantly.Lady Sandwich wrote often to Lady Ashburton at this time. On 2 Jan., she wrote: “I am stunn’d by your letter today my dearest dearest Harriet— I had no conception you had been so ill and can’t contemplate your serious illness—away suffering you had been I knew but that is wide of thinking you would never see your home again do not write yourself my child but pray I entreat of you to make Rouse send me a bulletin … I am convinced the hills are not healthy. … I am no Philosopher, but none of the people of the country ever lived in the heights in winter—& there must have been a reason for it. I don’t know the position of your Villa which must have been built since I was at Nice, I shall be glad to hear of you being at Mentone or Cannes.” In other, undated, letters, she wrote: “Mr Carlyle has been in a great state of anxiety about you—he comes very often to see me and yesterday brought me the 1st Vol. [French Revolution] published of the new edition of his works,” and “you are my first thought of a morning—& the last at night”; on 12 March: “The accounts of you are cheering—but—I shall not be at ease till I hear of you at Paris—it is a long & dreary journey—you go by sea I suppose to Marseille. The land journey would be too dreadful” (NLS Acc. 11388). Her anxieties on that head are incessant,
are those of a Mother.— — My life otherwise is solitary to a pitch: LatrappeFounding place of the silent Cistercian monastic order. hardly more so. Work gets slowly, slowly forward; wd stop altogether if one did not incessantly tug at it. One evening flitting about like a bat in the Hyde Park courses I came upon Delaine, a do just entering Rotten Row. His talk, his inquiries for you, &c &c were not so bad:—and yet, alas, is not Snobissimus the name of him?Delane’s diary at the time suggests his growing social influence; in an entry dated 11 Feb., he notes: “Dined with Sir Fitzroy Kelly, Lord and Lady Lyndhurst, Lord and Lady Salisbury, the Bishop of Exeter, Lord Stanley, General Storks, and others.” On 15 Feb., he “dined at Lionel Rothschild’s” and in early March attended “the Rothschild wedding at Gunnersbury. A very splendid affair indeed” (Dasent, Delane 1:252). The wedding was of Rothschild’s da. Leonora (d. 1911) to her cousin Baron Alphonse de Rothschild (b. 1827). Sir Fitzroy Kelly (1796–1880; ODNB); for Lord and Lady Lyndhurst, see 27:384JWC to KS, 29 Dec. 1852; James Brownlow W. Cecil (1791–1868), 2d marquess of Salisbury, m. Frances Mary, b. Gascoyne; Henry Phillpotts (1778–1869), bishop of Exeter; Edward John Stanley; Sir Henry Knight Storks (1811–74; ODNB); Lionel Nathan de Rothschild (1808–79; ODNB). Palmerston also consulted Delane privately on the choice of a speaker in the new Parliament, and asked him to give help informally in judging the candidates’ suitability for the office (Dasent, Delane 1:251). Heaven keep you, bring you back to us soon. Oh dear, Oh dear!—
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-RMM, 3 March. Addr: 16. Upper Brook Street. MS: Trinity. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO RICHARD MONCKTON MILNES

docBody.p: I wish you would come and ride with me some day; there is little other chance for me of seeing you at present. I called the other day to try if I could persuade you to such a thing; but found nobody.

I go out almost daily (very quiet neighbourly horse, and what rate of speed
you like) at 3½ p.m.—but will shift the hour (especially farther on), will come to Ur Brook Street &c, if you insist on that method. Come, if you can!
Vita brevis, ars longaLife is short, art is long; Hippocrates, Aphorisms i.1.—Ah me!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 5 March. MS: NLS 516.42. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: However hurried, I ought to write you a word to quiet your anxieties whh I see you are beginning to entertain about our poor Patient here. She is really very weakly, and suffers and has suffered a great deal,—coughing (frequent and irritative tho’ not deep), want of sleep (always more or less, sometimes total), then want of strength, of appetite, and all manner of wants. She has really had a very sickly winter, and is weak and thin as you can suppose: but I have never been in serious alarm about her either, nor has she ever been,—we trust always with confidence in “the good weather,” if it would but come. The other night (just about the time you wrote) she did thoroughly frighten Miss Jewsbury and the Maid,—even I myself, more used to such phenomena, was not without qualms, so violent was the affair: a violent 3 or 4 hours of incessant retching (without anything brought up), with spasms, nausea, and frightful pain;—right glad we all were to see that terminate, and some sleep follow, about 2 in the morning!Ellen Twisleton wrote, 4 March: “Saturday morning I went up to see Mrs Carlyle—was met by Miss Jewsbury at the door, nearly crying, who described Mrs C’s condition as so desperate, that if I had not got to the bottom of Miss Jewsbury, I believe I should have been frightened out of going up,—however, up I went, & it ended by my taking her out for a sunny hour’s drive in the Park;—but she is very poorly, & much run down” (Houghton 45M-98). I hoped and tried to believe, all the while, it might be some salutary clearing of the liver, and a crisis to the disorder: she is accordingly perceptibly better ever since; and I am again flattering myself we see land: but there is no counting in such cases! I have spoken to her more than once about sending for a Doctor; but she always pushes that away: and indeed it is too true I do not know any person here whose advice I could reckon certainly to be worth one doit in regard to such a case. So we keep hoping, and doing a very little plain medicine, on our own score. This is a true statement of the matter; about whh you need not alarm yourself: let us trust that before long I may be able to send you some better report.

For my own share I reckon myself to be obscurely yet perceptibly improved from what I was. No man can ride more diligently and regularly 2½ or
3 hours every day (today I had a beautiful solitary canter in Richmond Park,—6 miles awaySW of Chelsea and S of the Thames.); I am perfectly quiet too, my whole industry (which alas is not great!) is directed on the horrible Job I have (by far the hatefullest and most disgustingly fashous contemptible and difficult I ever was in): it goes on slower than snails; but I do drive it, and will inch by inch end it if I live!— No more at present. The weather is dry, cool, sometimes pleasantly sunny. All the world is in great tift abt change of ministry, and Dissolution of Parlt that there is to be:The earl of Derby (1799–1869; ODNB), in the House of Lords, 24 Feb., and Richard Cobden (1804–65; ODNB), in the Commons, 26 Feb., had moved a motion of censure against the govt. on the grounds that the bombardment of Canton, carried out on the orders of Sir John Bowring (1792–18711872; ODNB), gov. of Hong Kong, was unjustified. The attack on Canton, 27 Oct. 1856, was in retaliation for the boarding of the lorcha, Arrow, and the arrest of its crew by Chinese officials, because some of the crew were pirates. The Arrow was not a British ship; though it had a British capt. and was flying the British flag, its registration had expired eight days earlier. Cobden argued that the British action was wholly illegal (Hansard 144:1398–1400). Palmerston accused him of being “anti-English” (Hansard 144:1812). In the Commons vote, 3 March, the govt. was narrowly defeated. Palmerston publicly supported Bowring and asked the queen to dissolve parliament. The Times, 5 March, pbd. an article from La Verité that said the British parliament had relegated “the affairs of the country and the interest of the community … to second rank in order to give place to the play of personal vanity and ambition” and that Parliament was “a sad spectacle … speechifying preferred to business and the country sacrificed to petty, personal ambition.” I cannot pretend to care one farthing about any such matter. Fraser is gone by Scotsbrig.Fraser’s Magazine to James and Isabella Carlyle. God bless you and yours dear Sister—T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-RMM, 6 March. Addr: 16 Upper Brook Street / Grosvenor Square. MS: Trinity. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO RICHARD MONCKTON MILNES

docBody.p: We shall be at home on Sunday Evg;8 March. and I hope (without any great apprehension to the contrary) there will nobody else come. Tea is at 7½ p.m. by rule; but there will be a cup for the Hon. MemberMilnes was M.P. for Pontefract, Yorkshire, 1837–62. whenever he arrives.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LA], 9 March. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Dear Lady,—You are still far away from us; involved in clouds and uncertainties; nothing left for us amid the wide contradictory confusions but our own power of maintaining obstinate hope! I never before felt so sorrowfully the helplessness of human speech; the impossibility of gathering from these thick-coming rumours, whh vary every day, what one is to think of a Fact unknown, and so terribly interesting to one. The contemptible babble that human creatures utter is hard to bear in such a case. I take the resource of shutting my ears to it; I think with myself, You know nothing of it, your good prognosis or your evil, please do not trouble me with it!— On the whole all prophecies and accounts had assumed a favourable aspect of late: Venables called and comforted me much by his candid rational serious and hopeful account, whh brought many matters clear before. Lord A.’s Notes too pray thank for them as they merit from me. The very tone of his voice is audible in them; and I can read many things by serious inspection of a line or two so true from the source as these are.— We hear you are for moving homeward, “to Paris in April” if strength allow:—God send you here at your own house again, among your own friends again, that one might see you with eyes! The Spring is coming forward rapidly; fields already greenish in tinge, and trees themselves looking vernal against the clear skies. I often see Addiscombe region from the distance: poor House and Gardens and all things there putting-on their best I doubt not; and beautiful as the world could shew,—but alas the Lady, light of them all, is not there. Sometimes in articulate moments one’s thoughts are very poignant; but oftenest I am sunk into a gloomy frozen state whh does not articulate itself at all, and is only more sad on that account. For the last year or two, especially in late months, I find myself grown strangely old—rapidly becoming senex [old] and in fact become so, amid these chaotic waters of bitterness.

My Wife is still very poorly,—has begun in the last few days to go driving out, if the sun and temperature favour; therefore may be judged to be again in the way of recovery: but she has four months of sad leeway to make up. She is & has been very quiet and patient, with her sleeplessness, her coughings &c &c; which is the kindliest feature of her illness to me. Many people come to her in the forenoons (that is, more than enough, tho’ at the maximum perhaps 3 or 2) when she is able to see people: I myself sit aloft here; see nobody—but the ever-present face and doings of the Anarch Old.Chaos, see Milton, Paradise Lost 2:988 and Works 3:113. My labour disgusts me to the heart, and the result itself is unspeakably contemptible to
me;—no motive, only a dogged temper, to persevere. I had to send off my German galloway,Frederick Martin.— “Peesweep“ (Scottice for Pee-wit) is now the definition I give myself of him; his intellect, assiduity, futility and general behaviour, some what resembling those of that ominous Bird.“Peesweep,” “peewit,” and “teewheet” (see TC to JCA, 13 Feb.) are all Scots names for “lapwing.” John Leyden, in the glossary to his edn. of the anon. Complaynt of Scotland (Edinburgh, 1801), notes: “In the south and west of Scotland, it is much detested, though not reckoned ominous.” But he implied that an ominous reputation came from its “haunts [being] frequently intruded upon by the fugitive Presbyterians, during the persecution which they suffered in the disgraceful and tyrannical reigns of Charles II. and James VII, when they were often discovered by the clamours of the lapwing” (378). Leyden refers to the Covenanters, who objected to the imposition of Episcopalianism as the established religion of Scotland by Charles II; see 19:67TC to DL, 5 May 1845. He took to whistling thro’ his nose as he breathed here in the cold weather: so I had to send him home for a working-place; calls here twice a day,—and I cannot well pay him off (poor devil, so willing is he, and so resourceless) or I almost would. Friedh was to be written with a Peesweep (“ki-bitz” they call it in German), and nothing better to help one forward; that also was in the fates!—

We are all fallen to daggers-drawn in the parliamentary regions, as you see; an “election” to be held straightway,—and such a torrent of balderdash and worse poured out over the world as is painful to think of. People seem to prophecy that Palmn will get a Parlt more amenable to him,Palmerston had called a general election rather than resign because he rightly sensed that he had the support of the country, if not parliament, in defending Sir John Bowring. At the election, 31 March, he gained a majority of 85 seats, the largest majority for 26 years. Cobden (see TC to JCA, 5 March) had been M.P. for the West Riding, Yorkshire, 1847–57; as the W Riding voters disliked his policies on education and the Crimean War, he decided to stand for Huddersfield, hoping people there might be less antagonistic toward him; he lost, with 590 votes to 823. Although Palmerston won the election, many powerful people had misgivings about the action in China and the govt.’s response (see TC to JCA, 5 March). Lord Elgin, who was sent out to continue the war, wrote in his diary: “I have hardly alluded in my ultimatum to that wretched question of the ‘Arrow,’ which is a scandal to us, and is so considered, I have reason to know, by all except the few who are personally compromised” (Letters and Journals of James, Eighth Earl of Elgin, ed. Theodore Walrond [1872] 209). James Bruce (1811–63; ODNB), 8th earl of Elgin. Lady Sandwich wrote to Lady Ashburton: “There are so many people now in London who know every thing going on so much better than I do that I don’t pretend to send you news. Sandwich [her son] & I fought yesterday morning about Palm & China—have they told you the Registry of the Lorcha was expired 8 days … when the Chinese invaded her” (n.d.; MS: NLS Acc. 11388). John William Montagu, 7th earl of Sandwich. and in itself a shade worse than any we have yet had.— I cannot say I take any perceptible interest in it. Me there are plenty of other things to interest!—

Ought I to go at all upon this Commission for the Natl Portrait Gallery; or wd it be right to stay entirely away? If you were here I would ask; but alas,
alas!— — Work at it I neither will nor can as matters stand with me; nay there was nobody ever asked my consent, or ever spoke of the matter to me; and I know not whence the thrice-profitable bit of promotion (my first in this world) can have come.TC had presented Lord Ashburton in 1853 with a detailed proposal for a national portrait gallery; see 28:264TC to RWE, 9 Sept. 1853. On 4 March 1856 the earl of Stanhope moved in the House of Lords that an address be presented to the queen for the establishment of “a Gallery of the Portraits of the most eminent Persons in British History” (see 31:42TC to JRU, 5 March 1856). In his speech, Lord Stanhope quoted from TC’s “Project of a National Exhibition of Scottish Portraits” (see Works 29:404–13 and CL 29:75–90TC to DL, 2 May 1854). His motion was unanimously supported, and the Commons passed the financial resolution 6 June 1856, giving £2,000 for a British historical portrait gallery (Hansard 142:1124). A board of 13 trustees was appointed 2 Dec. 1856, and its first meeting was held 9 Feb. One of the original trustees, Lord Ellesmere, d. 18 Feb., and at its meeting, 28 Feb., TC was appointed in his place (see Athenaeum, 7 March), apparently without his knowledge; see also Catalogue of the National Portrait Gallery, 1856–1947 (1949) ix–x, xiii–xiv. Sorrow on it for the present; it is it that takes me away from you at this moment. I intend writing again within a week. Oh my Friend, my Lady. But I will not yield; nor shall you, Brave One!—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AH, 10 March. MS: NLS 3823.212. Pbd: Correspondence of Sir Arthur Helps, ed. E. A. Helps (1917) 191.
div3.head: TC TO ARTHUR HELPS

docBody.p:
I heartily congratulate you on getting so massive a new Piece of the Sysiphus Rock rolled up, and fairly laid at rest on the top of the hill!In Greek mythology, Sisyphus was punished in Hades by having to roll a boulder up a hill repeatedly, only to have it roll down again as soon as he reached the summit. Vol. 3 of Helps’s The Spanish Conquest in America and Its Relation to the History of Slavery and to the Government of Colonies (1855–61), 4 vols., covers the period from the conquest of Mexico in 1521 to the execution of the last independent Inca ruler, Atahuallpa, 1533. Harshly critical of slavery in general, he especially condemned the Spanish for building palaces at Madrid and Toledo with money earned from “duties on the importation of the negroes. … [T]hese two palaces must be allowed to enjoy a remarkable preeminence as monuments of folly and oppression. Other buildings have been erected solely at the cost of the suffering subjects of great despots, or by prisoners captured in war. But the blood-cemented walls of the Alcazar of Madrid might boast of being raised upon a complication of human suffering hitherto unparalleled in the annals of mankind. The Indians had first to be removed by every kind of cruelty … , and the Africans had to endure bloody wars in their own country before a sufficient number of them could be captured to meet the increasing demand for negro slaves. Each ducat spent upon these palaces was, at moderate computation, freighted with ten human lives” (Spanish Conquest [1856] 3:215–16). For TC’s response to the page proofs of vol. 1, see 29:313–14TC to AH, 17 May 1855, and 322–23TC to AH, 2 June 1855. I will read your new volume; and I have no doubt it will be with the old pleasure: but
that, or all men’s reading and applauding, or not reading and even hissing, is (if I may judge by my own sad feelings) a small matter in comparison with the above most important fact,—which is indisputable to critics.

Oh Heavens, yes certainly if I ever live across this horrid vortex of the jingling infinitude of Prussian sand and marine-stores (which fact seems often problematic to me), I do certainly intend to recreate myself at Vernon Hill:Helps’s home in Hampshire, which TC had visited with Emerson, July 1848; see 23:61TC to MAC, 6 July 1848. but all that is yet—God knows how far!

closer.salute: Pity me, pray for me; and accept many thanks, congratulations good auguries, and old and new regards.

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Mr. W [MRW], 10 March. MS: Berg. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO MR. WARREN

p.salute: To Mr Warren (Mssr. Chapman & Hall) / 193. Piccadilly.

docBody.p: 1o To give the Bearer another Copy of this vol i of Fh Rn instead of the one now sent.

2o To add to this one, vol ii & the vol i of Cromwell; make a Parcel of them (rather firm), and address: “Charles Butler Esq / 12. Wall Street / New York,” with, “London 11 March / T. Carlyle” on the corner;Butler had looked after TC’s Illinois bonds; see 28:314TC to JCA, 18 Nov. 1853, and 31:24831:biographical note.—then to cover this Parcel, and address, “Wm CrippsUnidentified. “Esq (&c as you find in that adjoined Note) “Nottingham”; pay and despatch immediately by post.— Read the Note / [t.o.]I.e., “turn over”; written at bottom of page. / and you will understand.

4oTC omits “3o.” To send all the following volumes, as they come out, addressed &c (in two covers) in the same way. If you have any gratis conveyance to Nottingham, were it even irregular, of course prefer that. But if not, the post.— I depend on your perfect punctuality and will say no more.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Chelsea, 10 March 1857“1857” added to MS in another hand.
By Mr Martin (my Amanuensis) tomorrow morning.

div3.sourceNote: TC-[WH?] 12 March. MS: London Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Possibly to William Hanna (1808–1882; ODNB; see TC to WH, 22 Nov. 1847, and TC to WH, 17 Dec. 1849), theological writer, who had previously sent TC his Memoirs of Thomas Chalmers (1780–1847); see TC to WH, 7 June 1852. MS bequeathed to the London Lib. by John E. Hodgson.
div3.head: TC TO [WILLIAM HANNA?]

docBody.p: I am still here as in old times; and glad to have some notice of you again. Of course I shall be gratified by the gift of your Book,Possibly one of the vols. pbd. in 1856 of Select Works of Thomas Chalmers, 12 vols., ed. Rev. William Hanna (Edinburgh, 1854–79), or Victor Strauss, Religion in Earnest: Tales Illustrative of Christian Life in Germany (Edinburgh, 1857) trans. Mrs. S. Carr, with a prefatory notice by W. Hanna. and hope to examine it duly by and by if you grant me the opportunity,—tho’ at present I am sunk miserably, beyond plummet’s sounding,Tempest 5.1. in pursuits far alien to the one you indicate. A time of leisure must come by and by; and we hope it will; for otherwise worse will!

closer.salute: If Mr Grant is still with you,Possibly James Grant (1802–79; ODNB; see 18:219TC to CR, 21 Sept. 1844), ed. of Morning Advertiser. pray give him my kind regards and remembrances,—which are now of old date, and have never suffered any interruption;—the same to Mrs H.Anne Hanna, b. Chalmers (1813–91; see 22:166TC to WH, 22 Nov. 1847), m. 1836. and your good old Father if he is still thereSamuel Hanna (1772?1771–1852; ODNB). and remembers me at all.

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 12 March. MS: NLS 516.43. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Dear Sister,—Lest I be disappointed today as I was yesterday, I will begin this day by writing the poor word you affectionately request.

Jane is certainly not worse; I think her decidedly better ever since that bad fit which happened before my last writing,—and indeed she herself cautiously admits as much. She sleeps perceptibly better,—never one night absolutely without sleep;—has a better appetite too (which indeed it was easy to have):—in short I am again in hopes we have got over the hill; and that with the good weather in our favour, all will come right again before very long. She
goes out every good day,—not a walk yet, but a drive; either somebody taking her, or in a hired cab of her own, with Nero for company: poor little thing she has had a sad four months of it, & they are not alone in our chronology.

As for myself I am sunk deep in wretchedness (owing to my impossible job &c &c), but feel withal as if any bodily health were mending: that is in fact nine-tenths of the battle too. Courage, courage!—

Aurora Leigh will evidently never be asked for again: keep it therefore with my blessing.This may well be the copy that Ruskin had lent TC; Woolner reported that TC “spoke with profound contempt of Ruskin because the little Art Deity called ‘Aurora Leigh’ the finest poem by far of the present age and gave him a copy to read” (see Wilson 5:297). It may also be on this same copy that TC wrote his comments and then noted, 3 Feb.: “to be returned (by and by), not being properly mine” (see appendix 2TC’s Comments on AL). Adieu again. Ever your affectionate
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [mid-March]. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:132–35 inc., where dated “March, 1857.” Ellipses are in the source. Dated by Anne’s cut to her finger which took place before JWC to MR, [24 or 31 March], when she was “quite recovered.” [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 15 March 1857.]
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
My dearest Mary— … If only you could get back your sleep, Darling! It is dreadful when sorrowFrom the death of her father, Rev. Edward Dobbie, 22 Feb. cannot have the relief which nature has appointed it in sleep, in forgetfulness, but must be endured by night as well as by day! and every sad image that presents itself is thrown out in such gigantic relief on the darkness, and made so haggard by bodily weariness! … There is nothing I feel so much sympathy with as sleeplessness; for there is nothing I have suffered so much from myself. However kindly disposed one may be, it needs always that one should understand another’s trouble before one can rightly sympathise with it. My comfort about you is, that your Husband, besides being a kind Husband, is a skilful Doctor; and whatever can be done to overcome your wakefulness will assuredly be done. Do you know he has helped me to get better sleep, by what he said when I was at Thornhill, about the injuriousness of Morphia, and such things. … I have also abstained from something else Dr. Russell did not prohibit, nay rather by example inculcated; I take no tea,—only what they call in Scotland “content“—not even that quite, for I take milk and water without sugar. For the rest, I am decidedly recovering now. And even while your mind must needs be full of your own sad loss, I know you are unselfish enough and love me enough to be interested in what I write of myself, and glad that it is so favourable. I have been
out four times in a carriage; and I feel stronger body and mind. The cough is not gone yet but there is no pain connected with it now; and it will need warmer weather to break the habit of coughing. I was beginning to think with Dr. Russell that I had taken a too serious responsibility on myself in doctoring myself thro’ this last illness; but now I am glad, for any of these slapdash medical eminences who had seen me a few weeks ago not knowing how many of the same sort of seizures I have weathered, would for certain have ordered me to Madeira, or the south of Italy,—to the complete upsetting of one’s domestic convenience, and the progress of Frederick the Great! It is seventeen years now, since a Doctor Morrah,James Morrah. who attended me here, in such another illness, told me I “should never live through another Winter in England!!” He was a man of high reputation, whom I shouldn’t have disliked having again, but he died soon after. Well, I resolved when the next Winter came, to stay and take my chance! and I have lived 19 Winters in England; and ten of them I have walked about in the coldest frosts, at the rate of six or ten miles a day! To be sure the Pitcher goes often to the well and gets broken at last.Proverbial. This time again, however, the poor little brittle Pitcher will come back from the well whole, I think; or with only a little crack in it. And cracked things often hold as long as whole things,—one takes so much better care of them.

The last two or three days, I have been more anxious about my maid than about myself; she has excellent health; has not been an hour unable for her work since she came to us three and a half years ago! But the other day she cut her finger severely; did not come to tell me, but fussed on with it herself; and it bled half a pint, and was badly wrapped up; and kept her awake all the night after, with the pain of it. To which I impute the billious attack she had the next day. She is going about again now quite well, only a little weak; but for three days I had two strangers,—that is to say, new hands in the house (I have one of them still), to fill her one place—and so inadequately! And I had to wait on her myself, instead of being waited on.

I must tell you an instance of Ann’s gentility: it was in shaving a bath-brickAn unbaked brick used for scouring and polishing metals. that she cut her finger. To-day when she opened the door to the Lady Alice HillAlice Maria (1842–1928). (a lovely girl whom Ann respects very much as the Daughter of a real live Marchioness),Caroline Frances, marchioness of Downshire. Lady Alice, who is the most bewitching little monkey in the world, said, “Oh Ann, what ails your hand?” “I have cut it, my Lady.” “How did you cut it?” “Well, I did it in cutting up a—fowl!!” She told me this substitution herself. “You know Ma’am,” said she, in telling of Lady Alice’s
kind enquiries, “I couldn’t go and say to a real young Lady that I did it cutting a bath-brick! that sounded so common! I thought a fowl was more the thing!!”
… I will write soon again.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 17 March. MS: Huntington Lib. Pbd: Larkin, BQR 37.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: I have no doubt you have done with those Biographies;Of Schiller and John Sterling; see TC to HL, 30 Jan., and 4 Feb. nor are they yet wanted,—but they will be, infallibly, in four weeks hence, they and the sequel to them; which latter is still in nubibus [in the clouds], and begins to look dangerous to me!

I think it ought to be the Miscellanies,Critical and Miscellaneous Essays, 4 vols. (Boston, 1838; London, 1839); 2d edn., 5 vols. (1840); 3d edn., 4 vols. (1847). which will need some little shifting (I believe) in some of the outskirts (change of Appendix into Text &c), and especially will need Summary and Index well done.

Will you be so kind as consider practically what you could do, and what you would like to do, in that matter; then bring me the Sterling (so soon as ready) any evening; and let us decide something about that other matter. If you find yourself unequal or unenclinedThus in MS. to the Miscellanies, I have another offer for that (unexceptionable, save that I shall have too much talk upon it; whh is a serious fault,—wool, and not cry,Cf. “All cry and no wool,” proverbial; i.e., a lot of noise and nothing to show for it. being the matter in quest!)—and in case of the worst, we can get plenty of other work to hold your helpful hand in use.Larkin wrote: “I responded heartily to this summons; … [M]y visits became less formal, and were entirely pleasant and encouraging. Mrs. Carlyle and I seemed to get on very happily together. She said, she didn’t see why Carlyle … should have me all to himself; and enlisted my services in many little practical difficulties of her own. She once, in those early days, told me, in her pleasant, half-flattering, half-bantering way, that I was ‘the only one she had ever heard Carlyle speak of, without what Sir Robert Peel would call “mitigating circumstances”!’ ” Soon after Larkin sent TC an essay, “The Poetry of Life,” expressing his notion of “the Christian ideal.” When he next visited, TC and JWC were strangely silent: “[T]hey must already have looked on me as a kind of feeble Irving; with much of his spirit of willing helpfulness; but utterly without his great gifts, for which perhaps chiefly they had both admired him. I have no doubt they were sincerely grieved at the thought, that here was another earnest life brought close to them, equally bound to be wrecked in the vain struggle after the impossible and unattainable” (BQR 37–38). Larkin himself believed that TC “had an inarticulate belief in the infinitely just ‘Most High God’ … and, if it does not reach to the clear heaven of Christian love and self-devotion, it is at least their everlasting basis” (Carlyle and the Open Secret of His Life [1886] 355).
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 21 March. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / N.B. MS: NLS 525.24. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: We are always in considerable confusion here, sometimes in considerable distress, or I wd have written to you sooner. Poor Jane does not get better: she has twice been evidently on the recovering hand, but has both times (the first time very badly) relapsed:See TC to JCA, 5 March. she is now on the second recovery (I at last hope) from a slighter check she had about a week ago. Nothing serious seems to me to be wrong; the cough, tho’ teasing and violent, has a superficial quality, I always flatter myself. But five months of pining and confinement,—want of sleep sometimes total, and always partial; rare access to the free air, &c &c: all this is very bad. We have never had a Doctor, neither of us knowing of any in the least likely to help, had our anxiety to have one been greater: sometimes, in bad moments, I think there ought to be one,—she also, I can now see, is occasionally disheartened, but only occasionally. On the whole if you happen to know of anybody, give us his name. Small help to be found that way, if one have not special guidance! Locock went to Nice,See TC to Lord ALOA, 12 Feb. pocketed his £1,000 (a nice fee for one day),—and, I seriously believe, did nothing but ill,—confirmed all that the Family DrJames Rouse. said, and expressed terror over it, whh the Fy Dr refused and refuses to entertain;—tho’ matters wear a very sickly aspect there Locock “has made a cure” &c &c. One rather feels as if a horsewhipping were not inappropriate to such a curative process.

I have put away “Peesweep,“—such was the title of unfortunate Wagner-Martin in late weeks; title rather descriptive of him. He was unhappy, and the cause of more unhappiness. Like to drive me distracted, sometimes, with his hysterical futilities,—poor soul. The ‘whistling thro’ the nose’ (in breathing in cold weather) made me send him home “to work”; at home or at the Museum, he was futile, chaotic not cosmic: “too weak for the place.” I got on perceptibly better since his unbeautiful face was veiled from me. Poor soul, we shall have a bout still before there can be some new outlet found for him. But his “help” I will have no more of, whatever come.

I begin to long for news from Scotsbrig.— Donne the Librarian has resigned;W. B. Donne, chief librarian of the London Lib. since 1852. Edward FitzGerald wrote to a friend in Feb.: “Donne is going to leave the London Library; he has now got his Sons through College, and he can make as much money, and more pleasantly (he thinks) by Review writing out of London—but not far out” (Terhune, LEF 2:255). Donne announced his resignation, 21 March, at a meeting of the London Lib. committee, having written to TC, 17 March, asking him to attend. great fuss choosing another, whh I keep aloof from. James Hannay Candidate M.P. for DumfriesJames Hannay (1827–73; ODNB; see 24:263TC to MAC, 3 Oct. 1849), author and journalist, known to TC since 1850. He stood as Tory candidate and was defeated. is a scrub of a creature, writing for Newspapers; applies to me this morning to give him a line.— Mit nichten [nothing doing]. My Horse came at the due hour; but it is now five, and I am still here! Adieu. Your affectionate / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-DL, 23 March. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO DAVID LAING

docBody.p: A long time ago I lent you (I think, included in some little quarto Pamphlet as part of its contents) a Letter of mine to the Scotch Antiquaries about National Portrait-Collections.See 29:75–91TC to DL, 2 May 1854. I want the thing now, to see whether it is worth reprinting; and shall be much obliged if you will send it back to me.— There is to be a “National Gallery of Portraits,”See TC to Lady ALA, [9 March. it seems; but I doubt it will be a long time first!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 24 March. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd. Attached to some pages of Frederick MS sent by TC to Neuberg.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: To Mr Ng (24 March 1857)

Old DessauerLeopold I (1676–1747), prince of Anhalt-Dessau, Prussian field marshal; see Works 12:327–33. 7pp. Try if you can read it,—compress the beginning of it with something (I think now) in a chapter you have; and adopt the better of the two!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [24 or 31 March]. MS: NLS 606.437. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote on the MS: “(Feb or early Marh Spring, 1857)”; dated after the birth of Jeannie Chrystal’s da., Sunday, 22 March.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Oh my Darling! I was so pleased to see your handwriting again! I knew how every time you thought of writing to me, you would shudder at the idea, the first time since!The death of her father. Ah, that first time one does anything after a great sorrow has fallen on one, realized as the first time, how it cuts one to the heart!— The first time I had been to Thornhill since—the first time I had seen you since— what a thought that was for myself last SeptemberI.e., since the death of her mother, 25 Feb. 1842, at Templand, Thornhill (see 14:27JWC to JOST, 27 Jan. 1842). JWC had stayed with the Russells at Thornhill, 22–29 Sept. 1856. Oh dear Mary! I never saw a more sympathetic Being than yourself—never was near any one that seemed to enter into my feelings so instinctively—still I am sure you will understand now better than even you could at that time the perfect agony of desolation that filled my heart that day, when I stood at the door of Templand; without even a right to be there! Often this winter when I have been in a high fever I have felt as if that moment was going to make itself into a center of delirium for me! and have lighted candles and sat up in bed to read, that I might drive it forcibly away— How good you were to me that day! all of you! Your voices sounded so gentle!— And one of these voices we shall hear no more—but we will carry the kind tones of it in our hearts—to make ourselves kinder It is so your Father would have us remember him, with a sorrow fruitful in goodness and kindness.

I am very impatient to hear you get back your sleep— Do you try anything but air and exercise?— Have you ever tried giving up tea?— I do believe my own sleep is improved by the discontinuance of my two cups of tea— I think too I have got some good of an infusion of hops—it is a favorite and certainly very safe prescription of Dr Holland’s.Sir Henry Holland (1788–1873; ODNB; see 5:356TC to JWC, 22 Aug. 1831), prominent London physician. You pour boiling water on an ounce of hops, and let it stand two hours—and drink four or five wine glasses of it in the day, chiefly toward night—it is very calming and is a slight tonic and a slight soporific—and can do no possible harm— I am sure it has been of use to me. I had another relapse last week—was three days and nights in a burning fever— I had caught a little fresh cold—from being out in a close carriage. I shall not attempt any thing of the sort again—but keep to my two warm rooms, till the warm weather comes.
Yesterday and today I have coughed less than any day for five weeks—in virtue I believe of having kept my bed after the last relapse—
My cousin Jeanie got a little daughterMary, b. 22 March. last sunday— I hope it will do her good—in several ways—

I wish every day of my life we were near one another— Not that I am allowed to feel lonely—Good Heavens “anything but“ as my maid says— The town has been pretty full of late weeks and I have more callers than I can receive— My acquaintance has really “shown feeling” (as the Haddington people used to say)—“honourable women not a few”Coterie speech; see William Huntington, Epistles of Faith (1785) part 1, letter 6. come to what they call “sit” with me—and they keep me in flowers and woodcocks and “all the delicacies of the season“—and all the fashionable gossip!— But how much better than all that one good, heart-to-heart, long talk with you darling!

Geraldine comes for “orders” in the mornings and sits with me in my bedroom an hour or two every night— My MaidAnne. is quite recovered and nurses me with a tenderness she never displayed before, since she saw my different fashion of nursing, in her own case— She never said “thank you” for anything I did about her; but so soon as she was on foot she put no end of gratitude into actions.

Pray dont tell “the Doctor[“]Dr. James Russell. Quotation marks omitted. about my infusion he might think it too impertinent that I should be prescribing for his wife— But just because he is a man, and a Doctor, he may perhaps hardly appreciate the good effects of such little solacements to the feminine imagination as my no tea, my infusion of hops &c &c &c

I wish you could go to Mrs Veitch’sProbably Agnes Veitch (b. ca. 1820), wife of James Veitch Jr., who was listed as a banker in the 1851 census, and a fundholder and farmer in the 1861 census; both of Eliock House, Sanquhar (about 10 mi. N of Thornhill). for a day or two—a change often breaks a bad sleeping habit when nothing else can— My sincere regards to the Dr
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: Please dont be long of sending me just two lines to say how you are

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 24 [25] March. MS: MUL. Pbd: Marrs 722–23. TC misdates the letter. Wed. was 25 March. Part of the letter between paras. 2 and 3 has been cut away.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Thanks for your Letter; which may be useful if Jane happen to fall at all seriously worse: she as yet stiffly declines having any Doctor,—did not find
Shaw “do anything but certify that nothing could be done”;Possibly Alexander Shaw (1804–90; ODNB), surgeon of 25 Henrietta St., Cavendish Sq. “never saw Thomson, tho he shewed very great attention in the matter of the Irish maid”Seth Thompson, 1 Lower Seymour St., Portman Sq.; see 30:79TC to JAC, 5 Oct. 1855. For Dr. Thompson and Fanny, the Irish maid, see 27:309JWC to JAC, 30 Sept. 1852, where he is incorrectly identified. &c &c In fact she shrinks at the idea of a stranger (especially of the London species):—I was thinking once of old Forbes, who has just been publishing a little quasi-medical Book, whh seemed to have very just notions of the Art.Sir John Forbes (1787–1861; ODNB), physician to the queen’s household, and founder of the British and Foreign Medical Review (1836–47); see 21:81TC to JAC, 25 Oct. 1846. In Of Nature and Art in the Care of Disease, pbd. Feb., he criticized public ignorance “of the natural course and progress of diseases” and “of the power of nature to cure diseases.” This was the reason the public demanded of the practitioner “more powerful doses” and prescriptions that could be “either useless or injurious.” Forbes blamed infatuation with medical “art” for encouraging people to listen to “the most ridiculous promises of charlatans; also to run after the professors and practisers of doctrines utterly absurd and useless, as in the instance of Homeopathy and Mesmerism, or dangerous, except in the proper cases, as in the instance of Hydropathy” (11, 12). But I doubt he does not practice: nor if he did, do I know at all where he lives even. I have seen him often enough in old times: certainly rather a wooden old gentn, yet not without mother-wit in his head.— It will be best of all, if we do not need any medical man!— This is the crown of bad weather in these days; I never felt a more truly Greenland element; I ride sometimes with cape &c as in the heart of winter, and am not too warm.

Jane complains of toothache, as an addition, this afternoon; has had to get chloroform &c: poor soul she had little or no sleep last night; and has been a shade worse all day, but I trust it is not a relapse again. She absolutely has not stirred from the warm rooms. On the whole she is certainly much stronger than I have sometimes seen her since this began. [ … Sc]otsbrig Letter (what is curious to think of) there arrived one from Alick: a very touching and interesting piece I found it,—the sugar bush, the burnt trees, Alick’s feeling of inexorable old age creeping on; an affectionate, most softhearted sternvisaged Brother,—at war with Fate, like the rest of us.
