My work goes on, work could not well [be] worse. The light of hope is as if withdrawn from my eyes: it seems I was born to (among other things) sink in this spoonful of dirty water? I won’t tho’,—that is flat!

Jean tells me about Stevenson (of Glasgow) going out with a Free Kirk party “to Jerusalem“: what is that?No Free Church “party ‘to Jerusalem’ ” has been traced. A mission from the Church of Scotland to the Holy City had been proposed by the synod of Glasgow and Ayr to the committee for the conversion of the Jews in 1855; it was turned down as “not expedient at this present time” (Report to the General Assembly [1856] 7). The mission was proposed again to the 1857 General Assembly, but turned down, partly because of testimony of those who had “recently visited the Holy City” (Report to the General Assembly, 22 May 1857). This recent visit is untraced. TC may refer to James Stevenson (1810–65), educ. Glasgow Univ., licensed by Presbytery of Glasgow, 1836; minister of Newton-upon-Ayr Free Church, 1843–65; otherwise unidentified. Kind regards to Jamie and the rest
docBody.name: [signature cut away]

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LA], 26 March. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Hansons, NE 458.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I have had two little Bulletins, the second more reassuring, tho’ both are of rather uncertain complexion:Lord Stanley wrote to his wife, 21 March: “I am sorry to say the accounts of Lady Ashburton are worse, the remedies have ceased to have effect, more water is forming & her debility increases. I fear her case is most dangerous” (The Stanleys of Alderley, ed. Nancy Mitford [1939] 173). many thanks to Lord An. for his friendly pains. Alas, I have nothing for it but to listen to the dim oracles; and refuse to be disheartened the best I may. You are clearly in much pain and depression; that, alas, I can by no means deny to myself. That I think enough for admitting; that is all I will admit, or have admitted. If they are giving you mercury (as I may conjecture), experience sufficiently teaches me the tearing wasting effects of that potent drug; and above all, its terrible effect on the spirits Never mind it,—if you only could never, or ever! One cannot help its harassing influence,—no strength of soul can;—but its effects are powerful for good too, I suppose beyond all other medicine in that respect.It was widely believed that mercury, particularly in the form of the “blue pill,” was an effective treatment against mental and nervous illness. The American physician Benjamin Rush (1745–1813) wrote in 1812 that mercury “stimulates every part of the body … conveys morbid action out of the body by the mouth, and thus restores the mind to its native seat in the brain” (quot. Janet Oppenheim, “Shattered Nerves“: Doctors, Patients, and Depression in Victorian England [Oxford, 1991] 113). “An electrified Cat“—I remember that was once a similitude of yours, for the state of nerves it (or some other cause) can produce on one’s nervous-system. Be not discouraged; be ready at mid-April: we shall think you almost here when once you are in Paris. I hear your House there is one of the finest possible for what you want with it.

We have had a week or more of the most supremely virulent March weather,—the last fit, we may hope:—today the Sun has come out, and the East-wind gone down: a large fall of rain is now due, and we shall be into April with its green things and its flowers.

Poor Jane is still prisoner; she caught new cold, venturing out too rashly;—staid punctually within heated rooms, during this last bout; and will not venture out even today. I think she is clearly getting better; and approve of
the caution she uses, whh cannot be too punctilious after such an experience. Five months now since I have seen her out to breakfast.— In fact these are heavy times to me, and to some others of us, in all manner of ways. The Scotch have a Proverb whh I often remember, “Jook (duck) and let the jaw go by (jaw is ‘sudden-torrent,’ ‘wave’ such as one finds in sea-bathing in rough weather): “jook and let the jaw go by.“— Yes, do; you also, dear Lady Sufferer; the waves and “jaws” do all go by; and better times come, one can hope!—

Everybody is about “electing” here; enthusiasm for Palmerston (Chatham of the Cabmen)I.e., Palmerston was a debased version of William Pitt (1708–78; ODNB), 1st earl of Chatham; the election was won because of Palmerston’s personal popularity. is very great. It is frightful to think what torrents of balderdash will be emitted, and what a pack of scurvy hounds will be at last returned, as “Collective Folly of the Nation,“—for really that is now coming to be definition of it more and more. One comfort is, we had no hand in it, no, nor will have!

I have been a second time to the “Portrait Gallery Commissioners”;According to the minutes of the board of trustees of the National Portrait Gallery, TC attended the meeting of Mon., 23 March, but no previous one (Heinz Archive and Lib., National Portrait Gallery); see also TC to Lady ALA, 9 March. and am not sure I shall soon be a third time. It does not appear to me they will ever collect a “Gallery” by their present mode of operating; nor is any other easily recommended all at once,—nor indeed do they seem the least conscious that any other is wanted.TC apparently received (and replied to) a letter suggesting that portraits of the comedian Munden and his wife might be appropriate for the Portrait Gallery as William Waldron wrote a second letter, 1 May, from 27 Brydges St., Strand: “You will admit that in regard to promoting the interest of Widow & Orphan I may without offending again address you in respect to the portraits of Lawrence & Shee of Comedian Munden & his Wife. Expense has been an obstacle to Mrs. Munden’s transmitting them for the season of Art Treasures Exhibition at Manchester where they might be justly appreciated. / But I trust, Sir that Works of pictorial goodness involving reminiscence of celebrity may by you be introduced to their best Museum. / The kindness of replying to solicitations having the living besides honour to the dead in view will duly gratefully be esteemed.” The Gallery’s reply is noted on the back of the MS: “Mr Carlyle having communicated your offer of portraits of Mr & Mrs Munden to the trustees of the national Portrait Gallery I am directed by them to say that they decline the purchase.” Joseph Shepherd Munden (1758–1832), the leading comic actor of his day, performed in Drury Lane, 1813–24, and was written about by Leigh Hunt, William Hazlitt, William Lamb, and others. Sir Thomas Lawrence (1769–1830), portrait painter and president of the Royal Academy, 1820–30; Sir Martin Shee (1769–1850), portrait painter and president of the Royal Academy, 1830–50. The portraits are untraced; ODNB lists eight portraits of Munden in the Mathews collection in the Garrick Club, none by Lawrence or Shee. Munden’s wife, Frances Butler (1753?–1836), retired from the stage after their marriage in 1789. The widow and orphan referred to by Waldron are presumably those of their son Thomas Shepherd Munden (1800?–1850) who had written his father’s Memoir (1844). We will leave them to their fate a little
while:—one attendance costs me an hour always of working time; and I have something to do with the little time that is now left me here. Lord Lansdowne seems always to attend; very cheery polite old gentn,—seems to think we are in quest of play-writers, verse-writers, anybody we can catch who has been heard of in the newspapers of the last fifty: except Händel and RaleighGeorge Frederick Handel (1685–1759), composer; Sir Walter Ralegh (1552?–1618), military and naval commander, author. I know not any real demigod they have yet got or are in sight of;—and even Händel I shd have had my doubts about.— Enough, enough.

The first holiday I have (whh will be by and by, at the closing of a certain “mud-vortex”), I mean to ride to Addiscombe and see the physiognomy at least of that again.— Adieu, dear Lady; God bless you always friend of friends. (Here is the Horse come,—my one useful servant in this world) T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-DL, 28 March. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO DAVID LAING

docBody.p: You would oblige me very much if, in your Antiquarian SocietySoc. of Antiquaries of Scotland. or otherwise, you could procure me a Copy of that Letter I once wrote to you (and read in a very correctly printed state) about the Scottish Exhibition of Historical Portraits.For TC’s letter of 3 May 1854, see 29:84–90TC to DL, 3 May 1854; see also 29:75TC to DL, 2 May 1854; it was printed in 1855; see 29:314TC to DL, 20 May 1855. For the letter, see Works 29:404–13. I got 5 or 6 copies of it from you, and sent them about; one (incorporated in the Transactions) I kept for myself: but a kind of semi-official amateurUnidentified; not Lord Stanhope as he apparently had his own copy, presumably sent to him by TC; see 30:84TC to JN, 20 Oct. 1855. has borrowed it from me almost two years ago; and now when I want it very much (for printing in certain “Miscellanies” of mine, which are going to press),The cheap edition of Critical and Miscellaneous Essays, 4 vols., was pbd. Aug. to Oct.; “Project of a National Exhibition of Scottish Portraits” was 4:330–37. my Amateur “has never received it,“—Post-Office must have lost it, for it went by post! Lost it sure enough is; and I have no resource but to apply to you.

If you could cut out the leaf or two, occupied by the Letter, in the little Pamphlet of Transactions; and mark for me on the margin the correct Title of that Pamphlet (year and place Edinr! included), it would come more easily and safely to hand, and there wd be nothing more wanted for my present objects.

If you cannot possibly get the thing for me in this or some other easy way,
have the goodness to let me know directly, and I will contrive some other effort. But I hope it will be possible for you.

We have got a thing called “National Portrait Commission” here; but that need not slacken your Scottish efforts, if there ever were any:The Scottish National Portrait Gallery opened in 1889; see 29:90TC to DL, 3 May 1854.—I reckon it may be a very long time indeed before there be a “Gallery” got together by the present hands and methods! I am extremely occupied, and in the most miserable manner I have heretofore ever had experience of,—nigh choked, soul and body, in beggarly whirlwinds of Prussian sand!
No more therefore at present.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: David Laing Esq &c &c

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [28 March]. MS: NLS 552.135. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by Neuberg’s visit on Sunday, 29 March, see n. 11 below.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—You are evidently taking far too much pains with that imbroglio of Scrawlings. I merely wanted you to run over the masses with your fresh (undigusted)Thus in MS. eye; to judge what passages were worth the chance implied in having them copied by Wagner;Frederick Martin. to mark with a pencil stroke on the margin what he was to copy,—and send him home to do it. With strict and strictest charge to bring every line of the original back to me.— He has not done that in the case of George II;George II (1683–1760), king of Great Britain and Ireland, 1727–60. and I have sat, for 3 days, over that Piece, in the uttermost wretchedness, not knowing what on Earth to do with it,—or where to begin upon it,—owing to that want! But we will be patient: I do myself immeasurable mischief by the want of that virtue. No use asking Wagner what has become of the George II things: he will ‘drop a tear over himself’ (a very bad habit!)Referring to Martin’s habit of sniffing continuously; see JWC to IC, [ca. 10 Dec. 1856].—and that is all we shall get.

Please do not meddle with SoissonsThe Congress of Soissons; see Works 13:142. at all: send that home by him tomorrow straight hither;—and what of the other you have ready (not hurrying yourself) he is to commence copying (sworn to bring the original all back, and at least put it as he found it here)

My Wife is but little better,—improving I do however think. The Decker
BooksSee TC to JN, 19 Dec. 1856. are not quite witht value: please ask Who wrote that Prinz HeinrichHeinrich Friedrich Ludwig (1726–1802), Prince Henri, Frederick’s youngest brother; see also 29:73TC to JN, 28 April 1854. Neuberg replied, 18 May: “The Author of the life of ‘Prinz Heinrich,’ as well as of the little Books on Ziethen, & Old Dessauer, (Decker writes) is Heinrich von Bülow, Brother of the ‘General,’ him ‘of Dennewitz,’ whose life, by Varnhagen, you know. I remember in Varnhagen’s Book some mention of an eccentric clever Brother, who wrote very sharp military criticisms on the then Prussn. affairs … for which he got imprisoned, and if I remember rightly died in prison. … The ‘Ziethen,’ and ‘Dessauer’ … are out of a biographical ‘Sammelwerk,’ the titlepage ‘which probably had an engraving on it,’ was missing.” TC’s copies of Adam Heinrich Dietrich von Bülow, Prinz Heinrich von Preussen. Kritische Geschichte seiner Feldzüge (Berlin, 1805), and Varnhagen von Ense, Leben des Generals Grafen Bülow von Dennewitz (Berlin, 1853) are in HCC. Bülow’s biographical Sammelwerk is probably Militärische Biographien berühmter Helden (Berlin 1803–6), 5 vols. (rather a solid piece that), and those other Büchlein [little books] abt Ziethen,Hans Joachim von Zieten (1699–1786), Prussian cavalry gen. the Old-Dessauer &c, whh are of very flaccid quality, I fear. Berenhorst is by far the ablest man I have yet communicated with on Prussian Soldier-matters: unluckily an ill-tempered perverse kind of nature withal, whh much twists his judgements upon all manner of things.Georg Heinrich von Berenhorst, Betrachtungen über die Kriegskunst, über ihre Fortschritte, ihre Widerspräche, und ihre Zuverlässigkeit (Leipzig, 1827; first pbd. Leipzig, 1798–99), in HCC. TC wrote on the flyleaf of the book that it had been given him by Guido von Usedom: “His book is full of a certain talent, & real opulence of mind; but is defaced by sediments of imperfect moral qualities (pride, anger, vainglory too traceable in it, tho’ well varnished over), which considerably pervert (as one may well see) the conclusions he arrives at … Scepticism (in war itself, much more on all other ‘arts’ & subjects), this, with a dash of revolutionary sentimentalism, may be described as the result he has finally come to. (Note of March 1857, while pretty well on with reading his Book.)” See also Works 14:233 and 18:315. Berenhorst (1733–1814), “a natural son of the Old Dessauer’s, and evidently enough a chip of the old block, only gone into the articulate-speaking or intellectual form”; see Works 18:314–15. His hatred to Fritz is a kind of elixir of hatreds,—distilled to invisibility or nearly so, but felt in every page. I read him witht disgust,—tho’ slowly, his style too partaking of his temper, and being dreadfully screwed and twisted. I begin to see Frh may have had him in aversion, especially his “sympathy” on the disaster in Torgau Fight,—and have impatiently ordered him to go and mind his work elsewhere: “Er sammle Fuyards [Go and round up deserters]!”—

We are at home Tomorrow evgSun., when Neuberg often visited Cheyne Row. TC wrote in his journal: “My poor wife ill, all this winter; 5 months of a cold now; much suffering, much patience on her part;—getting better I do hope. Truly frightful work with that (undoable) Prussian Book; with foolish ‘Peesweeps’ of clerks &c (poor Wendie [i.e., Sorbian] German, whom I have had to turn off, as incompetent fairly); with buying horses; riding steadily and far daily thro’the black ruddy elements all winter— Oh that I had known ‘my limits’; but I did not.— I see nobody; sit till riding time at my dreary work; must not give it up, tho value less? The remedy is, to get it down.— Lady A. fallen very ill at Nice; nothing but sorrow there either: my friends all fallen silent there, or falling? ‘Do not lose heart,’ my dear Mother used to say. No; be resolute, but more piously so, more wisely!— General ‘Election’ going on (hat gar nichts zu bedeuten [it has hardly any significance]); my ‘Works’ printing. Enough!—” (29 March). to you, at least I am
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: I believe it wd be a very thrifty thing if I took all these Papers and cast them into the fire at once. Perhaps I shall have virtue to do that one day;—it was always my plan hithertoIn a note attached to the MS, TC wrote: “pp. 23, 24; & 34 (of Book now on hand); correct but fearfully patched: copies are in their place,—and these are the originals. / Copies certified correct by Ng (29 March 1857); originals put aside (among waste)—not tear them up. / 1 April 1857 / ‘Books’ is Fk’s (Schooling &c) Youth, Potsdam Gdn Gibraltar War &c.” For the “Gibraltar War,” see Works 13:97, 102, 142. TC did not burn the papers, many of which are now at Yale.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [29 March]. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd. Written on the same sheet as TC to JN, 24 March, and attached to some pages of the MS of Frederick that TC had sent to Neuberg, 24 March, and to which Neuberg had obviously replied.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: To follow p. 47? (7pp.) (no, it cannot come in there! ‘Equal step’ &c still somewhere? (No 37) Apparently this must come in directly at the end of p. 47; but I cannot find (29 March, 1857) where the other Chap. on Dessau is (paragraph at the beginning is ‘bis,’ I think,—twice given, better here?)— So it must take this place for the present. God pity me, for man cannot!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-[C & H] [CAH], 1 April. MS: NLS 7197. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO [CHAPMAN & HALL]

docBody.p: Will you be so good as send the present Volume (Cromwell ii) with the 3 preceding onesThe Athenaeum advertised, 28 March, vol. 2 of the “Cheap Re-Issue” of Cromwell as ready, and its vol. 1 and French Revolution as already pbd.; see appendix 1Athenaeum Advertisements. and all the following to
Miss Jewsbury / 3. Oakley Street, King’s Road, Chelsea. Of course you attend also to the Nottingham New-York businessSee TC to [C & H]MRW, 10 March. in that respect.

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: Anthony Sterling wrote to TC from 3 South Pl., 2 April: “Many thanks for your note with its enclosure, and regrets for your being unwell which state let us hope may not last.” He gave details of the length of Letters from the Army in the Crimea, which he was to publish privately in Oct.: “I am not so reckless of sound advice as you seem to suppose and whether I print for private circulation or for publication I shall certainly divide according to my poor ability these letters into groups, with further writing and as you say elucidation. … I cannot help thinking that you would see more daylight peering out of these letters, if you had heard them all.” He intended making additions to the book, including an index, and to publish it in 2 vols., but there was to be no index and the letters were pbd. chronologically in one vol.

ps.p: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea,

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [6 April]. Addr: Thornhill / Dumfriesshire / N.B. PM: 6 April 1857. MS: NLS 606.436. Quot: Hansons, NE 460, 463.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I want very much to know about your sleep? Dont plague yourself to write a letter while you have not spirits for it; but do send me just two lines to say if you have broken thro’ that miserable habit of awaking in the early morning. I never lie awake all night myself, without thinking of you, with such sympathy as only comes thro experience. Considering that I still keep the house, my own sleep is rather improved. Only if anything have worried me during the day. I have a wakeful night, and one brings another. Last week Mr Carlyle startled me one evening with a project of going off to Germany, so soon as he had finished the second volume of his book, and writing the other two volumes there!— I was to go with him; and he calculated on my long-ago strength and activity and ingenuity, to shelter him from the disagreeables of a strange country, and surround him with a scotch home in the middle of german curtainless beds, and german stoves, and german devil-knows-what-all!— “So you see my Dear,” he concluded, “you must make haste and get well, for you will have plenty to do, and scheme out”!—

Now all that talk might never get further than talk—Mr C propounds many such projects that come to nothing, beyond the worry of the moment— Still this one might be carried out! and the bare idea of it in my actual state of nerves and bodily inability made me like to scream! Four bad nights were the result!

No more has been said about Germany since the day after the first declaration of his scheme. Then, he merely said; “How will you like going to live in Germany do you think?“— I said very quietly; “I dont think the present is a favourable time for your asking the question, or for my answering it. When one is confined to two rooms with so bad a cold one has little spirit left for new adventures especially when they involve bodily fatigue“— “True” he said—“you must of course get well first of all.“— Since that the subject has
been let drop—and I trust in Heaven it may not be returned to— If he would only go and write the rest of his book in Scotland!— But there would be no “facilities” there!

It is beautiful warm air the last two days; and I should have gone out at last, but for the constant showers—making every thing so damp— Since I kept my two rooms my cough has been gradually going off—and my strength returning— It would be a pity to run the risk of more relapses for the sake of getting about a few days soonerAnne Procter wrote about this time to William Brookfield, who had recently returned with his family from traveling in Europe: “I am very glad you have come home again. To find Mrs. Carlyle, I fear, seriously ill” (Brookfield 2:453).

The last accounts of Lady Ashburton were very favourable— She had been suffering so much from Locock’s medecines that she positively refused to go on with them, and sent for the Physician (Russian) of the Empress of RussiaMaria Alexandrovna, of Hesse-Darmstadt (1824–80), m., 1841, to Tsar Alexander II (1818–81). One of the tsarist family’s personal doctors was S. P. Botkin (1832–89), but it is not known when he began this role. (also at Nice for her health) He entirely disagreed with Lococks view of her case—desired her to give up all medecine entirely—and she was rapidly recovering her strength and spirits, on a diet of “skimmed milk, a little bread, and salt herring”!!! She was driving out, and meant to come to Paris in a week or so—where they have taken a fine house (a thousand pounds for two months of it!!) and after that, she thinks of going to CarlsbadSpa town in western Bohemia, now the Czech Republic, 116 mi. W of Prague.— Why she never thinks of coming to her own beautiful Place in HampshireThe Grange. I cant understand!—
You will have heard of my cousin Jeanie’s babyMary Chrystal.—all right— I hope she will now at least turn to dressing it instead of herself.
My kindest love to Dr Russell.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: I looked up all the texts and put marks at them.Unexplained.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LA], 7 April. MS: NLS Acc. 11388 inc. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 5:282–83 inc. Part of the text is from Wilson; see nn. 4 and 8.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Dear Lady,—We hear cheering accounts of you; vague, but all favourable, and more or less agreeing with Lord An’s last note; which are a great comfort,
you may believe! Today Miss Farrar reported to my Wife, that you are out of the severe treatments altogether, living on milk diet; perhaps on the road to Paris by this time:—Would to Heaven we could believe all that! We can hope at any rate; we have always refused not to hope.

The April weather is miraculously warm here; much rain, but a temperature equal to the end of May; and westerly winds, when dry as they are from time to time, altogether wholesome and pleasant. Might they but bring you home to us soon. Once at Paris, you will seem to us next door to home; within a day,—fully nearer for a Letter than my Scotch Border is;—almost looking over into your old haunts here. Bath HouseThe Ashburtons’ London home, at the corner of Piccadilly and Bolton St.; see 30:200JWC’s Journal, 22 Oct. 1855. is vacant, but safe and ready; how ready wd it and other objects be for you!—

As for myself I am not prosperous; have been less so for a fortnight past than usual; and oftenest very dark indeed. The truth is, I am fallen extremely weak (I did not know how weak), and have more laid on me than I can well travel with at times. A sad business that I ever undertook that Friedh: what had I to do with it? I am not fit for such an unutterable mass of confusions, difficulties, disgusts and ineptitudes; should have been 20 years younger; should have put myself under Tom CribTom Cribb (1781–1848), English bare-knuckle boxing champion. first, to get into condition. My case is very bad;—and I find there is only one remedy, To get the thing done, were it only at the rate of an inch a-day!—

My Wife continues rather improving; but is still weak as possible;—very cautious, this time, of not getting new cold; has only been twice out, in spite of the tempting glimpses of weather. Today indeed she narrowly escaped rain, whh now continues.— I find I have ridden too diligently; so the oracles plainly sing, much to my sorrow: one cannot force back lost health by vigour in riding. I must have done about 1,500 miles already: but am now ordered to take it more moderately; and keep an eye on other Laws too. One does not know one’s limits; and one should, and must!—

A Daydream of mine is, To see you quiet, well and solitary at The Grange once more,—all Highland wildernesses and wild things and journeyings given up; a “practical school” for girls, do for boys (difficult exceedingly, important exceedingly) occupy the Lady and the Lord, supply them with a generous interest;Both Ashburtons had a long-standing interest in education. Lord Ashburton was the proprietor of Brown Candover Parochial School, Hampshire, and had agreed with the Committee of Council on Education in 1851 that the premises would be used without interruption for the education of the poor, access being given to inspectors of schools, in exchange for a parliamentary grant for the payment of stipends to pupil teachers (Hampshire Records Office, 80M 70 S3). Philip W. Stockman, of Fareham School, Hampshire, complained to Lord Ashburton, 31 July 1855, that because of the latter’s generous subsidies to the Candover school the master there charged fees so low that Stockman could not compete: “I know your lordship too well as a philanthropist, and schoolmaster’s staunch friend to believe that you will suffer my case to pass unheeded” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). In 1859, Ashburton was to build the Grange Church of England School on Northington Hill in Hampshire (Hampshire Record Office TOP237/1/3). There is no evidence that the Ashburtons ever set up a girls’ school or were interested in the day-to-day running of the schools, though Brookfield wrote to Lady Ashburton in 1852 about “[n]o instructions” having been issued for “a visit to your school with reference to Augmentation of your Damsel’s salary” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388), and Lord Ashburton appears to have been interested in the appointment of teachers: “I saw the new schoolmistress in London & liked her appearance. She is very young to exercise authority but not younger than Miss Lee” (n.d.; NLS Acc. 11388). For Lord Ashburton’s pamphlet, Ashburton Prizes for the Teaching of Common Things, based on the work of Richard Dawes (1793–1867; ODNB) at Kings Somborne National School, Hampshire, see 28:335TC to JCA, 7 Dec. 1853, and 29:27TC to LOA, 9 Feb. 1854. For TC’s encouragement of the Ashburtons’ interest in education, see 30:127TC to LOA, 29 Nov. 1855. this and other things for genuine human employt, and interest
ever-new: no travelling, not even for health;—in the whole world, wherePart of MS missing; what follows is taken from Wilson. will you find a “better climate” (really better) than you have in your own England, in your own House and fields? All is to be quiet, regular, wholesome, wise, beautiful. And I (this is always one item) am to have somewhere in a still glade of the Woods, a brick Cottage, two rooms and kitchen “with a deaf (or at least dumb) old woman,” &c. &c., and to see you once every day, after my work is over! Couldn’t I tumble all my books into a cart; send it forth in God’s name—and follow!— This is a beautiful dream! I am getting more and more passionate for the Country; Country diet (of milk, &c.), Country air; innocent Country talk,—or else silence, and an end at least to so much of insane inanity;—and in fact I must make a terrible trial for it, were this Book once done, if it ever be.

Alas, yesterday at Charing Cross I passed while the Hanbury versus Chelsea Election was just ending.Robert Culling Hanbury (1823–67), brewer, partner in Truman, Hanbury & Co.; M.P. for Middlesex, 1857–67, admirer of Palmerston, who supported extension of the franchise, reform of parliament, and admission of Jews to Parliament (Times 3 April). Henry Charles Cadogan (1812–73), Viscount Chelsea; M.P. for Dover, 1852–57. The Times reported the nominations in Brentford, 2 April, as “of a very disorderly character” because of a group of what looked like drunken militiamen supporting Lord Chelsea. Chelsea had voted with Cobden against the govt. on the Arrow affair (see TC to JCA, 5 March) and was accused by the electorate of standing in Middlesex because Dover no longer wanted him. A Conservative who supported Palmerston in his disapproval of the secret ballot, Cadogan saw no harm in a “moderate” extension of the franchise but was against the admission of Jews to Parliament. At a meeting in his committee rooms, 4 April, a motion was passed that “in the judgment of this meeting the public opinions of Lord Chelsea are opposed to political and social improvement, and that he is not therefore qualified to represent the county of Middlesex” (Times 6 April). “Lord Chelsea nowhere,” they told me, Brewer Hanbury preferred to him; and at the top of the poll Ld. R. Grosvenor,—
probably the greatest fool in England.Lord Robert Grosvenor (1801–93; ODNB), politician; Whig M.P. for Middlesex, 1847–57; created 1st Baron Ebury, Sept. 1857. He had also voted with Cobden against the govt. in the Arrow affair. His opponents in the election made much of his support for the bill to limit Sunday trading that he had introduced in April 1855. It was withdrawn in July 1855 after growing press and public opposition and demonstrations against the bill in Hyde Park. TC may also have disliked him for this reason; for TC on sabbatarians, see 28:193TC to JWC, 9 July 1853. In fact, Hanbury had the largest number of votes, 5,426, Grosvenor, 5,324, and Chelsea, 2,916. Nobody seemed to be minding it, of the public. Hustings were about deserted, on the pavements in Cockspur StreetBetween Charing Cross and Pall Mall, where the Albion Hotel, Lord Grosvenor and Hanbury’s headquarters, and the Union Hotel, Lord Chelsea’s headquarters were both located. The Times reported the “triumphant returns of the two liberal candidates” and that the Albion Hotel “was surrounded throughout the day by an anxious crowd who perused the hourly returns of the state of the poll with great interest” (7 April). stood parboiled groups of ugly people (Committee-men, presumably), looking out gloomily with bloodshot eyes:—I was near bursting into laughterSection from Wilson ends here and MS resumes. in their faces,—poor devils, after all!— Adieu, dear Lady: I pray only these good accounts be confirmed. Good be with you evermore. T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 7 April. MS. Yale. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee possibly John Edward Jones; see n. 3.
div3.head: TC TO AN UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: I had lost your Letter till this morning.

Being extremely occupied at this time, and not calculating that I can do any good at the London Library, I decided to leave this Election altogether alone;William Bodham Donne had resigned; see TC to JAC, 21 March. An advert. for his replacement appeared in the Athenaeum, 4 April, applications to be sent to Donne. and shall probably not be in a Committee meeting at all till after this matter is ended. I went one afternoon, some weeks since, to reinforce a small minority there was, who pleaded that Bibliographic Accomplishments, as we had found by sad experience since the loss of poor Cochrane,John George Cochrane (1781–1852; see 12:346TC to WDC, 7 Dec. 1840, and 27:93TC to LOL, 24 April 1852), first librarian, 1841–52. were to all appearance a quality that did not really exist among Candidates (perhaps was extinct in the British Nation at present); that we ought to be content with a certain Sublibrarian we have at present, who is an excellent methodic, industrious goodnatured man, and knows the London Library by heart;John Edward Jones applied for the post but was unsuccessful; he had also been unsuccessful in 1852 when Donne got the post; see 27:144–46TC to JAC, 14 June 1852.—and give
up the idea of fishing out a real “Librarian” from the miscellany of the Public, till we incidentally might notice some symptom of one. This idea was not relished by the majority (among individuals of whom I could privately trace some decisive expectations directed upon yourself);—so that my whole work being done in the business, I had only to return home, and leave it till finished.

To several of your qualities, extant in a superior degree, I can myself bear witness; and it is possible, probable, the majority of the Committee will not have so strict notions of what a “knowledge of Books” means as I have;—at all events, I can well believe you are probably superior in this respect also to anything that will offer. So that I should say your chance on the whole seems good; and I believe I may promise farther that the Committee will decide bonâ fide upon such evidence of fitness as they may get,—and certainly without prejudice again[st] you, so far as I could gather that day.

I can only therefore encourage you to do your best in the way of shewing what you are; and shall hope (and believe, of you more than of another) that whatever you may want of Bibliography &c on entering on your Office, you will steadily go on acquiring till you are perfect in it. With many good wishes— Yours Sincerely,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[TW], 8 April. MS: NLS Acc. 6833. Addressee conjecturally identified as Thomas Watts (1811–69; ODNB; see 27:biographical note), TC’s closest acquaintance at the British Museum Lib. and an expert on Hungarian language and literature.
div3.head: TC TO [THOMAS WATTS]

docBody.p: If you ever want Copyists at the Museum, I think the Bearer of this, Mr Martin, whose qualifications are practically known to me by five months experience, would be very likely to suit beyond common.

He writes an excellent legible hand, German or English; has some academic culture, considerable sharpness of perception; knows German (which is his native language) in every minutest particular; French also to a high degree of exactitude, by long residence in that country; of his English, whh he writes fully as well as he speaks, you can yourself judge.
He has served me five months; and I can bear witness to his very great diligence, punctuality, and general desire to be useful.

If you could direct him in any way how to set about getting into some subaltern employment among the numerous people whom I suppose to be working at the Catalogue, or otherwise doing Copyist work, you would not
only much oblige me (which you are ever ready to do), but I am persuaded you would do a service both to the work on hand and to a meritorious man who is at present out of work. Any advice you could give him would be highly welcome in his present position.

I got your Hungarian Paper,Possibly referring to Watts’s paper, “On the Recent History of the Hungarian Language,” given to the Philological Society 13 April 1855 (see Transactions of the Philological Society 1855 14:285–310). and read it with pleasure: Many thanks.

Could you discover for me, some time, who it was that wrote that extremely stupid History of the Duke of Cumberland,Andrew Henderson, Life of William Augustus Duke of Cumberland (1766). near a Hundred years ago, of which I have got a Copy (not quite at hand at this moment)? Doubtless you know the Book.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-DL, 8 April. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO DAVID LAING

docBody.p:
Many thanks for all your goodness to me. I received the little Portrait affairSee TC to DL, 28 March. duly by return of post; a very seasonable help. And a day or two after, there arrived a much more valuable Gift, also right welcome to me, the Fifth Vol. of Knox’s Works,—which now make a goodly row on the shelf here; and must be near completion, I should think.David Laing, The Works of John Knox, vol. 5 (Edinburgh, 1856). Laing had also sent previous vols. to TC; see 21:235–36TC to DL, 18 June 1847, 23:100TC to JAC, 26 Aug. 1848, and 29:75TC to DL, 2 May 1854. All six vols. are listed in Carlyle’s House 96. Laing wrote, 23 May: “I did not expect you would feel the least interest in the 5th Vol. of Knox. But your Brother, when in Scotland last year expressed a desire to see the Vol. & pray gratify him. I must set almost speedily to the Sixth and concluding Volume.” Except the History of the Reformation,Knox’s The History of the Reformation in Scotland had been pbd. in the first two vols. of Knox’s Works; see 23:94–95TC to DL, 20 Aug. 1848. which has much attra[c]tionLetter omitted. even at present, and found me more at leisure for it than the others did, I have got no deliberate study made (as I full surely design) of these utterances of the Great Scottish Man; some cursory skimmings are all I have yet got from them. But certainly it is a real pleasure to me, and I think it a real honour to you, that you sort them up into purity in this manner, and get them all ready for the perusal of mankind. A truly patriotic and pious labour, that, beyond all dispute;—which should not have
been neglected so long, but which you still find waiting for you to do it. Therein you stand between Scotland and a great shame; all men must wish you honourably thro’ with it. I hope, and indeed confidently expect, you will take care to have a really good Index, and proper elucidations appended (clear statement, done with brevity and exactitude, of the times, the circumstances &c in which these several Treatises & Pamphlets were printed, reprinted; so that everybody that wishes it, to all time coming, may be able to read them with clearness of intelligence, and thank the Editor as he goes along.There are numerous notes giving MS and printed sources, a glossary, and general index for the first two vols. at the end of vol. 2, and a detailed name, place, and general index for vols. 3–6 at the end of vol. 6, part 2.

closer.salute: With many thanks on my own score, I remain

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 10 April. Pbd: Larkin, BQR 39.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: My dear Sir,—After you were gone I began to remember that the Goethe (Wanderjahre) Introduction was not among the others in Appendix to Vol. I.“[O]f Miscellanies” inserted in sq. br. in the text of the letter, presumably by Larkin. TC includes his introduction to Wilhelm Meister, “Preface, and Introductions to the Book Called ‘German Romance,’ ” in Critical and Miscellaneous Essays (1857 edn.), vol. 1, app. 1. Please put it there; they will thus all be in a lot,—and it will help the size of your volume, too. If you stick the above piece of MS.” ‘Note of 1857:’ introducing ‘Preface to German Romance’ ” inserted in sq. br. in the text of the letter, presumably by Larkin. The note duly appears at the beginning of app. 1 in Critical and Miscellaneous Essays (1857 edn.), vol. 1. at the beginning of said Appendix (completing the footnote); and then will add, by way of footnote, at the end of each name, e.g.—From Musäus were translated Dumb Love (or whatever they are); from Tieck, &c.,Johann Karl August Musaeus (1735–87) and Johann Ludwig Tieck (1773–1853). TC’s introductions and translations of their stories were first pbd. in German Romance (1827) and were repbd. in Critical and Miscellaneous Essays (1857 edn.), vol. 1, app. 1.—we shall have that matter fairly winded up.

I find the other day there was a rather queer little Paper of mine, turning on the ‘Opera,’ printed in some Annual or other,—I cannot say in what London Annual,The Keepsake (1852); see TC to JCA, 17 Feb. except that presumably it had once been Lady Blessington’s, and that certainly this No. of it was published by Lady Blessington’s
Niece,Marguerite Power; see TC to JCA, 17 Feb. next year or second-next after Lady B.’s death.In 1849. Perhaps 1852 or 3? The Piece indisputably exists; I saw a piece of it yesterday, no farther gone. If you could fall in with any reservoir of extinct Annuals, or otherwise hunt up this Piece at any time, it would be ready against vol. 4 of Miscellanies.It became 4:325–29. But do not mind much at all. I think I can inquire it out myself, by due expenditure of force, if hard come to hard. Or perhaps it may fall in of its own accord, from some quarter while we are going on.
This is enough for the present. We hope to see you again some evening before long.— Yours always truly,

p.name: T. Carlyle.
p.note: Larkin noted that the copy of German Romance TC gave him “to cut up and arrange for reprinting, was a copy of the original edition published in 1827” with a dedication to JWC on the flyleaf of vol. 1, “written by a much younger hand than that which indited the intricate MS. with which I had become so familiar“: “AN J. W. CARLYLE. / So ist das werklein nun vollbracht; / Drumm nimm’s, mein holdes weibelein, / An Dich, im Schreiben, hab’ ich stets gedacht, / Und Es und Ich wir sind ja Dein! / T. CARLYLE” [To J. W. Carlyle. / This little work is now accomplished; / therefore take it, my sweet little wife, / in writing it I have thought of you constantly, / and it and I are wholly yours]. Larkin wondered “whether this little glimpse into the past threw any new meaning into Mrs. Carlyle’s notions about the inevitable fruitlessness of ‘romantic devotion,’ which she was already seriously warning me ‘would never do’ ” (BQR 40).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-HF [HFE], [ca. 12 April]. Pbd: Hansons, NE 457 inc., where dated “Easter” and “April 1857” (457, 592); Easter Sunday was 12 April.
div3.head:
JWC
TO HELENA FERME

docBody.p: I don’t know if you are old enough to remember hearing of Mrs Jordan the great comic actress?Dorothea Jordan (1762–1816), actress and mistress of the duke of Clarence, later William IV (1765–1837), by whom she had ten children. I once saw her, when I was six years old. At all events you are old enough to have heard of King William! Well, the man who drew these clever little pictures is a grandsonUnidentified; possibly Philip Sidney (1828–98), 2d Baron de L’Isle and Dudley; trustee of the National Portrait Gallery, 1878; son of Sophia, b. FitzClarence (1796–1837), eldest da. of William IV and Dorothea Jordan, and Philip Charles Sidney (1800–51), 1st Baron de L’Isle and Dudley. of these two people, and takes I suppose his comic talent from the actress-grandmother. … I fell very ill again … and have been all these months confined to two rooms, coughing, and not sleeping, and very weak and dull. So, since my return from Scotland in the beginning of October, up to nearly the present time, I have had only a

figure.p: Hugh Miller, by J. G. Tunny
Reproduced from Hugh Miller, Testimony of the Rocks (1857)

docBody.p: fortnight (about Xmas) free from colds! The weather is now very favourable for the like of me, and I have been out a few times. But instead of walking twelve miles at a stretch, as was my practice, I now think much of twelve yards! My cough is nearly quite gone however, and I have no other ailment but weakness. In such a long confinement, I found consuming my own smokeCoterie speech; cf. Tarr, Sartor 113. about as much as I was up to. That I must certainly have managed to do; for Mr Carlyle has paid me so many compliments on my ‘patience’! and compliment is not in Mr C’s line.

div3.sourceNote: TC-LM [LMI], 15 April. Pbd: unidentified newspaper clipping; Wilson, Carlyle 5:281. Text: newspaper clipping.
div3.head: TC TO LYDIA MILLER

docBody.p: Last night I received a GiftHugh Miller, The Testimony of the Rocks; or Geology in its Bearings on the Two Theologies, Natural and Revealed (Edinburgh, 1857). of your sending, which is at once very precious and very mournful to me.

There is for ever connected with the very title of this Book the fact that, in writing it, the cordage of a strong heart cracked in pieces; that the ink of it is a brave man’s life blood!Miller committed suicide as soon as he had finished his work on the book, apparently spending his last day reading the proofs; see also TC to JCA, 28 Dec. 1856. The Athenaeum, 4 April, reviewed Testimony of Rocks: “The close of the work and the death of its writer occurring so closely together have led to the very general inference, that the production of this work led to that overwrought state of mind of the author which led to his destruction. … [I]n no portion of it do we find evidence of labour such as would break down a mind like that possessed by Hugh Miller” (429). The Book itself, I already see, is full of grave, manly talent, clearness, eloquence, faithful conviction, inquiry, knowledge; and will teach me and others much in reading it:TC wrote at the end of the table of contents of his copy: “To p. 152 extremely well worth reading; mostly skippable after that— Send it to Js Aitken Dumfries, when done with; everybody to take good care of the poor volume, there being a special interest in it” (vi). The section of the book approved of by TC is concerned mainly with paleontology and geology. The rest of the book, except for the last two lectures on Scottish fossil flora, is Miller’s attempt to reconcile the Mosaic with the geological record of creation: “the days of the Mosaic account were great periods, not natural days”; he concludes that the “long ascending line from dead matter to man has been a progress Godwards … destined from the beginning to furnish a point of union; and, occupying that point as true God and true man,—as Creator and created,—we recognise the adorable Monarch of all the future!” (152, 156). TC comments here: “very idle work, all this!” At the beginning of the fifth lecture, “Geology in its bearings on the two theologies,” Miller maintains that the “science of the geologist seems destined to exert a marked influence on that of the natural theologian” to which TC responds: “Try again!” (172). On Miller’s analysis of the “Noachian Deluge,” TC comments: “dreadfully wearisome stuff!” (305). TC’s copy: Strouse. but that is already an extrinsic act
which will give it a double significance to us all. For myself, a voice of friendly recognition from such a man,Probably referring to Lydia Miller’s inscription on the flyleaf, “To / Thomas Carlyle Esq. / from Mrs Hugh Miller / By the Express Desire of Her / Late Husband,” or to the passage in which Miller quotes TC when writing about free will: “[W]e see around us some men addressing themselves with stout brave hearts to what Carlyle terms with homely vigour, their ‘heavy job of work,’ … rearing up well-taught families in usefulness and comfort, to be the stay of the future” (255–56; TC’s copy: Strouse). coming to me thus out of the still kingdoms, has something in it of religion; and is strange and solemn in these profane, empty, times.

In common with everybody I mourned over the late tragic catastrophe; the world’s great loss, especially your irreparable and ever-lamentable one: but as for him, I confess there was always present, after the first shock, the thought that at least he was out of bondage into freedom and rest. I perceived that, for such a man there was no rest appointed except in the countries where he now is!

Dear Madam, what can we say? The ways of God are high and dark; and yet there is mercy hidden in them. Surely, if we knew anything, it is that ‘His goodness endureth for ever.’Ps. 136:12. I will not insult your grief by pretending to lighten it. You and your little ones, yes, you have cause, as few have had, to mourn; but you have also such assuagements as not many have.

closer.salute: With respectful sympathy, with many true thanks and regards, I remain, sincerely yours,

docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-CWW, 18 April. MS: NLS 23167. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLOTTE WILLIAMS WYNN

docBody.p: I am happy to report that the poor Wife got nothing but benefit out of your visit; that the accidentUnexplained. which had befallen earlier in the day proved slighter than might have been feared, and has had no permanency;—and in short that, this morning, things look well again, and in a state of progress.
Some afternoon shortly I will not fail to come, and get my road-instructions.

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: Thomas Erskine wrote to TC, 18 April, from 38 Charlotte Sq., Edinburgh, sorry for his long delay in writing: “the more inexcusable as I had heard from worthy Mrs Braid that Mrs Carlyle, in whom she takes a mother’s interest, had been ill. I am glad that she is now better & in a condition to benefit by what of spring or summer may be before us.” He hoped to see them both when next in Scotland: “& before that time I trust that this weary Fritz may be off your conscience, & thrown on the consciences of other men, as incentive or warning as the truth of the matter may make him. I suppose that he shows us what a strong will & a clear insight, without a conscience can do for a man. To me it is a most unpleasing spectacle—a German king confining his kinghood to leading armies & extending frontiers … I would much rather be honest Mrs Braid, selling flour & bacon. & lovingly bearing the burden of her bed rid son.” He wrote: “Our University here narrowly missed getting Scott for Professor of logic the other day, which I greatly lament both for his sake & ours. I believe the Free Kirk bears the sin of it” (see 31:101TC to AJS, 25 May 1856, and 150–51TC to AJS, 5 Aug. 1856).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JGM, 20 April. MS: London Lib. Quot: Alan Bell, “Thomas Carlyle and the London Library,” TLS, 29 May 1981. James Garth Marshall (1802–73), Leeds flax manufacturer and M.P. for Leeds 1847–52; see TC to MAC, 15 Feb. 1838, TC to MAC, 12 June 1838, and TC to JGM, 13 Oct. 1846.
div3.head: TC TO J. G. MARSHALL

docBody.p: I hear there are now some Fifty-two Candidates for that office in the London Library,—not one of whom, as I judge from former experience in such affairs, probably possesses the least real knowledge of “Bibliography,” which is his essential business there. At any rate, anticipating such result, and being otherwise immeasurably busy in this my own garret, I have undertaken not to interfere at all in the “Election,” and shall most likely not be in the Committee at all till the unhopeful operation is quite over. This has been already my answer to five special applicants. Your friendProbably Robert Harrison of Leeds, who was apptd. will produce his evidences like the others; if he is in fact a “Bibliographer” at all, I shd think it wd give him a shining distinction: and otherwise, I believe the Committee are sincerely desirous to get what they think the fittest man, and will endeavor to do strict justice. I often wonder at the “Anglo-Saxon” methods you talk of; and the qualification that please the electors of said noble “Anglo-Saxons” to office. From the Archbishop of Canterbury “for saving souls,”John Bird Sumner (1780–1862; ODNB), archbishop of Canterbury, 1848–62; see also 29:249TC to LA, 8 Feb. 1855. down to Lord Raglan and Co. “for making War on Russia,”Fitzroy James Henry Somerset (1788–1855), 1st Baron Raglan; commander of British troops in the Crimean War; see 29:249TC to LA, 8 Feb. 1855, and 35829:biographical note. they are a sight to be seen under this sky at present. Our “London Librarian” will be liker his work, I should think, at worst than either of these!—

I heard of Forster’s political movements. I guess he will yet be elected if he live;William Edward Forster (1818–86; ODNB; see 15:229TC to JOST, 14 Dec. 1842, 16:39TC to JGM, 1 Feb. 1843, and 21:53TC to JAC, 19 Sept. 1846), Bradford woolen trader; friend of the Carlyles since the 1840s, though now less close; withdrew as a radical candidate for Leeds when a Liberal announced his candidacy, to avoid dividing the vote. A radical and a Tory were elected; when the Tory died, late May, Forster was again a candidate but withdrew again when there was a Liberal candidate; see T. Wemyss Reid, Life of the Right Hon. W. E. Forster (1888) 1:307–11. He became Liberal M.P. for Bradford, 1861–86. and may help, rather signally in some points, in speeding things whither
they seemed bound at full gallop, so far as I can estimate, in the time that now is.

What my notions have slowly got to be about Anglo-Saxon “Liberty” &c &c, it is perhaps better for you that you do not know. They are not pleasant to myself, very far from it; nor am I interested to afflict my fellow-creatures with them farther in present circumstances. Being indeed nearly killed with “undoable labour” at present, in another departt.

I ride daily, to keep myself alive till the job be done. So soon as you come to Town, appear here at 3½ p.m., and we will have another ride together for auld Langsyne. I send many regards to the Lady.Mary Alicia Pery Marshall, b. Spring Rice (1812–75), m. 1841; see 10:28TC to MAC, 15 Feb. 1838, 13:246TC to JWC, 12 Aug. 1851, and 26:127JWC to KS, 12 Aug. 1851 (where Pery is misspelled Perry). In fair weather as in foul (whh it now rather is, figuratively speaking[)], I am
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 20 April. MS: advtd. for sale by Francis Edwards, catalogue 874 (1965), item 507.
div3.head: TC TO AN UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: [Expressing thanks for a book.]

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [20 April]. MS: NLS 606.473. Quot: Hansons, NE 471; Ashton 387; Fielding and Sorensen 223–24. Dated by TC to Lady A[LA], 7 April, in which the “April weather is miraculously warm,” and JWC’s remark that “the week before last we had three days of the heat of summer.“
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
This is the fourth day I have sat down to write to you! Three several times I had hardly made a beginning, when I was interrupted by something or some body, that could not be set aside. Today is so cold and threatening; that I may hope the external world will leave me in peace; and the internal world looks auspicious enough; only that I feel to have wool in my head instead of brains!— The week before last we had three days of the heat of summer! and
I went out—both on foot and in a carriage. But this favourable weather lasted just long enough to enable me to ascertain by experiment how weak I was! Ever since, it has been fierce north-East wind again and I have had to keep within doors. Anne said this morning while lighting my bed-room fire, “Upon my word, those three warm days were given us for a complete deception”! I could not help saying aloud “Gracious! if my Aunt AnneWelsh of Edinburgh. heard you”!— My cough is almost gone however, and I get generally about five hours sleep— I am wearying to know how you go on in that particular. It is anything but a consolation to me to think of another being as ill off, or worse than myself. Thackerays daughter’sThus in MS. Anne Isabella (1837–1919; ODNB) and Harriet Marian (1840–75). were here yesterday, and speaking of their Grandmother’sAnne Carmichael-Smyth, b. Becher (1792?–1864), Thackeray’s mother, who lived in Paris. sleeplessness—she had just come from Paris to try what change of air would do. “We told her about you” said the eldest Miss Thackeray, “we thought it would be such a comfort to her to hear of somebody in the same way as herself—and you can’t think how pleased she was!!”— Naive at least! I do think a young Human-being who has never known a day’s sickness or sorrow, whatever good humour may lie on the surface, is as cruel as a young Tiger! For after all one cannot bring intelligent sympathy into the world with one; as one brings one’s hair or teeth! It has to be learnt, painfully, by experience— It takes fellow-feeling to “make us wond’rous kind.”Cf. David Garrick (1717–79), “An Occasional Prologue on Quitting the Theatre,” 10 June 1776, given before his last performance as Felix in The Wonder (1714), a comedy by Susannah Centlivre (1669–1723); asking for the audience’s “smiles for sickness and for age,” he continued: “A fellow feeling makes one wondrous kind!” (Arthur Murphy, The Life of David Garrick, Esq [1801] 2:131). I should have loved you, dear Woman, in whatever circumstances I had had opportunity to know your good, pure heart, and winning ways; but I could not have entered into your present grief as I do, if I had never lost my own parents; and if I had slept soundly all my life, I should not have shuddered as I do, in hearing of your bad nights. And so, I felt no temptation to box poor Annie Thackeray’s ears when she made that hard speech, looking the while ready to burst with health and happiness! I merely thought; “poor girl! you will understand better about all that by and by!”Anne, later Lady Ritchie, wrote of her visits to Cheyne Row, as so “vivid a part of my early life. … [B]est of all, there was Mrs. Carlyle herself, a living picture; Gainsborough should have been alive to paint her; slim, bright, dark-eyed, upright, in her place. She looked like one of the grand ladies our father used sometimes to take us to call upon. She used to be handsomely dressed in velvet and point lace. … She was not familiar, but cordial, dignified, and interested in everything as she sat installed in her corner of the sofa by one of the little tables covered with nicknacks of silver and mother-of-pearl. … / She used to tell us many of the stories which have since come into print. She was never weary of discoursing of ‘Carlyle.’ … ‘If you wish for a quiet life,’ she used to say, ‘never you marry a dyspeptic man of genius.’ … As children we did not have much of Carlyle’s company … but the sense of his presence overhead in the study distinctly added to our enjoyment so long as he remained upstairs. Mrs. Carlyle used to tell us of her early life, of her passion for study. … Once, looking expressively at me with her dark eyes, she began to speak of self-control. ‘We have all … a great deal more power over our minds than it is at all the fashion to allow, and an infinity of resource and ability to use it. There was a time in my own life … when I felt that unless I strove against the feeling with all my strength and might I should be crazed outright. I passed through that time safely; I was able to fight it out and not to let myself go’ ” (Anne, Lady Ritchie, Chapters from Some Memoirs [1894] 134–37).

The german project rests in abeyance. Indeed I am sure Mr C will not have the two volumes of his book off his hands in time to go any such road for a good many months to come. And a winter at Berlin (which he seemed to contemplate) I would positively not agree to. The cold there is dreadful in winter; and I am not so suicidally disposed as to subject my delicate lungs to its action I would do a great deal that is disagreeable to meet his wishes and keep him quiet; but I would not carry my complisance so far as to go and die and be buried among strangers.

However I escape a great deal of angry discussion by letting all his ideas take their course till the moment of carrying them into action. So few of them ever reach that point! and they efface themselves all the sooner for not being stimulated by contradiction!

A Lady here, a shrewd old Maid,Unidentified. said to me once “I never knew any wife that might get her own way so completely as you; if you only managed well! You have but to pretend always to want the opposite of what you really do want”!!—

Only think! my little dog is to have his picture in the Exhibition this year! A friend of ours went into an artist’s studio the other day, and saw a picture he was just finishing to send; “Why, said he, that is Nero?” “Yes said the Artist (the man who did your photographs) but he did not sit for it, I painted him from his photograph.” And if he had painted only him in the picture, I should have been well pleased; but the poor little dog has been used up as an accessory to the figure of a—stark-naked Woman! just stepping into a Bath!Robert Tait’s Susannah, to be shown at the Royal Academy Summer Exhibition in May. Now I dont like this at all for as my dog has a very extensive acquaintance, and the portrait of him, I am told, is recognizable at any distance, and the dog was never seen but in my company I am in horror lest the naked figure should be taken for me!!— The only comfort is, the naked women in pictures are always plump—and I am but two degrees removed from a skeleton at present.

Has Mrs Maitland of Eccles really set up a baby?Mary Catherine, b. Gillespie (1805?–57), wife of Lauderdale Maitland of Eccles, Dumfriesshire, 2 mi. W of Thornhill. She d. 27 June, age 42, at 10 Albyn Place, Edinburgh, after the birth there of their da., Lina Mary, 15 May. She was the da. of Alexander Gillespie, M.D., and Eliza Mary Gillespie, b. Shirriff. Have you been to see Mrs Veitch yet?See JWC to MR, [15 March][mid-]March. I should be so glad to hear of your having taken some little excursion.

Do you remember my promising you something to keep your tea-pot warm, that would be better than the cloth you wrapped about it? I had had one of the tea-warmers I had seen made; and had written part of an absurd letter to your Husband to accompany it—being sure it was on his account you took so much pains with the tea; when that relapse befell me, and I had to take to bed, leaving the letter unfinished in my blot-book. Alas! before I was well enough to finish it, came his sad news!Presumably a letter in Feb. from James Russell with the news of the death of her father, Rev. Edward Dobbie. and the half written letter begun in foolish spirits was thrown in the fire, and the thing shoved out of sight for a while—even now I send it with misgiving—lest the gaudy colours should be unpleasant to your poor sad sleepless eyes.

closer.salute: God comfort you my Darling. My Love to your Husband.

docBody.name: Yours Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Mr. W [MRW], 22 April. MS: Berg. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO MR. WARREN

docBody.p: Memorandum to Mr Warren.

Revd Walter Welsh / Auchtertool / Fife / by Edinburgh,—to whom a Copy of each Volume was to be sent as it came out,—has got duly the 2 of French Revolution; but has heard nothing yet of any of the Cromwell Volumes.French Revolution had been pbd. in Jan. and vol. 1 of Cromwell, late Feb.; vol. 2 was advertised in the Athenaeum, 28 March and 4 April, as pbd. “this day”; see appendix 1Athenaeum Advertisements. Will you be so good as take order in regard to this (whether the others that go to Glasgow &c are all right, I don’t know);—and please send a Note at any rate to Mr Welsh, informing him what Bookseller in Edinr gets charge of the volumes; so that, if there be farther delay, he may apply in person.

2. To send a Copy of the Cromwell (no more) to “David Laing Esq, Signet Library, Edinburgh“:—it ought to have his name written on Vol i; but unless you can (t.o.) send your man down hither with one, some forenoon while it is still time, I do not see how that is to be done. I am here till 3 p.m. always.— Or
here is a bit of paper, properly inscribed, to get bound-in as a fly-leaf, if you prefer that method?
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Chelsea, 22 April 1857

div3.sourceNote: TC-VL, 26 [24] April. Addr: 8 College Sq. / Doctors Commons. PM: 25 April 1857. MS: NLS 23167.118. Pbd: Fielding, “Vernon Lushington” 14–15 inc. TC writes on Friday, 24, but misdates 26 April.
div3.head: TC TO VERNON LUSHINGTON

docBody.p: If you have returned from your Circuit,Referring to Lushington’s work as a lawyer. I shd like to see you again,—Tomorrow (Saturday) Evg, for instance? Or the first evg you have to yourself after that.

The Cromwell is happily all over;The Athenaeum, 25 April, advertised vol. 3 of Cromwell as to be pbd. 30 April; see appendix 1Athenaeum Advertisements. in revising your work (a task rendered quite easy to me), I had all along occasion to thank you in silence: all was as lucid and succinct as the best practical intelligence cd make it.

The thing in question now is a small but perhaps delicate request I have to make of you, in a quite other field. Prepare yourself to say No, if it be too delicate: for I myself have no interest in the thing, except to do and say, with veracity, what seems to be my portion of function in it for another human creature.Probably concerning Frederick Martin; see TC to VL, 28 April.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 26 April. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: I think it will be better that I come to you on Wednesday Evg. MadameEliza Forster. will let me appear in rough coat I will come riding, and be off again before 9½ o’clock;—fortified with your instructions, and a “chop” plus two glasses (not more) from that hospitable bottle, the memory of which is dear to me.— I recollect the No, “40. Montague Square“:In fact, 46 Montague Sq., where he had moved after marriage. shall I guess the hour to be 6? If yes, do not write at all, and it shall be so settled.

If you had opportunity, you might ask your PrinterEither McCorquodale & Co., printers of his most recent book, Daniel de Foe and Charles Churchill (1855), or Bradbury & Evans, printers of Forster’s next book, Historical and Biographical Essays (1858), 2 vols., and of Life and Times of Oliver Goldsmith (1854), 2 vols.; they had wanted to print the new edition of TC’s works; see 31:129TC to RWE, 20 July 1856. for a rough guess at the expence: Two Volumes Hist. 8vo (à la Macaulay)“8vo“: octavo; i.e., a book the size of Macaulay’s History of England, vols. 1 and 2 (1849), vols. 3 and 4 (1855); see also 31:152TC to RST, 7 Aug. 1856. 450 pages each, with a frontispiece engraving (Portrait) to each, and say three small maps,—or these latter items we could guess for ourselves. His answer might help us a little. Robson must print the Book,Frederick. for he alone can read it; therefore do not give your man much trouble. I will ask Robson himself,—but, alas, when?— — On the whole, I find I had better have £100 less from Chapman on condition of his taking all that bother off me;—and also I find that we ought to come to some decision; and fairly get to work.
Adieu dear F. till Wednesday at 6:—or till such other hour as you appoint, if it be necessary to write and appoint another.

closer.salute: With many kind regards to the Lady,

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HTW, 27 April. Addr: Engineer’s Office / East and West India Docks (the name in TC’s hand, the rest in John Ruskin’s). PM: 1 May 1857. Pbd: The Bookman 56 (1919): 130. TC had forgotten Wake’s address and sent it to Ruskin for forwarding. TC’s brief message is on the inner flap of the envelope.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY T. WAKE

docBody.p: With Mr. Carlyle’s ComptsThe envelope contained clippings, sent to TC by Edward Everett (1794–1865), of a report in the Boston Daily Courier, 10 April, of Everett’s presentation of the tithe book of Ecton parish (see 29:218–19TC to HTW, 19 Dec. 1854) to the Massachusetts Historical Society at a ceremony inaugurating the bronze statue of Benjamin Franklin outside City Hall, Boston, 9 April. TC wrote on the clippings (now in Boston Public Library with MS C.1.30) before sending them to Wake: “Boston (N. Eng) recd. April 25—T. C.” (The Bookman 56:130).

div3.sourceNote: TC-RWE, 28 April 1857. MS: Houghton. Hitherto unpbd. The letter precedes TC to VL, 28 April 1857 .[This letter, pbd. at CL 44:233, is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO RALPH WALDO EMERSON

docBody.p: Permit me to recommend to you this young English gentnProbably John Webb Probyn (1828–1915), author of Essays on Italy and Ireland and the United States of America (1868) and later works. (I think a Cambridge Scholar Probyn had graduated from Trinity Coll., Cambridge, 1850.), friend of an excelt and obliging young friend of mine, TC’s letter was written at the request of Vernon Lushington (1832–1912), writer and barrister; see 32:136TC to VL, 28 April 1857, where Lushington’s friend is unidentified. who describes him credibly in highly favourable terms,—a strong wish to see you, one of the qualities predicated.

You will actually oblige me, and help in repayment of a debt,Lushington was helping TC with his Collected Works (1857–58); see K. J. Fielding, “Vernon Lushington,” Carlyle Newsletter 8 (1987): 7–18. by complying (as you are sure to do) in this matter.

div3.sourceNote: TC-VL, 28 April. MS: NLS 23167.121. Pbd: Fielding, “Vernon Lushington” 15 inc.
div3.head: TC TO VERNON LUSHINGTON

docBody.p:
Many kind thanks:—do all that you can, and let us hope for a good issue to the forlorn Martin. I will straight way write him my Certificate; he will be at
his speed, inquiring what to do and how, tomorrow morning. I will recommend him not to trouble you, except in case of extremity.
I have written the Emerson Note for your friend.Unidentified.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 29 April. MS: NLS 552.136. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,— I find I am stopt short by that Nosti Correspondence.The correspondence between “Nosti,” the undercover name of Reichenbach, Prussian resident sec. in London, and Friedrich Wilhelm von Grumkow (1678–1739); see Works 13:221–22: “a more sordid mass of eavesdroppings, kitchen-ashes and floor-sweepings … was never got together out of a gentleman’s household.” I will skip, till you find it out for me. Meanwhile it is better I send you the whole batch of Queries, and have done with them. On that inclosed Patch, you get a not too lucid Copy of them! The sooner the better.

I am now in hopes of being at Press taliter qualiter [for what it’s worth] very soon. We must then get on, at some steady rate, till these two voll. are done.— — By the bye, having now decided to make a long pause before ever trying voll iv and v, I sometimes wish I had accepted DeckersSee 27:375TC to RLDAKD, 27 Dec. 1852. offer of an Oeuvres de Frédc. These London LibrarySee 31:118TC to RLE, 8 July 1856. people write to me, once in the half year or so, in a certain subdued but intelligible tone, “You have 80 voll” &c &c!TC was only supposed to borrow 10 vols. at a time; see 30:69TC to WBD, 17 Sept. 1855. I long greatly to be able to take the whole 80 detestable volumes, and fling them on their floor to all eternity. But that cannot happen, after all, it wd seem, for some time.— — On the whole it is little matter. Truth is, I had much rather not have Fredc’s works by me, were I once done with all this! We will wait till the Works (with Index &c) are completed.Probably referring to the final vol. of J. D. E. Preuss’s edn. of Oeuvres de Frédéric, 31 vols. (Berlin, 1846–57), pbd. by Decker; cf. 27:376TC to RLDAKD, 27 Dec. 1852. Then, it will not be impossible to buy a Copy, and burn it when one has done with it.
A wretched snuffy Clerk, reproaching me because I have got those Books, seems to me (tho’ I know the wretch is in his duty) one of the unkindest cuts of all!Julius Caesar 3.2.—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 1 May. MS: NLS 525.25. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I had your Note this morning; I have been long looking for it. You shd write me oftener, in these times of cheap postage; I am so held, I never write when it can be avoided. Whh also I surmise some times is an error on my part.

Jane has got no more cold for a six weeks past; but is so utterly weak she cannot rally much till the sun come; and this is as grim a Mayday as I ever saw. For my own share, I am no worse than usual; often somewhat disheartened by my last mischance,—but on the whole it is rather in the imagination, all that, if we take it up strictly. Considerable bother I have had, learning to wear (easily) my apparatus;For his hernia. TC wrote in his journal, 29 March: “First appearance of Hernia. A great shock to me, when drying myself after bathing. May God Almighty grant that it be a useful lesson; for certainly it was a heavy and hard one. I do begin, too, to see I had need of it. So many things loading me this winter, health gone,—and I madly resolute to mend all by mere force: by fiercely writing agt nature, fiercely riding to gain health &c. Doing the wretched bubble of ‘George II & Friedh Wilhelm’s Quarrel’ (forsooth!) with misery whh seemed then to be supreme enough, but was only superior! It is now Friday when I write,—going to the Surgeon for consultn this day.—I find surely I have not been wise in my procedures; surely if I be not wise, they will not prosper. Let me be taught.” but worn, it is a complete succedaneum: I have never had either pain or inconvenience from the thing at all except in that way only. And riding answers better than walking for it, I think. Besides it is really an admonition to me. “Be canny!” it says,—for exactly in proportion to my general health is the tolerability of that “apparatus” and the rest of it.

I expect to have a Bargain made with Chapman in a few days;—then to go fairly to press with my two volumes;Vols. 1 and 2 of Frederick, pbd. Sept. 1858. get these done within about a year;—after whh have a long pause (perhaps visit Germany &c) before starting on the other two. By working “Canny, Canny,” I believe I have still strength for this.

Residence in the country, with meal and milk ad libitum [freely], fresh air, and quiet, quiet:—this is my constant daydream at present; in fact I get a deal of annoyance out of London, and my imagination aggravates it, and abolishes the good there is. If you had a nice Country house, and we this Town one, what fine exchanging of quarters there might be!— — I send Fraser today for Jean after you. My affectionate regards to Jamie & Isabla,—to poor old GrahameWilliam Graham wrote to John, 6 May, and John forwarded the letter, 8 May: “I know not what report has raised him to such a Key.” Graham was under the impression that TC had been awarded £1,000 a year, “as the Greatest Writer of the Recent Age!” He wrote of his pride at owning TC’s works and that he was longing to see John, hoping in the meantime that John would write him a long letter (MS: NLS 1775B.240). too.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 1 May. MS: NLS 552.137. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Night before last I got a note from Wms & Norgate,Dealers in German books, 14 Henrietta St. whh I meant to send you, with request to begin a small operation upon it for me. The Note, today, is lost; but it was merely an Application from Tauchnitz of LeipzigChristian Bernhard Tauchnitz (1816–95; see 27:110TC to JAC, 10 May 1852). abt our forthcoming Book; and the operation can go on, all the same.

Tauchnitz has written to Williams & Norgate, Henrietta Street Covent Garden, that he wants to print that Fh II (in English);The first German edn. in English of vols. 1 and 2 of Frederick was pbd. by Tauchnitz (Leipzig, 1858) as part of the Collection of British Authors series. and Wms & Norgate ask me to write to them, or to come &c: that was the lost Note;—and I think it will be briefer if you start from that basis, & manage the thing for me.

French Revn, you can tell Tauchnitz, I am happy to hear is well printed: price given for it (only £25) seems to me very low.Tauchnitz had pbd. French Revolution (Leipzig, 1851), paying TC £25; see 26:111TC to JN, 25 July 1851. Are there no other (old) Books of mine he wd like to print? Lr Day Pamphts;Tauchnitz was to publish Cromwell (Leipzig, 1861) and Life of Schiller (Leipzig, 1869). He apparently did not publish Latter-Day Pamphlets; TC had regretted not recommending it to Tauchnitz at their meeting in1851; see 26:110TC to JAC, 24 July 1851. that wd be a sappy morsel, for example!

“Fk II” two “Histl Octavo” voll 500 pages each (or so) is actually now going to press; will be a Book (please God) before this time twelve month. Unless I am offered £100 for the privilege of printing, no bargain at present.— That is the sum of the thing; if you will be so favourable as put it into official language
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [1? May]. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Tentatively dated by Larkin’s work on vol. 1 of the “Miscellanies“ (see TC to HL, 10 April), assuming that his summaries are those for the cheap edn. (in one vol.) of Life of Schiller and Life of Sterling (see TC to HL, 30 Jan.), advtd., Athenaeum, 13 June, as pbd. “this day”; see .
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: I expected you last night; still more confidently tonight. I find I ought to have written.

Tonight the Printer has sent me Proofs of the Summaries and word that he wants (meaning, will soon want) vol i of Miscellanies. Please come to me tomorrow night if you possibly can. I will confidently expect you

The Summaries, on reading them over, I find to be extremely good; very careful, exact, and the phraseology ingenious and expressive. Hardly anything I shd think of changing. But there are two points that must be attended to: first, a page-no ‘(p. 10’Thus in MS. or the like) introduced here and there: second, a more distinct method of punctuation. I think you can alter everything in the course of one day, after we have talked together: so I promise Robson you will take him back the Proofs on Monday morning.

By way of giving you time to understand a little what kind of connections I mean, I enclose you the first slip with some pencillings on it: whatsoever you find dark in that we can explain in our talk at night,—when you take the other two slips; and leave the vol i of Miscs if it be ready.

closer.salute: I am in boundless haste, and always

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GLC, [5 May]. Addr: Holywood / Belfast. PM: Belfast, 6 May 1857. MS: Strouse. Fielding and Sorensen 224–25.
div3.head: JWC TO GEORGE LILLIE CRAIK

docBody.p: “Ill”? dear Mr Craik! I should think so! When, in the memory of man, was I ever well? And didn’t I tell you in my last letter, that I was confined to the house with a protracted cold, which I had no expectation to shake off till warm weather come? I put it to you as a man of veracity and candour if warm weather have come yet! I am not however so ill as I was; my cough is all but gone I get about half instead of a tithe of the sleep normal to Human beings, and I eat certainly as much as Nero eats, or rather, is allowed to eat. When the Eastwind has blown itself out, which wont be (Mr C’s tailorUnidentified. says) till “the 26 of June”; I expect to be “about” to more or less purpose.

Et tu Brute!Julius Caesar 3.1. Oh how could you fill so much of your paperProbably his letter to JWC rather than an article in the Penny Magazine, to which Craik was a regular contributor. with the Life of
